PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of certain Australian citizens draws to the attention of the Senate the need to establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia:

PARA.TAB: because of the many difficulties experienced by Australian citizens accessing limited consular services when travelling through Croatia;
because of the limited consular services in Croatia, requiring Australian citizens to visit the Australian Embassy in Austria, incurring travelling and other costs; and
to establish and maintain economic and political ties, for the mutual benefit of Australia and the Republic of Croatia.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners respectfully request that the Senate should:

PARA.TAB: Take appropriate and immediate action to establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government honour its commitment to the Higher Education sector as stated in the Liberal and National Parties' Higher Education Policy (February 1996).
We demand the Australian Government honour its promises to:

PARA.TAB: maintain Austudy and Abstudy with benefits at real levels
maintain levels of funding to universities in terms of operating grants
maintain the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS)
ensure no compulsory up‐front fees for undergraduate places
ensure no cuts in university places.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intention by an Australian Government to introduce student fees, increase HECS repayments, abolish Austudy or Abstudy, or cut funding for university places.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: We, the citizens of Queensland, call upon the Prime Minister to intervene in the Expenditure Review Process of Budget Preparation to fully protect the Australian Broadcasting Corporation from major expenditure cut‐backs which would irreversibly damage the professionalism, independence and quality of the national broadcaster.

In particular, we ask that all A.B.C. regional services be more adequately maintained with increased recognition of staffing and resource needs in non‐metropolitan Australia. Furthermore, we submit that any review process should be more broadly based and require the knowledge and experience of several individuals who have a background in national radio and television broadcasting.

PETITION.TITLE: Ramsar Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia in Geelong requests that the Senate examine the proposal to set aside land currently protected under the Ramsar Treaty in order to provide for a chemical storage facility at Pt Lillias. Further, we request the Senate to examine whether the proposal to set aside an area alternate to the one now nominated by the Ramsar Treaty is in accordance with the requirement of that Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Ramsar Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned Aboriginal people of Australia requests that the Senate examine the proposal to set aside land currently protected under the Ramsar Treaty in order to provide for a chemical storage facility at Point Lillias. Further, we request the Senate to examine whether the proposal to set aside an alternate to the one now nominated by the Ramsar Treaty is in accordance with the requirement of the Treaty and the International Convention on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, and the Declaration Of The Principles of International Cultural Co‐operation, UNESCO, 1966, and the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being, members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6.(1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from The Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated, `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was ` July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their country on active service overseas.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honour able `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Campbell) has just been able to inform the Senate—by motion—in relation to the non‐controversial business to be dealt with at 12.45 p.m. today and to the order of general business for today. I want to briefly speak to this motion to indicate the opposition's concern about the way the government is mishandling the government business orders of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation program for the day, as outlined on the red, was changed yesterday without consultation with the opposition. I appreciate the fact that Senator Campbell rang me and apologised for that. I also appreciate that it may be difficult at the moment, with the death of the government whip, Senator Panizza. Normally matters relating to the listing of government business have not been dealt with directly through the government whip, but I appreciate that his death may have caused changes to arrangements on the government side of the chamber.

At 9.30 today, we have been informed, again, that there is a proposal to change the orders of the day to bring forward the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2). While the opposition is happy to debate that bill, I urge through you, Madam President, that the normal mechanisms of consultation take place with the opposition, the other parties and the independents in this place. That did not occur yesterday, it has not occurred this morning. I say this with the best spirit I can muster. I am not making a very partisan comment here, but I think the ball has now been dropped on two occasions. I appreciate there may be reasons for that, but I urge the government to get its act together on this. Yesterday, I had to cancel a meeting because I was informed legislation was coming before the Senate. Having marched people out of my office, I found that, in fact, a different bill was being brought forward for debate. I do not think that is good enough.

This morning, literally 30 seconds after the bells stopped ringing for the commencement of the day's sitting, we have been informed that the government is proposing a change. We can accommodate the change, we are happy to debate the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2), but I do urge, through you, Madam President, that the government give this some consideration. What we—and, I think, all parties in the Senate—require, and what is ordinarily the case, is some consultation about these changes. With, as I said, the best will in the world that I can muster on this occasion, I ask the Manager of Government Business to give my comments due consideration.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of Appropriation Bills by Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present additional information received by the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee in response to the 1996‐97 budget estimates hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This relates, I presume, to the additional information received—volume 5 of the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee—concerning questions placed on notice in October last year. Frankly, the estimates processes have revealed just how deplorable the state of affairs is within the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. We have seen that this government has embarked upon a policy to reduce outlays for this department in terms of overall government expenditure from about 11 per cent of whole of govern ment expenditure to nine per cent in the forward estimates period.

In practice, what that means is that, for schools, universities and employment programs, there has to be a remarkable, dramatic drop in the level of service provided by the Commonwealth to the Australian people. We see in today's newspaper the impact of that in terms of the Australian National Training Authority. I noticed the answers to questions have been highlighted here. The government has now run into great difficulty in trying to administer these cuts in a manner where they are seeking to hide the true impact of the cuts from the Australian people.

For school students in Victoria, the Victorian education department has highlighted, through the arrangements made last December, that independent school students will get the equivalent of about $1,700 each from Commonwealth government vocational studies, but state school students will get only $300 each for vocational studies. That is the way in which programs are being administered, and the impact in terms of vocational education and training is a decline in expenditure totaling some $137 million over the forward estimates period. That directly relates and impacts upon the services provided by the Commonwealth for students, for Australian citizens throughout this country.

In my state in particular there are a whole series of measures now being undertaken to disproportionately allocate funds for private schools and private interests in particular and a slow, creeping privatisation of the functions of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs in such a manner as to provide a disproportionate share of resources to private interests. So we see the downgrading of the public education system and the downgrading of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the public sector in this country. That will have long‐term detrimental impacts on the economy and culture of this country.

It is not just about the economic impact; it is the social impact that I am fearful of. I am concerned that the Australian National Training Authority has sought, of course under government direction, to distribute moneys in such a way as to give unfair advantage to private interests and private schools in particular. That could be no better expressed than in the article in the Age this morning entitled `School Funding Gap Revealed'. What is revealed through these answers is that this is a pattern that now emerges in all aspects of the government's administration of this department.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Export Control (Hardwood Woodchips) (Monitoring Fee) Orders (Amendment), Order No. HW1 of 1996, made under regulation 3 of the Export Control (Orders) Regulations, made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

For the information of the Senate, the effect of the change to regulations which the government has before the Senate is to reduce the levy on export woodchips which is raised in order to fund the woodchip export monitoring unit, otherwise known as WEMU. The woodchip export monitoring unit was established because of the now two decades old controversy over the environmental impact on forests in four states of Australia by the export woodchip industry.

The unit was set up in 1995 under the Labor government. It was funded by a 12.6c levy on each green tonne of woodchips being exported out of the country. The aim was to raise $660,000 a year to fund WEMU. The woodchip export monitoring unit's function is to ensure that, amongst other things, the environmental safeguards which governments at a state and federal level want put in place will in fact be carried out. But the reality is that, in the two years of its functioning, the woodchip export monitoring unit, despite that funding, has not been able to carry out the task set for it.

One of the basic reasons that it has not been able to carry out the task is that it is underfunded. It has only two staff. Those two staff have not had on‐the‐ground experience with forestry matters. They certainly have not been personally involved in the conservation issues raised in Victoria, New South Wales, Tasmania, Western Australia and which potentially will be raised in Queensland now that the government has decided that export woodchipping from Queensland will be allowed to proceed in the future.

The ability of this unit, which is integral to the monitoring of this most contentious of environmental issues for the whole nation of Australia, needs to be increased. It needs to have a much bigger staff allocation and, above all things, it needs to become visible in the job of monitoring export woodchipping in a way that it has failed to do so far.

But, instead of increasing the minuscule levy that is on export woodchipping to facilitate WEMU being properly able to do its job, the Senate has before it a change in regulations that would actually decrease the amount of money. What is proposed is that the levy be decreased from 12.6c a unit to 11.2c a unit.

This year the government has already issued licences for 6¼ million tonnes of export woodchips to come out of Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales and Western Australia destined for Northern Hemisphere countries, principally Japan.If you do the calculations on that almost unprecedented level of export woodchips coming out of our native forest, you find that it can be expected that, under the existing very tiny levy, $787,000 would be raised. Under the levy proposed by this change in regulations, only $700,000 would be raised. In effect, the government is cutting the revenue expected from this levy by $88,000 this year. I submit to the Senate very strongly indeed that there needs to be a five or tenfold increase in the levy if this unit is to be able to do anything like the job expected of it.

That is not just an off-the-cuff statement. During the estimates committee hearings last year Senator Parer, when questioned about WEMU, indicated that he had no knowledge of its existence. Unfortunately, he is not here to talk about that at the moment, but I hope he does come into the chamber. When we spoke to the departments involved it seemed that they had very little knowledge. It was not until the second day of the committee hearings that we could get somebody from this export monitoring unit to come before the Senate estimates committee to explain what was going on.

But we did find out that when it came to Tasmania at least that the woodchip export monitoring unit was failing to do its job. It failed on a number of bases. First of all, its existence was not known to key departments within the Commonwealth. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet had failed to pass on to it information about breaches of woodchip conditions in Tasmania. Likewise, the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories had failed to pass on to the woodchip export monitoring unit critical information about breaches of regulations in Tasmania.

Citizens who are concerned about the impact of export woodchipping on our high conservation value native forests do not know that WEMU exists. They do not know that there is a place within the Commonwealth orb to which they can address their complaints.

When we asked WEMU what it had done to let people know that it is the place to which complaints should go, we found that it had done no advertising whatever. There had been a press release, which, so far as I know, got no coverage. In fact, WEMU has failed to become recognised as the place to which complaints about breaches of woodchip regulations and woodchip proper practice, if there is such a thing, can be sent.

I will give some instances. A very comprehensive document listing series of breaches of forestry practice was sent to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet by Mr Andrew Ricketts from Reedy Marsh near Deloraine in Tasmania. These included breaches of stream side reserves, logging in places where it should not have been allowed and so on. In fact, in Tasmania, the Forest Practices Board, the state instrumentality, had confirmed these breaches, yet its counterpart in the federal arena, the Woodchip Export Monitoring Unit, knew nothing about these breaches. They told me at the committee that if a breach had occurred, they would know about it. But when asked about this extensive range of breaches confirmed by the authorities at state level in Tasmania, they had no knowledge of it at all. There was a complete breakdown and failure because they are unfunded and effectively hamstrung by the pittance which the Commonwealth allocates to them to do an enormously important and key job in trying to settle the contention about export woodchipping.

When it came to a breach of the law and the illegal logging of national estate forests on the east coast of Tasmania by the nation's biggest woodchipper, North, WEMU again seemed to have no knowledge and certainly no ability to act. The total outcome from this breaking of the law, whereby North went in and logged national estate forests on the east coast, was a smack on the hand through a letter from the minister. In other words, it was nothing much at all.

At Nimmitabel in New South Wales in 1994, on the property of Mr Chris Graham and family, Harris‐Daishowa moved in without the owner's permission—this block was bought specifically to protect 60 to 70 hectares of old‐growth forest—and illegally logged this private land for woodchipping. The company has since accepted liability without prejudice and offered to pay the equivalent royalty of $15,000 for this unique and irreplaceable forest.

I cannot tell the Senate the anguish of the Graham family, who put aside what was for them a big amount of money to protect what was for them a wonderful, magnificent piece of forest. They went down there one day and found that Harris‐Diashowa had gone in on their land illegally and logged it. They wrote to the national minister for forests, Mr Beddall, but got no reply. In 1995, they wrote again to his department, providing maps and full details. This was after WEMU, the Woodchip Export Monitoring Unit, was established by him. After persistence, they were told that the department had lost the file. Certainly there has been no action from WEMU.

What has happened there is a total travesty of those people's rights and the conservation values of those forests. It was a complete failure of the expectation that WEMU would be able to do its job of monitoring the environmental impact of the voracious export woodchip industry in Australia's high conser vation native forests. I might add that it is an impact beyond just the word `forests'. It is an impact that, as we have seen with the East Gippsland forest agreement in the last few days, is going to continue to erode vital areas of habitat for rare and endangered species of flora and fauna. It will continue to erode forests of inestimable value. We will continue to see a massive confrontation between the conservation movement and the export woodchippers who have been licensed to cut down Australia's native forests at the greatest rate in history at a time when we have less left than ever before.

A specific federal body has been set up to be the interface for the concerns of millions of Australians who do not want export woodchipping. According to repeated opinion polls, 80 per cent of Australians do not want export woodchipping of our wild native forests. This industry is making extraordinary profits out of these publicly owned forests. Surely that federal body ought to be adequately financed from the sale of those forests. Surely it should be visible to the public. It is neither of those things. Here we have the government wanting to cut the measly amount of money that goes to funding this critical unit by $80,000 plus in the coming year. It is something that the Senate should not allow. We are not in a position to increase this levy, but if we were, that is what we should be doing.

Let me reiterate that there will be record levels of export woodchips taken out of this country in the coming years. The industry is going to make a killing, with billion dollar profits. It is surely not going to do any harm to increase what is at the moment, if you look at freight on board sales of woodchips, a one 1,000th levy on the money the woodchip companies get from the sale of these public forests so that there can be some adequate monitoring.

I know the government is going to argue that it is cutting the fee because there is a component of self‐regulation involved here—the companies are going to do an audited report each year themselves. That is not going to satisfy me, I do not think it will satisfy some of the honourable senators sitting very close to me and it is certainly not going to satisfy the public. They are not gullible enough to believe that this industry, with its record of breaches of forest codes, unlawful illegal logging, destruction of private citizens' forests, and destruction of habitat of rare and endangered species, is going to be self‐regulatory. The public is not going to believe that this industry will in any way be self‐regulatory if that is going to get in the way of it making money.

It is time we took a stand, at least on this neutral ground of having an umpire which has got the strength to do the job it was purported to be able to do. It was a good thing that it was set up—I congratulate the previous government for that—but we have found that, in its two years of operation, it simply is not well enough funded. The government, with that two years of experience tucked under its belt, should be giving this critical watchdog unit the profile it requires and the ability, not only to take in information that is handed to it willy‐nilly, but the ability to go out in the field and investigate complaints independently.

Ideally, this should properly be an independent statutory authority so that it is able to independently act to make sure that in the coming years proper process is not infringed, as it is being repeatedly infringed in the logging of forests for woodchips by the eight woodchip companies which are licensed in this country. Properly also, there ought to be some division between its function as watchdog and police of what is going on in the forests and the judgment at the end of the day as to what it can do. These functions are all wrapped up in one.

I reiterate that we now know that WEMU is failing because it does not have the capacity to do a job that is much bigger than the one it is able to do on this shoestring budget. Two people, unknown even to other departments within the Commonwealth, completely unknown to the wider public, are expected to do the critical job of ensuring that these huge woodchip companies which are working in huge areas of forests are monitored. I think I saw the figure the other day: eleven football fields of forests in East Gippsland alone are being cut each working day, and East Gippsland is only part of the suite of forests around the country being logged.

This issue is not going to go away. The contention will get worse as more and more forests are cut into. I would think for its own defence, for its own public kudos, the government would want to strengthen and improve the capability of this referee—this umpire, if you like—in the form of the Woodchip Export Monitoring Unit. So it is a little bit rich for the government to put before this chamber changed regulations which will actually decrease the amount of money going to this underfunded, understaffed and incapable unit within the federal bureaucracy. If the government does not want the unit to function adequately, then it should abolish it and put the money to some other use.

I submit that there is no place, given the increased export woodchipping of the coming years and the increased contention there will be about the destruction of forests and contentious wildlife habitats, for a scale‐down of the puny watchdog function that the Commonwealth has put in place. It needs to be reviewed, greatly expanded and much better funded out of the enormous profits that these woodchip companies are making at the expense of the public interest and this nation's great forest environment heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —May I start by saying that the government does not accept the motion before the Senate today—notice of which was given by Senator Brown—and, moreover, that the government does not accept many of the assertions that Senator Brown has made today. But that is nothing extraordinary, in that we do not accept many of Senator Brown's assertions.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just outline for the Senate briefly what this debate is about. It is about a regulation setting a level of charge—it is not a tax, it is a charge—which is required to be paid by woodchip exporters to meet the cost of a monitoring operation. I am very glad to have in the chamber two distinguished former chairmen of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. They would understand the point I am making that, where a charge is made, a charge cannot be collected in excess of the cost which is sought to be defrayed by the charge. So, for example, if the cost of operating something were, say, $5 million a year, the Commonwealth is not able by regulation to charge $10 million a year and pocket the difference. In fact, there is a legal obligation upon the Commonwealth—as both Senator Colston and Senator Bob Collins would be aware—to refund amounts of charges which are received in excess of the cost which they exist to defray.

Senator Colston, in his period of time as chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances dealt with a number of issues—incidentally, when Senator Bob Collins was the minister—where charges had to be refunded by the Commonwealth and arrangements had to be made to ensure that refund occurred. As Senator Colston will be aware, and Senator Bob Collins will also be aware, in relation to excess charges collected for meat inspection, amongst other things, it was quite a complex process of refunding the money.

Now what Senator Brown seeks to do is to say that he wants to force the Commonwealth to collect more money than it is legally entitled to collect and then force the Commonwealth to refund that money through a very complex procedure. That is really what this is all about. Senator Brown, in gilding the lily today, of course, has raised all sorts of concerns that he has about forests. I will take Senator Brown's concerns at face value, but as Senator Bob Collins would be aware, the management of forests is a state responsibility. The Commonwealth has imposed obligations to report—and I commend Senator Collins because I understand the unit in question was set up when he was the minister. The Commonwealth has placed on top of that a second layer of control, and that relates to the requirement to report to this unit.

But it is not the principal control. The principal responsibility, constitutionally, remains with the states. So, if Senator Brown has concerns about what may have happened during the life of the previous government in New South Wales, it is not even a concern which should be levied against Senator Bob Collins; it is a concern which he should raise with the New South Wales government. Any matter to do with the management of forests is a responsibility of the relevant state government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just have no idea.

—Senator Brown interjects that he believes that I have no idea. Senator Brown, we have seen your grasp of legal issues to do with regulations before and some of the extraordinary claims you made about the views of the regulations and ordinances committee, so I really would suggest that you cease to interject on this matter because, unfortunately, your track record on accuracy has not been too good.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I say that there are number of things that Senator Brown has said today that are grossly inaccurate. One of those was that the new monitoring arrangements were self‐regulation and that these companies were going to audit themselves. Of course, Senator Brown is either so ignorant that he did not read the statement issued by Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, and the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, or, having read it, he decided not to bother accurately stating what is in the statement. The announcement, which was made on 31 October, requires that the auditing should be done by an independent person who is a registered company auditor, preferably with expertise in `forest/environmental management auditing', to verify the processes that the exporters have in place and the data on compliance that they provide to the woodchip export monitoring unit.

So rather than the companies auditing themselves—or, rather, our taking the information on trust, which has been the situation hitherto—we are further requiring that there be independent monitoring of the information which is supplied to the unit. Now Senator Brown knew that, or should have known that, because that was in the statement. However, Senator Brown chose to give a completely different story to the Senate. That is a matter for Senator Brown to wrestle with, but I am very disappointed that such a grossly inaccurate picture was presented to the Senate today.

BREAK.PARA: The best thing that we can do is to work with the states to implement regional forest agreements which are based on ecologically sustainable forest management. It is not going to achieve anything to require the Commonwealth to collect a charge in excess of what it is legally required to do. We now have before us the absurdity—the absolute absurdity—of Senator Brown requiring the Commonwealth to collect money which it will have to repay, because that is the situation.

If Senator Brown really thinks that the best thing that the Commonwealth Public Service can do, and the best thing the Attorney‐General's Department can do, is collect money in excess of what they are entitled to collect, and then spend another six months wrestling with how they are going to refund it, and on what basis it is going to be refunded, and then draw up another set of regulations—and no doubt he will come in here and try and disallow those, frothing at the mouth—I am afraid that I disagree with him, because quite frankly it would be a total nonsense to require the Commonwealth to collect money in excess of what it needs and in excess of what it requires.

This is not a debate about appropriations or about the appropriate level of funding—and I think Senator Collins, on the other side, having set up this unit, would recognise that. This is simply a technical debate about whether we are going to require the Commonwealth to collect money in excess of what it is legally entitled to. Senator Collins, when he was minister for primary industries, knew all the complexities of trying to refund money to people who have had money collected in excess of what the Commonwealth was entitled to. Senator Collins would be aware of all the difficulties we had in respect of meat export inspection charges which were in excess of what was necessary—all the difficulty we had in refunding those charges. I would be surprised if Senator Collins now wanted to go through the same exercise when we knew that the level of charge would be in excess of the requirement.

Even those who would say that the Commonwealth should spend more money on this unit would have to accept the fact that this debate cannot change the level of Commonwealth expenditure on the matter. The level of Commonwealth expenditure on the matter has been set in the budget and, therefore, this debate is purely on the technicalities of whether we want to go down this circuitous path.

The whole arrangement was put in place at the recommendation of the woodchip export advisory board, which contains, for Senator Brown's information, officials from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, amongst others. It was decided that we were going to ensure better accountability—that is no reflection on the previous arrangement, Senator Collins—and better transparency by ensuring that the unit reported directly to the minister rather than to the first assistant secretary of the land resources division of the department. Given that the division administers woodchip exports, to ensure that there was better monitoring and transparency of the monitoring, we thought it appropriate that this unit report directly to the minister.

We have implemented the advice of the advisory board, which includes representatives from the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, representatives of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and is chaired by the executive director of the DPIE's agriculture and forest group. So we have done a lot to improve the accountability and the transparency. I say that as no slight on what the previous government did, because I commend Senator Collins on what he has done.

We are requiring the audit to be independent. The auditor can be chosen by the exporter and must be paid for by the exporter, but obviously it has to be notified to the woodchip exports monitoring unit prior to commencing the audit. If there is any problem there, that will be picked up. For those on the other side of the chamber who roll their eyes at the suggestion that the company pay for the auditor, this is the arrangement with all audits in this country which are required by statute. Any audit that is performed is performed by an independent person at the expense of the person or company which is being audited. But it does not mean, of course, that the auditor is in the employ of the company being audited, merely that that is an expense that the company is required by law to meet. That is what is the case here.

So in conclusion, I think it would be extraordinary if the Senate were to require that the Commonwealth collect a charge of 12.6c a tonne when the amount to which the Commonwealth is entitled is only 11.2c a tonne, and then go through the process of refunding 1.4c a tonne on all woodchips collected. If we have to find a mechanism to do that, as Senator Bob Collins and Senator Mal Colston would be aware, that would be an extremely vexing task and another unnecessary burden on the officials of the department who, according to Senator Brown as evidenced before the chamber today, have much better things to do with their time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It grieves me deeply, I must say, not to be able to meet the expectations of Senator O'Chee on this occasion. The opposition will be supporting this motion. Senator O'Chee is absolutely correct in the concern that he has raised in respect of the requirement on the government not to levy a dollar more for a particular purpose than is required for that purpose. Might I say for the benefit of Senator O'Chee that it is that important issue which certainly preoccupied my consideration on this matter. But after consultation with my colleagues, the shadow minister for resources and the shadow minister for the environment, our position is that we will—acknowledging the reality of that problem—be supporting this motion. The reason for that is quite simple.

SPEECH.PARA: I hesitate to speak on behalf of Senator Brown, but I am sure he would concur with what I say—I listened carefully to what he said—in that I do not think that he is suggesting that it is a bad principle that the Commonwealth should not levy beyond the need for the purpose for which the levy is enacted. Senator Brown's argument, in so far as I heard it, is that, from his perspective, that levy is insufficient to meet the needs of the Commonwealth's responsibility in this area. There is a long history attached to this. Senator O'Chee alluded to it, and some of us are very familiar with it. The situation, however, is not quite as simple as Senator O'Chee painted it, saying that forests are managed by state governments and therefore there is no role for the Commonwealth in ensuring that those forests are properly managed in respect of woodchipping. There is one major hole in that argument. I wish it was not there, but it is there. That is that the Commonwealth retains export control powers over woodchips and therefore it is in a position, with a very blunt instrument indeed, to affect forest management practices in so far as they relate to woodchips. It is the Commonwealth, not the states, that issues the licences for that particular forest operation to go on. Therefore, there is in fact a heavy responsibility on the Commonwealth to ensure that the conditions of the licences that it issues as a government are met.

Forest management is the responsibility of the states. One of the great difficulties, which all of us here are aware of, that the former government had in attempting—let me assure you it put a lot of effort into it—to get a rational national forest policy for Australia, which was required, was that the Commonwealth did not have any constitutional responsibility for forest management. I might add—I think this would be an accurate statement—that the former government had no particular desire to be the day-to-day manager of Australian forests. But because of those export controls over this particularly controversial commodity, it had an absolute obligation to ensure that monitoring was carried out correctly.

Because of that history of state forest management, in the past there was a process whereby a very small and hardworking number of Commonwealth officers, I might say in passing, were involved in what almost at times seemed seamless meetings that often went literally around the clock and into the next day, and then into the day after that. I have nothing but the highest regard for the dedication and professionalism of the officers I dealt with in the department. A very high standard of public service was indeed demonstrated by those officers. They were obliged to fundamentally accept the assurances of the actual forest managers—that is, the state government agencies—and their role in real terms because they were not resourced to do anything else. They could not go beyond that.

I found that to be an unsatisfactory situation when I discovered it, as did the former minister for resources. The former government deliberately imposed this levy in order to fund much better resourced direct surveillance because, unfortunately, there are a number of examples—and some of them, I regret to say, are bad ones—where the assurances that were provided by state governments on this matter were not met. Senator Brown has alluded to one of the more dramatic, and I have to say regrettable, occurrences that in fact occurred. So it was necessary for the Commonwealth to have a much better resourced and direct role in monitoring compliance with the conditions that were set on its own licences.

That is really the point here. It is not simply, as Senator O'Chee put, a question of, `Well, state governments do this; we are basically a postbox.' They are our licences and we have to ensure the conditions are met. There was ample evidence, certainly enough to satisfy me in the past, that those conditions were not met. On too many occasions we were not able to adequately check on that independently of the assurances we were given by state forest agencies that everything was okay because we simply were not resourced to do so. That is why this levy was imposed.

The levy is being reduced because of an arrangement that the government entered into with the forest companies that they would do their own independent audits, thereby reducing the workload for the Commonwealth and imposing an extra layer of responsibility, as the government sees it, on the companies. The problem as I see it, without having the opportunity to have that tested, is that I saw enough evidence—and I am not suggesting the majority of these operations are not properly managed, because they are—to indicate that the exceptions were too often and too dramatic. In the past particular companies, as well as state governments, have not done the right thing either. So I think there is a legitimate degree of scepticism here in the Commonwealth parliament about whether these independent audits of the companies are the way to go and whether they will lead to a lesser task for the Commonwealth.

Can I say to the Senate that I have carefully considered this issue. In the last 24 hours I have spent a fair bit of time on it. The actual level of reduction in the levy is small; I think it is less than a cent. In percentage terms it is quite a small reduction, but it is in fact a reduction. It is a change in the levy which in our view is in the wrong way.

The most valid point the government can make in opposing this disallowance motion—and Senator O'Chee made it—is that there is an obligation on the Commonwealth not to in fact levy a greater sum of money than is required for the purpose for which that levy is imposed. It is indeed, and I can attest to this personally, a very messy business being required—as I was when minister on a number of occasions—to repay that levy, simply, apart from anything else, from the point of view of trying to work out an equitable way of repaying it when you have a legal requirement to do so.

I would have thought that the solution for the government, one that we would like to see imposed, is quite simple. It is this: the budget settings of this government are not the Ten Commandments; they were not brought down from Mount Sinai carved in stone. In fact, they can be changed by the government without even coming anywhere near this parliament. I differ with Senator Brown when I say that the current levy is probably sufficient, without going into it in any detail. Perhaps Senate estimates may reveal a different story; in fact, I am sure this matter will be canvassed at Senate estimates. But I suggest to the government, with the greatest respect, that the easiest solution would be simply to vary the budget of the surveillance authority and put what some people would think of as modest resources into surveillance and ensure that the surveillance task that the Commonwealth exercised in fact used the levy that was required. Some people would think that would be an absolute minimum.

BREAK.PARA: In conclusion, can I say that I have no difficulty in concurring with that view. I think it is a regrettable move to make, I might add, in political terms. To be frank—not that I want to offer gratuitous advice to the government, particularly when it is a small amount of money involved—the easiest way the government could remedy this would be by simply agreeing to use the resources raised to improve the degree of surveillance the Commonwealth is offering. Frankly, I do not think the politics of this are good for the government. On those grounds, the opposition will be supporting the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am more than happy to stand and support this motion on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I am certainly not happy with the idea that this licence fee is too much; that we should be reducing it. Indeed, I would like to move on from what Senator Bob Collins has just been saying and suggest that the $88,000 could be put to immediate use either through some additional spot checking—and I will suggest in a moment what the government will find if it does that—or indeed through a public consultation process where there is public advertising of the fact that this monitoring body actually exists, and where there are serious offers of, firstly, submissions and, secondly, a process in each state where those interested in protecting our forests are able to appear before this body and give some of the evidence that I know many of them have amassed.

SPEECH.PARA: After listening to Senator O'Chee, I suggest that he has obviously never spent time in the forests of East Gippsland, particularly, or in other forests, such as the Wombat forest and the forests of Western Australia. If he had, he would see how, unfortunately, we simply cannot trust these companies. For the government to come in here and even suggest that we should leave more of the monitoring up to these companies is an absolute mockery.

I have walked through the Wombat forest, where I acknowledge that woodchipping at the moment has ceased—I do not expect it will always remain that way unfortunately. I saw that they broke almost every rule they could possibly find, from failing to keep adequate stands of timber beside water catchment areas and along the creeks to failing to maintain roads; failing to actually clear up to the point where they were taking only the best sections of the logs; taking them so far above the ground that they actually reduced what they were paying for them; and leaving so much of the crowns and the thinnings on the ground that the local community could no longer have trail rides through the area because horses were stumbling, in one case actually breaking legs on the rubbish that was left on the forest floor.

I acknowledge that finally the previous government stopped chipping in that area. But I have no faith that if we further downgrade the surveillance process and surveillance system, areas such as the Wombat forest will not be logged again, or that the Wombat forest itself will not be opened up again to woodchipping.

The companies that are mining our native forests, that are devastating the habitats of threatened and endangered species and, in particular—I stress that this is happening yet again in East Gippsland—that are ruining our water catchment areas, surely are not the people to be left to look after what they are doing and to see whether they are doing it properly. Indeed, if $88,000 is such a concern, if these companies are running on such a marginal budget, then surely they should just give up woodchipping and get out of it if they are worried about being charged that extra $88,000.

The process we are discussing today is far from adequate, as has already been explained. Surely we should at least have somebody on the ground in each state to randomly check the coupes that are being cut, the way in which they are being cut and whether some of the minimum requirements are being met. I notice on the map that has just been published in East Gippsland the significant areas that have been temporarily put aside along creeks and rivers. But having looked in East Gippsland at what has already been done, I have no faith whatsoever that these 20-metre and 40-metre buffer zones will be met. Here we see that there is not even someone, an independent person, on the ground in East Gippsland on a regular basis—indeed, I understand, on any basis whatsoever—to go out and to look at what is happening.

Last year I witnessed areas that have been cut. Unfortunately, actually getting maps from people to look at which coupes were supposed to be cut—which was extremely difficult—we found that those maps did not line up with what actually had been done and the areas they had got in and cut. It is suggested that some of the trees left are habitat trees. I do not know what they are expecting to actually climb up those trees as a good wind will blow them down, and a possum would be pushing it to get more than a couple of metres off the ground. To suggest that these trees are going to be habitat for a variety of creatures, particularly those that were set aside for the powerful owl not far from the Croajingalong border, is an absolute joke.

Unless we have a better monitoring process, I think the community response to this government's decision will get stronger and stronger. After listening to the rhetoric that has been put out by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and listening to the community concerns voiced to our office in faxes and phone calls, the minister is not fooling anyone. We are clearing, I would estimate, in East Gippsland something like 19 football fields of forest a day. In 20 years, on the government's own admission, we will have basically clear‐felled half the remaining forests in East Gippsland. What we are doing is pushing towards the probable extinction in that area of the tiger quoll, the spotted tiger quoll, the sooty owl, the masked owl and the powerful owl.

This government, and particularly Senator O'Chee, can come in here and say, `We can push the ball back to the state governments. They will look after it.' Unfortunately, the records of the Victorian and Tasmanian governments are absolutely appalling, as is that of the Western Australian government. We cannot leave them to do it. The Commonwealth has not just the export controls on woodchip licences; surely it has to recognise, Senator O'Chee, that it has some responsibility for World Heritage. To suggest that we can simply put our hands up here in this place and say, `Look, sorry, we can pass that all back to the state governments' is an old and tried method that simply no-one will be fooled by.

I conclude by saying that the additional money collected can be spent in a range of ways and, indeed, urgently needs to be spent. The amount of money should be increased threefold, not decreased in any way whatsoever. The process of monitoring needs to be opened up to public consultation so that those groups and organisations which really do have some accurate information, which have put together maps of what is happening and which have the photos to show the damage that is occurring can be involved in the monitoring process. To suggest that, with the increase in the rate of cutting and the increase in the areas which can be cut in East Gippsland, we need to decrease the pittance these companies are paying is an absolute disgrace. I support Senator Brown's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Brown's motion, not necessarily for the same purpose that Senator Brown has moved it but I certainly agree with the importance that he has placed upon a regulation which provides funding for a monitoring service. My personal view, quite frankly, is that the monitoring unit never worked, because it never had sufficient funding to start with. Of course we, when in government, put it in place. But that is my view.

SPEECH.PARA: I think my view has been supported by the failure to actually carry out prosecutions of severe breaches that have occurred in forest activities since the introduction of the woodchip export monitoring unit. As Senator Bob Collins said, the Commonwealth does have a responsibility because the Commonwealth does issue the licences. It has a responsibility to ensure that the product exported under those licences is legitimate for all intents and purposes.

Senator O'Chee said states have responsibility for the management of the state forests. True, they do. But, unfortunately for many states, particularly Tasmania, Victoria, maybe New South Wales and, probably to a lesser extent, Western Australia—and I will focus on my own state—the state forest agency has got itself into a predicament with regard to its own funding. It has to rely very heavily on the volume turnover of wood to actually meet the state government's requirements of a return from the operation it runs. Therefore, woodchip exports are very important in terms of providing revenue.

As I said, they have got themselves caught in a trap. They cannot monitor, do not monitor and for many years have not been able to monitor. Indeed, some legislation at a state level actually precludes them from monitoring. I will just quickly refer to one concessional arrangement in Tasmania that existed, the ANM concession. Even though it was a public forest, a crown forest, forestry was not even allowed into that concession without the permission of the company that had been granted it under state legislation.

My purpose for supporting this motion is that I believe we should have a total focus on utilisation and downstream processing in this country. That is something the government has said. Indeed the government has accused us of being the woodchip export champions of the world. I can remember the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) making many statements about how they would change things, about how they were jobs driven, about how they would put in place regulations that were more equitable but would lead to greater downstream processing in this country.

When we debated the other regulations, including this one, when the regulations were changed, they were disallowed in the House of Representatives. The old regulations that operated under our government were changed and the new ones were brought in. All of those regulations, bar maybe one or two, actually weakened the provision for sourcing for woodchips.

Australia is a big country and there are many forests to get around. In most cases, the first point a woodchip export monitoring unit will go to for information about where forest activities are occurring is the state forest agency. The state forest agency, in general, has an agreement with most companies that it will advise them of any inspections to be conducted.

There may be some safety requirements that they will use as an excuse, so the woodchip export monitoring unit never got on the front foot. It was always on the back foot. It never really conducted any random inspections where it could actually prove or see first hand exactly what was going on. Rather, it always got a manicured approach when it went out to visit any specific coupes, if it ever did. It always got the manicured tour. Therefore, it failed, and it will continue to fail regardless of what funding it has.

At the end of the day, we have to drive industry development in this country in what is one of the most important resource based industries that we have because we have an increasing trade deficit with regard to wood product. We all know that, so we all ought to be trying to do something about turning that around. The forest industry is going to exist. As I said, it is a most important industry in this country, but we have to drive the engine for change to utilise more of the wood that we take from our forests in this country.

Tim Fischer put out his trade statement, as I said, focused on jobs. According to what the Australian says today, in terms of a global sense our trade as a share of the global trade is actually declining. When you look at the converse of that, in terms of wood products we have an increasing import problem. We ought to be trying to do something about that. I would urge the government to take on board what Senator Bob Collins said with regard to the utilisation of the funds. In fact, I would like to see the funds increased threefold because right now there are real problems with regard to adherence to the requirements for the sourcing of wood.

I know that with many of these issues it is difficult to be across them all. There is the independent audit, or the self‐audit, by companies. It is really a self‐audit because, essentially, under the regulations they are required to provide information about where they sourced certain wood from and what volumes they sourced. Once it is turned into woodchips, it is very difficult for the Inspector Clouseaus of the woodchip export monitoring unit to go down and determine which chip came from where and from what log because a chip is a chip and it is on the pile.

So, in essence, whoever does the audit of the company's information provider has to accept at face value that it is reasonably accurate. Moreover, they do not have much choice because they cannot really prove to the contrary. The only way they can do that is to get out in the field and see whether or not there are breaches. All the woodchip export monitoring unit can do is see whether or not there are actual breaches in harvesting activities. It cannot do anything other than that.

I just want to refer to how bad it really is in Tasmania's case so far as the state agency is concerned, the manager of the public forests in Tasmania and, indeed, in any other state. We know that sawlogs in Tasmania are being woodchipped in huge volumes. It is acknowledged—indeed it was acknowledged in a court proceeding most recently by the state agency in Tasmania. I have a view that, if the government and we are all committed to more jobs in this country, we ought to be trying to do something about that.

There are many ways in which the government can spend money to actually get a focus for this industry that will make it export orientated. No sawmilling operation in Tasmania has a real export focus. There was a case recently where a developer proposed to the state a development which would have been totally export oriented and which related to sawmilled, processed, hard solid timber. Yet it could not get off the ground because in Tasmania a cartel exists of the major woodchipping companies and one or two major sawmillers.

We have to change that. If governments have a responsibility, they have a responsibility to ensure that public resources like forests are maximised in the interests of the public. We must take whatever steps we can to ensure that. Where it can be clearly indicated that we can do better, then government—and the Commonwealth in this case in dealing with export woodchipping licences—has a responsibility to take whatever steps it can and which are necessary to put in place mechanisms that will ensure that you maxi mise the benefit. Otherwise, all of the rhetoric about jobs and improved export driven markets or export operations with regards to resource based industries is just rubbish; it is just rhetoric.

I think the Australian public do have a concern about our forest industries. Our paper industry, for instance, is in decline. I just cannot see how it can continue to survive unless we have major pulp mill developments in this country. Therefore, we ought to be very clearly looking at it and taking the approach that we need to drive something to happen.

It will not happen from our major exporters of woodchips. North and Boral have a view, which is fine for them from a company point of view, that they want to make as much money as they can from woodchips. There is a lot of money to be made from woodchips. There is no doubt about that. But we will not get the sort of downstream processing development that we need if we do not take steps to put in place regulations and requirements that will lead us to greater development and downstream processing.

I really appeal to Senators Harradine and Colston. Even though this is really an itsy‐bitsy issue in so far as it is one regulation relating to the export of woodchips, it is a very tiny step or a holding of the line in the right direction. What we need to consider longer term is to get more information—and it is available—before the parliament that will clearly identify that we are not doing enough, that we are not being successful enough in terms of downstream processing of a very important natural resource that could provide so much more economic benefit to this country and so many more jobs for people, particularly in regional Australia. We really need to take greater steps to achieve those sorts of objectives.

For that reason, I think we must hold the line on the funding for the woodchip export monitoring unit. As useless as it might be, it is something we should maintain at least. We should try to get it greater independence so that it can function better because, as I said earlier, this is a big country. There are hundreds and hundreds of coupes, if not thou sands of coupes, being cut at any one time. It is an almost impossible task for any group. As Senator Bob Collins rightly pointed out earlier, officers are dedicated, but they are totally underresourced, totally underfunded and have a task that is almost impossible to do and can only be done in a piecemeal way. That being the case though, it should still be done.

We asked questions before on other regulations that relate to sourcing. I would suggest to the Greens and the Democrats, as I have done to Senator Colston and to my own colleagues, that at the end of the day the only real way you will fix this problem, if a government is not prepared to take the necessary steps, is to change the Export Control Act. That will relate to where wood is sourced for export woodchips. If you place a criterion in the act, then you do not have a problem. That ultimately may well be the step that will have to be taken to fix this problem and actually get a focus for downstream processing in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to strongly support the motion of Senator Brown and those who have spoken already. I just want to make one short remark and that is that I believe the government's argument for rejection of this motion is spurious in the extreme. It is spurious for one primary reason that was well spelt out by Senator Bob Collins. It is that this WEMU unit does not meet the needs for which it was established, does not do the job for which it was established, and it is up to the government to gather as much money as possible to make it an effective working unit. In those circumstances, it is impossible for any payer of those levies to demand of the government any refund whatsoever because they know that that unit needs far more funds than it is getting to do the job under the circumstances for which it was set up.

SPEECH.PARA: I would urge the government not to be macho and bullyboyish in this instance but to recognise the validity of the argument, which was very carefully crafted and very well expressed, and accept it and do something about improving this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators looked back at the Hansard , they would find that, via Senate estimates questions largely and other questions on notice, many of the questions that originally resulted in the public conclusion that there was not anybody who actually monitored Commonwealth woodchip licence conditions were asked by my former colleague Senator Chamarette. I think it was the case that there even were some people within the Commonwealth who believed that someone was looking at export licence conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: But, funnily enough, when those questions were asked initially about who was monitoring export licence conditions, we were shunted off to the states by the Commonwealth saying, `They are the ones that look after forests.' When questions were asked to the state bodies through our state parliamentarians, we were once again shunted off. The states said, `We look after certain environmental criteria, but these are Commonwealth licences. It is not within our ambit to monitor Commonwealth licence conditions.' So they shunted us back to the Commonwealth. The questions went backwards and forwards until it was inevitable that somebody realised that nobody was monitoring Commonwealth licence conditions.

There was no point in people crowing about how wonderful the conditions were on Commonwealth woodchip licences when there was nobody to monitor them. Hence, I guess it was inevitable that WEMU was set up. I will not say that was the only influence, because many community groups were saying similar things. But it helped that those questions and answers came through at the federal parliamentary level.

However, the response from Senator O'Chee today certainly indicated the government's lack of understanding in terms of what people would think is a reasonable requirement for the Commonwealth to monitor its own licence conditions; that is, that an auditor approved or paid for by a company somehow or other would be an acceptable body to monitor Commonwealth licence conditions. WEMU has not been around all that long, and I wonder whether the Common wealth Auditor-General has even had the opportunity of doing an audit. That would be very interesting. When you look at the goals of a particular unit like WEMU, if the resources that have been allocated are insufficient or if they are not being used in a way that actually meets those goals, then it would be a very useful thing to have that particular body audited.

I would urge the government to take up that suggestion—or perhaps I can make the suggestion if they feel that auditing is going to be effective and efficient in this particular arena—for the Commonwealth Auditor-General to look at WEMU and see whether the pathetically small amount of resources are being used effectively to achieve the goals of monitoring Commonwealth export licence conditions. I would be fairly certain that it would hardly be seen to be effective to be underspending in such a small budget if the goals of that particular unit were to monitor federal licence conditions.

The reason we know this—I certainly know it in Western Australia—is that community groups have had firm evidence about breaches in licence conditions, but there was no acknowledged understanding of those breaches at the Commonwealth level. There seemed to be a real slip between cup and mouth and there seemed to be the necessity to believe, even at that stage, what the companies were saying.

When the first reports came out, there seemed to be an absolute requirement for the very poorly resourced unit to believe what the company said. If you ask a company, `Have you breached your licence conditions?' then what do you expect them to say? What do you expect a company appointed and paid auditor to say about a company's licence conditions? How much information will they receive? They will receive the written information that is given to them by the company. Is the company going to provide to the auditor information about breaches in their own licence conditions? I hardly think so.

Therefore, we have to start thinking about matching the rhetoric with reality; that is, if people are concerned that the community do not have a good idea about how wonderful the industry is in maintaining their high standards of environmental excellence and in maintaining their licence conditions, then that needs to be proved. I have heard Senator Newman say on numerous occasions that the only way in which people can have confidence in our social security system is if we get the cheats and, in those instances, I see everybody on that side saying yes, even if they are technical breaches. Does she come down heavily on those people? Yes, she does, even if it means them starving.

But what happens with corporate cheats? The answer is nothing. When was the last prosecution for a breach? When was the last large corporation required to lose its licence? When was the last action that took place due to these corporate breaches which are probably worth hundreds of millions of dollars overall? What happens to these people; what is the real impact on the ecosystem; and what is the real impact on the community?

The kind of impact it would have on the community was shown in the example that Senator Brown gave of the people who put their life savings into a piece of land to preserve it for the future because they believed in that but who found that the company not only logged their property but also offered them royalties—royalties which most of us in the conservation movement think are totally inadequate—for the loss of that irreplaceable resource.

In the strongest possible words I would support this motion. It is petty minded, in my belief, to act in this way: to suggest that it is an over‐collection, when in fact it is an underspending, is an indictment of the government. I think there is time now for them to reassess the situation and to start doing the heavy work that is required to rebuild any semblance of public confidence in this process.
