—I am still behaving myself but they have not changed. They are both well‐known merchants of misinformation.
—Order! The minister has the call. If other senators wish to make a comment, they may do so after the minister finishes his contribution.
—Perhaps he should be a little less provocative and abusive.

—Mr Deputy President, I am never provocative. I am just stating the facts. I want to remind the Senate of the true role of the Labor Party in this appalling affair. In the late 1980s the Hindmarsh Island bridge was proposed by Binalong Pty Ltd, a company owned by Tom and Wendy Chapman. The South Australian government later assumed the responsibility to build the bridge, with Binalong to pay half the cost. In December 1993, some members of the Ngarrindjeri people, the applicant women, applied for a protection order under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 to prevent the building of the Hindmarsh Island bridge. In July 1994, Professor Cheryl Saunders provided a report to former Minister Tickner stating the Hindmarsh Island bridge area was a sacred site to the Ngarrindjeri people. Former minister Tickner granted a 25‐year protection order over the Hindmarsh Island bridge area.

BREAK.PARA: In February 1995, the Federal Court quashed the protection order. It held that the minister had failed to follow the due process of the heritage protection act by not personally reading what is generally known as secret women's business. This decision was later affirmed by the full bench of the Federal Court.

In December 1995, a South Australian royal commission found that the secret women's business was a fabrication. This finding was supported by the view of some of the Ngarrindjeri women—the dissident women—who maintained that there was no secret women's business associated with Hindmarsh Island. A new application under the heritage protection act was made by the applicant Ngarrindjeri women. Justice Jane Mathews was appointed to prepare a report into this new application and in June last year Justice Mathews submitted her report. In September the High Court invalidated the appointment of Justice Mathews.

In all, we have had four inquiries or royal commissions. We have seen over $4 million of public money poured into those inquiries. That money has been totally wasted—nothing has occurred as a result of that expenditure. That has been a direct result of the previous Labor government. They wasted that money. It is an example of the incompetence of those people and I am happy to demonstrate that to Senator Bob Collins now. It is a long and sorry tale and one that they should be deeply ashamed of.

When we came to government the Hindmarsh Island mess was just one of many we inherited from Labor and it is one we have sought to clean up. You would think that the Labor Party would have some remorse to at least assist in the clean up. But, no, instead, they are in here obstructing us, opposing every effort to clean this expensive mess up.

I also said yesterday that they are a laughing stock in the public area because of their handling of this issue. You would think that they would have woken up to the fact that the Hindmarsh Island affair was a big nail in their political coffin at the last election. It is obvious that they have not learnt anything from that sorry saga. Now, after creating this expensive mess, what is their response? It is to insist that we either accept an amendment that will almost certainly guarantee years of litigation, delay and public expenditure or leave things alone and let nature take its course. That will also guarantee more public expense, more delays and, in all probability, more litigation.

The Hindmarsh Island Bridge is an albatross around Labor's neck and, in a political sense, the longer it hangs there—and by their behaviour today it is obvious that it will—it will be like a stinking carcass on them, and so be it. If that is what they want to wear, I am happy for them to wear it. If they insist on going down the track they are on, then let it be on their heads. Let the Australian public have no delusions about it. The Labor Party has already wasted $4 million of taxpayers' money on this issue and now wants to waste up to another million dollars. Let us not forget that of the four inquiries already held, three determined that the bridge should proceed and the one that found otherwise was overturned on appeal.

Let us deal with the nonsense put forward by Labor both yesterday morning and in an ill‐informed and misdirected outburst by Senator Bolkus last night. Senator Bolkus rather foolishly assumed that the legal advice that I referred to was in relation to the nonsense he raised about the constitutional validity of this bill. He was wrong, and I pointed that out last night. The additional advice I sought was in relation to the opposition's amendment, which I note is worded differently than the proposed amendment raised by Labor in the other place.

I am happy to release that legal advice, Senator Bolkus, which made it perfectly clear that your amendments, as I said yesterday, will only invite further litigation, tying things up for goodness knows how long and costing taxpayers more money. I also note that yesterday Senator Collins and Senator Kernot became excited when I told the Senate that Father Frank Brennan—

TALK.START.PARA: —A spurious argument.

—You said it yesterday. I quote from yesterday's Hansard —that Father Frank Brennan `had indicated that any short, sharp section 10 report would be a sham'. Let me quote what Senator Collins said yesterday, and I think he has the grace to withdraw once he has had a chance to read the Hansard —I hope he has. When I said that Father Brennan said it was a sham, he said, `Did he say that? I bet he didn't.' It is in the Hansard of yesterday, Senator Collins. That is what you said: `I bet he didn't.'
—I bet he didn't say—
—I will quote from what he said. Did I hear you say that he did not say that?
—Senator Herron, once you leave the script, you're hopeless. Why don't you just get back to the script?
—Did he say that, Senator Collins? Did he say that?
—With all your bombastic bluster, I don't know what you're talking about.
—I did not think you did. You do not understand it.
—Order! All comments will go through the chair.
—Mr Chairman, I will quote from page 39 of the Hansard of the legal and constitutional affairs hearing:

BREAK.PARA: CHAIR —With the short inquiry that you suggested, there is the prospect that it could be seen as a sham in view of the fact that it is all predetermined. Would you agree with that?
Father Brennan —Oh, yes, particularly given the strength of the things the minister has said.
So, Senator Collins, so much for your bombast yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not what you said.
—Is that not an invitation for litigation?
—Stick to the script.
—Order! I have asked honourable senators on my left to allow the minister to make his comments. If you wish to make comments later, you may do so after he has finished his comments.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order on your ruling. With the greatest respect, and I have the greatest respect for the chair, the minister in fact is being, I have to say, unusually offensive and provocative this morning. If he was a little more temperate in his delivery he would get no interjections from this side whatsoever. In fact, I am anxious to hear his arguments.
—Irrespective of what the minister is doing, I expect senators on my left not to interject.

—Is that not an invitation for litigation if we were to have a short, sharp inquiry? We have got the proponent of it saying, yes, it is a sham, particularly given the strength of the things the minister said. It highlights the fact that neither Senator Collins nor Senator Kernot has even bothered to read the Hansard .
—What's the page number?

—Thirty‐nine. I also note that Senator Collins repeatedly made the point that he is not a lawyer and is therefore quite possibly wrong in his assertions. It is a frequent assertion of Senator Collins. I would suggest that Senator Collins did that to cover himself because he knows full well that the arguments he has been putting forward are spurious nonsense. As for the constitutional argument, it is just so much hot air. In fact, if you applied the very same argument to last year's ATSIC amendment bill, which removed the right to elect a chairman and instead allowed for appointment of a chairman, you would find that Labor voted against the very principle that they now espouse. And there are other examples.
—Are you seriously suggesting that's a good—

—There are other examples. You did. Section 51 of the constitution gives the Commonwealth the power to make laws with respect to the people of any race for whom it deems it necessary to make special laws. The power of the Commonwealth to enact the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill comes from section 51 of the constitution. Senator Bolkus's claim that the power in its application to indigenous people is restrict ed to making laws for the benefit of indigenous people is simply incorrect.
—How do you explain it away?
—I will. The hollowness of Senator Bolkus's claim is apparent from the fact—
—You left a key bit out of Father Brennan's quote.
—I am happy to read that, but it was the sham aspect, Senator Collins.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I don't know why you don't recognise this side of the parliament.
—I beg your pardon?
—I have been up here for about 30 seconds trying to get your call, Mr Chairman.
—What did you say?
—I said that you didn't recognise this side of the parliament.
—That is not what you said. You said—

—That is right. I do not know why. If you find it offensive, I will withdraw it. My point of order is that Senator Herron has misled the parliament by quoting only one part of Father Frank Brennan's comment on page 39 of Hansard . Father Brennan also made it clear that this legislation could also be seen to be a sham as well. I think, for the purposes of not being provocative in this debate and for trying to get this debate back on the rails, he should—
—Mr Chairman, on the point of order: Senator Bolkus is out of order. Under what section of the standing orders is Senator Bolkus attempting to raise a point of order?
—Senator Harradine, you have probably come in about 10 seconds before I would have. I indicate that there is no point of order.
—That is a very selective piece of quotation, Minister.

—It was in relation to the sham; that is all. I could have gone on quoting forever, because there are many more quotes. You said that he never said that a short, sharp bill was a sham. You said that you would bet on it. He did.
—We will give you the full quote from Frank Brennan in a moment.

—It is available in the Hansard . I come back to Senator Bolkus's claim. The hollowness of Senator Bolkus's claim is apparent from the fact that the Labor Party, when it was in government, made laws reducing the rights of Aboriginals under the Land Rights Act by introducing a sunset clause on land claims and restricting the veto over mining, presumably using the same constitutional power. Those amendments, like these, were based on the fact that special measures can be amended from time to time in the light of changed circumstances. This can include qualifying them or rolling them back, as indeed is contemplated under the Racial Discrimination Act and the international convention, which envisages that special measures shall be temporary, not permanent. Additionally, in the advice received from the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney-General's Department on 27 November—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken this honourable minister to task on previous occasions for his continued habit in here of attempting to mislead this Senate by his selective quoting of our nation's newspapers.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I regard that as offensive and a slur on my integrity. I have not attempted to do anything.
—It does not matter. I will withdraw.

—I am not sure that I would have asked you to withdraw. I think it is a debating point. I regret that I was speaking to a temporary chairman of committees at the time. I would not have asked you to withdraw.

—Those who know Frank Brennan personally will recognise this when they hear the full quote and the very important qualification that he put on this. I am indebted to my colleague Senator Bolkus for pointing this out. They will know the irony with which Frank Brennan often embellishes his comments. Let us hear the full quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Oh yes, particularly given the strength of the things the minister has said. But I think we are almost at the stage where anything done will be a sham, aren't we, including this legislation?

What Father Brennan was saying in terms of the full quote was, `Yes, there are ways of concluding this matter and complying with the Heritage Protection Act, and this is one that I am proposing. However, this legislation is a sham.' It is. The minister deliberately sought to quote the whole of that paragraph with the exception of those last three very important lines. It is a habit that he gets into very often. We have to pick him up on it very often.

Another thing needs to be said. In terms of the particularly offensive manner in which the minister has charged into this parliament this morning, we who were here yesterday have all noted during it the dramatic comparison between this and yesterday. The reason I make that point is that I want to say to the Senate something I said to a colleague after the debate yesterday and got agreement on. We have made a lot of excuses for this minister because he is a decent person. He is someone—I happily say it now—I personally like. We have made a lot of excuses. However, it is now close to 12 months on. The minister has been in this portfolio for a year. The cold, hard facts, as disagreeable as you might find them, are that in real terms this minister has as much a grasp of this portfolio now as he had on day one, and that is none at all.

All the minister can demonstrate—he has done it again in here—is that he is capable of reading a script. He had a full phalanx of advisers in the advisers box in with him yesterday, but he was so unsure of his arguments. As Senator Bolkus said yesterday afternoon in here, he was so completely nonplussed when perfectly reasonable questions were asked. The minister said to Senator Bolkus and other senators in here that he had to adjourn this bill for 24 hours to get legal advice about whether he could accept the amendment I moved here in the parliament yesterday.

Senator Herron took significant exception to the suggestion made by Senator Bolkus that it was also deficient not to have sought advice from the heads of power on which this legislation relies. Senator Herron rejected that and said, `No. That is not correct. I am only asking to defer this bill for 24 hours to give consideration to whether this amendment can be accepted by the government.' I point out to the honourable minister that this amendment was moved in the House of Representatives on 5 November last year—three months ago—by the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. Three months ago, the opposition put up in lights in the most obvious way we could that we would be moving this amendment in the Senate. If we moved it in the House of Representatives, of course we would move it here in similar terms. We have, despite the fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —And canvassed at length.

—Exactly. The arguments supporting it were canvassed at length. The minister talks about referring to the Hansard . It would not hurt him if he did occasionally. He has so few pieces of legislation to administer in this portfolio that it is just appalling that he cannot get across the few he has.

SPEECH.PARA: You had three months notice, Minister, that this amendment would be moved. That was something I commented on when talking to my colleagues. Despite the fact that you had three months notice, you were totally unable to respond to this amendment and we had to have the debate deferred for 24 hours so you could check on this. You talk about checking the Hansard.

In terms of shams, Minister, I have a few questions to ask about the options that might be available to you. This is an obnoxious piece of legislation. Senator Harradine correctly referred yesterday to a short additional comment by Senator Cooney on why the Senate should not pass this bill. I agree with what Senator Harradine said about this dis senting report. This is as succinct, as cogent and as well written a dissenting report as I have ever seen in a Senate committee report. I noted that at the time I read it and I mentioned that to Senator Cooney.

This is an indication of why Senator Cooney had as distinguished a career at the Melbourne bar as he has had in the Senate. Because it is so short—and I agree with what Senator Harradine said—and in the face of Senator Herron's bluster and technical legal arguments, I will quote this report because there are some matters of real justice that require this bill not to be supported. Senator Cooney put it better than I have seen anybody put it so far.

I know that Senator Herron is going to be giving A‐G's advice about black letter law. I will have a fair bit more to say about that now. I actually wanted this matter to be wrapped up in 10 minutes, but because of the way you behaved this morning there are a number of things that you have said that now need to be responded to before this debate concludes—and they will be. I was hoping that it was going to be a short debate, but it is not going to be.

There is black letter law, Senator Herron. As I said yesterday—and I did not say this to cover me or anything else—I am not a lawyer, but I am very familiar with the law. Over the years there have been many cases where courts have properly construed black letter law to the great distress of the judges who were doing it.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made a very silly statement about these issues on radio earlier this year when talking about the Wik decision. He said, `Judges do not make laws; parliaments do.' What a piece of factual nonsense. Judges have been making laws for hundreds of years. Whilst I may on occasions—and this is open to me to do, as it is for every other citizen in society to do—disagree with the way in which judges have made law, I say without hesitation, `Thank God they do.' On many occasions, the community at large has been the beneficiary of the law making—particularly in the area of natural justice—that the judges have engaged in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes they haven't.

—I agree, Senator Harradine, that sometimes they have not. Sometimes I disagree with the law that judges make. What I was going to go on to say, Senator Harradine, is that there has been enormous development over the years in the area of natural justice. Most of it has been made by judges and not by parliaments. At the end of the day, judges like to bring down decisions that are just in real terms as well as comply with black letter law. I will quote what Senator Cooney had to say about this. He stated:

BREAK.PARA: This bill should not be passed because the benefits to be gained by doing so are outweighed by the harm its enactment will cause. The government seeks to bring a matter to do with the Hindmarsh Bridge to an expeditious and inexpensive conclusion. To do so, it has introduced legislation which, if passed, is likely to prejudice the rule of law, may breach the Racial Discrimination Act, be reasonably seen by people, including many Aborigines, as in fact doing so, and gives one side to a dispute an advantage over the other.

These issues could and should be avoided by letting the law as it now is run its course. No legal or legal like proceedings to do with persons involved in the matter of the Hindmarsh Bridge are now extant. However, there have been proceedings undertaken with the understanding that the law relevant to them would not change before the issues involved in them had finally been resolved. That is not the case. There is still contention over the status of land which will be affected by the building of the Hindmarsh Bridge.

In the past, government has legislated in a way which has affected legal proceedings then imminent or in fact taking place. This is an unhappy precedent. It should not be followed. The rule of law is an instrument essential to the doing of justice, to the vindication of rights and to the restraint of arbitrary power. To change a law because of the perceived need for expedition and money saving is to pursue an unhealthy course. To do so in a way that will give one group of people an advantage over another becomes a significant risk to the legal framework of our society. Different legal minds have come to contrary opinions as to whether the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill if passed would contravene the Racial Discrimination Act. Given that there is a solution to the Hindmarsh Bridge issue other than this legislation, and given that a range of reasonable and learned people hold a strong belief that it contravenes the Racial Discrimination Act, this bill should not be passed.

I do not think there is a better argument than that for why this bill should not pass the committee stage let alone the Senate. I would like the minister, on behalf of the people that he is supposed to represent in this chamber and as Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—not the Attorney-General—to address the case put by Senator Cooney.

I want to put a number of questions to you, Minister, about your powers under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Heritage Protection Act—a copy of which I have here. Is it a fact that, under this act, it is open to you whether or not you issue a declaration for the protection of an area having properly followed the processes of the act? Is it a fact that indeed there is ample precedent for your predecessors declining to do so? Is it also a fact that, under the provisions of this act, even after having issued such a declaration it is open to you to vary or revoke it at any time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again: selective quotation. I forgive Senator Bolkus for this selective quotation, because he was not in the chamber. Senator Bolkus is preoccupied.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins then. Senator Collins misquoted. What I said yesterday was this: `The reason for moving this motion'—the delay motion—`is that I am seeking further legal advice in relation to the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill 1996.' I asked that it be postponed. I did not say anything about 24 hours. I said nothing about that, Senator Collins. I asked that it be postponed because I took you in good faith. I took Senator Bolkus in good faith. It appears that that is not the way in which you take me.

SPEECH.PARA: Advice received from the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney‐General's Department of 27 November was tabled at the Senate committee hearings. I remind Senator Collins of the recommendations of the majority report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The majority report was that they considered the bill as necessary to facilitate the construction of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge and that action should be taken now to remove the impediment to its construction caused by the heritage protection act. So there is no doubt about the majority opinion. I will come to Senator Cooney's opinion. Like Senator Collins I have a great respect for Senator Cooney and I will answer that in a moment. Referring back to Senator Bolkus's statement, in the advice received from the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney‐General's Department of 27 November which was tabled at the Senate committee hearings he indicated that there was no basis, particularly constitutional, on which a court could invalidate the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill once it was passed. This bill has been through all the normal checks and balances, including the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. Never at any stage did I say that it had not, and I am just reinforcing that.

I do not recall anyone, including Senator Bolkus, raising the question of the constitutional basis for the bill at the committee's hearings. He never did. Suddenly it was trotted out yesterday that there was some constitutional impediment. You had ample opportunity, Senator Bolkus, during the legal and constitutional committee's hearings, but you never brought that up at all. Not a whisper. Then you came in here yesterday as if it was some great revelation. As I said, it is hot air in a paper bag. It had no validity, and I was told that yesterday and I am reinforcing it now. It had no validity whatsoever. Indeed, neither the majority nor the minority report raised any such questions—you had every opportunity to do that—nor did the opposition raise that question in debate in the other place.
The Attorney‐General's Department has confirmed that the Commonwealth has the power to pass the bill under subsection 51(xxvi) of the constitution. It has the ability to pass it.

Coming to Senator Cooney's statement on his legal opinion, his very erudite legal opinion—I hold Senator Cooney in very high respect, as we all do in this chamber—I will respond with this. The Chief General Counsel of the Attorney‐General's Department—I am happy to produce this—said:
You asked me on 5 February on behalf of your Minister for urgent advice on the following questions concerning the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill.
1. If the Bill as proposed is enacted, would it be subject to challenge on the grounds of inconsistency with the Racial Discrimination Act?
Answer:

No. The Bill in my opinion, as I have previously advised, is not inconsistent with the RDA. As a later Act, the Bill once enacted will prevail in any event over the RDA, hence there will be no basis for a challenge to the Bill once enacted on RDA grounds. (WA v. Commonwealth (1995) 183 CLR 373 at 483‐4).
2. If the opposition amendment were included—
and this is your point, Senator Collins—
(to make the bill subject to the RDA) would the possibility of such a challenge be increased?
Is that the point, Senator Collins?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet. You are getting nearer.
—Answer:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes. Such an amendment could encourage a legal challenge to be brought which would require a Court to examine and pronounce on whether the amended Bill as enacted was in fact consistent with the RDA.
I touched on this issue in evidence I gave to the Senate Committee examining this Bill last year (pp 87, 89).

I think it should be obvious that those opposite do not have a feather to fly with. Their arguments have been exposed for the sham that they are. I am happy to have had the opportunity to expose them. I accepted them in good faith yesterday. I have checked it again; it has been rechecked. I have read the result out to you. There is not a feather to fly with.

I just cannot believe the politics of it as well. Those on the other side cost the taxpayers over $4 million over this issue and now from opposition they seem hell‐bent on wasting more public money on it—and time, more importantly.

On that subject, I am sorry Senator Kernot is not here, because she raised the subject yesterday and I think she probably has more consideration for this matter than do those opposite, because they are the ones that blew that $4 million. If this bill is obstructed today and defeated—and the answer to your question, Senator Collins, was yes, obviously; that is fairly obvious—and I am forced to appoint another reporter, which is the outcome you suggested yourself, Senator Collins, and spend another million dollars—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just support our amendment. We are not suggesting you do that.
—I pointed out to you, Senator Collins, that if we support that amendment as the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney‐General's Department—
—It might work.
—It might! Did you catch that, Mr Chairman? It might work!
—Yes.

—It might work! We are back into the legal jungle again. It might work. It might not work, also. It might or might not work. I am saying that if we pass the amendment the bill can proceed. You do not accept that. That is where we differ. If we accept your amendment it might or might not work. We want to introduce finality into the argument. You have just exposed the shallowness of your own argument. It might work. It might work, Senator Harradine. That is what he is saying to us.
—It may actually—
—Is it `may work' now? We have changed from `might' to `may'. It may work, it may not work. It might work, it might not work. Here we go again.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to get back to Senator Kernot. Senator Kernot said, `Why not appoint another reporter? Why not go back?' That is what the opposition is suggesting. Will we spend another million dollars? Do you know where that million dollars comes from, Senator Collins?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not going to cost a million dollars, Senator.
—It comes from the ATSIC budget
—Your figure is spurious, Senator.
—Yours cost $4 million. Are you suggesting that the price of legal advice and expert advice has gone down?
—Order! Comments should be made through the chair.

—I apologise, Mr Chairman. I want to point out that, if another reporter gets appointed, that comes out of ATSIC expenditure. That is what that suggestion does. ATSIC will have to find the money for a fifth inquiry. That will mean taking money that could have been spent on housing, education, health, sewerage, training—any of a number of essential services. Are the Democrats willing to share that responsibility with the Labor Party? I think not.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are pretty simple. Labor has made a huge mess of this issue. They are making a further mess of this issue. I would strongly urge them to accept that, to cut their losses and to support the government legislation. If they do not, I will be happy to go out and expose their fraud to the Australian public. It has already been exposed. You would think they would learn something. It is no wonder they are going to be in opposition for a long time. They have not learnt anything from this sorry saga of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge affair. We are coming in and trying to clean it up for them and for the Australian public—because at the bottom line it is taxpayers' money that is going towards this.

If we do not pass this bill, we end up back where we started. As Senator Collins said—he was quite right—Labor's amendment might do something; it might not. He is right. It will not produce finality. In relation to the legal advice that we obtained, I will again quote from the Chief General Counsel. I am pleased that Senator Cooney is here. He would accept, I am sure, the integrity of the Chief General Counsel, the integrity of the opinion of the Attorney‐General's Department. When asked whether, if the bill as proposed were enacted, it would be subject to challenge on the grounds of inconsistency with the Racial Discrimination Act, The Chief General Counsel's opinion was `No'.

Let's get on with it. Senator Collins said that he wanted to get this over with in 10 minutes. I am happy to proceed to a ballot on this matter. Those opposite are obviously not going to change their position. They will not listen to logic. I am trying to help them, in a political sense—and I find that going a bit against the grain after all these years. That is not my role.

Having done that yesterday, I get attacked for it: I am incompetent, I have not got on top of the portfolio, or something along those lines. That really got me. You are saying that I am incompetent. What about what occurred in the past? Why did we get into this imbroglio? It was because of my predecessor—and you are jumping up and down about me. I will stack my record against his, so don't come at that. If that is the basis of your debate, you have got nothing to run with. I am happy to stand on my record to date.
Let's get on with it. Let's get the ballot over with. I have responded to all the matters put to me. Let's bring on the ballot and get it over with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I found an interesting statement by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) today in the form of an accusation that the Labor Party were at fault or in error in their judgment in assuming that governments did not have the power to make laws which were detrimental to Aboriginal people. I guess governments can make whatever laws they like; whether they are challengeable later is the question.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting point the minister made was, `Ah, but you are wrong or inconsistent in your arguments'—he pointed to the Labor Party—`because you supported the ATSIC bill last year.' I was very clear in pointing out that the ATSIC bill last year was detrimental to Aboriginal people. I must have been the only person saying that the bill was detrimental to Aboriginal people. I am very glad that the minister has now admitted it, and I am sure those words will be helpful for those people who may think that that bill was challengeable because it was detrimental to Aboriginal people. So thank you, minister, for that. I did not vote for it.

What are the technical difficulties and will those difficulties come up again and again in relation to such things as section 10? I think they may do. That is why this is not good enough. This approach that we are being asked to handle today is not good enough. Even if it were not, in my opinion, detrimental to the Ngarrindjeri people, it is detrimental to the whole issue of advancing the cause of fair treatment to every Australian. In this particular type of issue part of the answer must be that we have got to look at and give opportunity for input on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act.

I would be happy to hear from the minister, from the government's point of view, exactly what kind of reviews have been taking place on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Protection Act 1984, but it seems to me that that is not good if there is not the ability for people to make input. Over time, what we have seen from the coalition has been a ridiculing—I have seen it on a number of occasions in this chamber—in relation to secret business. I have heard people who are deeply religious speaking in this chamber. I remember former Senator Baden Teague showing a deep concern for the situation in East Timor with the desecration of the Host.

In no sense do I wish to diminish people's beliefs, but some people might wonder what the fuss is about. They might see communion as being a fellow in a long dress holding a cup of wine. Obviously that has much more meaning for people of a Christian religion, for people who believe in sacraments and so on. That is not considered to be nonsense by a number of senators in this chamber, but there has been detrimental comment in relation to secret business.

This is not the only area in Australia where there are issues of cultural sensitivity. Instead of trying the sort of nonsense that is in this bill, maybe we have to work out a process by which we can allow comment on the issue. Maybe we should go back and work out how sensitive cultural information and values by law—whether Aboriginal law or another law, or the law of another country in fact—can be shared. It might involve a situation involving a death penalty.

People have come into this chamber saying, `Well, if it is so important, why isn't it in the records?' How can these matters be interpreted when there is a lack of cultural understanding? Aside from that issue, how can it be said, `It was not in the record. Therefore it is not true'? It has to be said that there is a lack of understanding but that there exists sensitive cultural information that cannot be passed on except under certain conditions to certain people.

If the coalition is saying that that does not exist, that is a denial of Aboriginal culture. If that is what this minister is doing, if that is the viewpoint this minister is supporting, please let him say that this is the case. Whatever his viewpoint about the Ngarindjerri claim, please let him stand up and say, `This is not the case; there is no such thing as secret business'. And, if there is such a thing as secret business, how the heck is he planning to deal with it in the future?

In my opinion we have to work out a way for people who have information about how this should be dealt with to have the opportunity to present that viewpoint so that we all as a parliament can work out how the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 can be sensibly amended to allow the sensitive handling of this kind of cultural information. If we are talking about heritage, there are many occasions, I believe, when people have not been able to speak up, have not been able to put their information forward or have had the court system used against them since the act does not enable that information to be handled sensitively.

I would like to know what the government, and perhaps the Labor Party, are planning to do about this. Would they support a reasonable inquiry into this issue which will allow public input so we can get a sensible outcome and so that we do not continue to have a situation where governments try to enact a ridiculous bill which will take away the rights of a group of people? Whatever the problem is with section 10, it may still relate to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act. Maybe that is what we need to look at. I would like to see, if there is support from the Labor Party, some mechanism by which we can advance and allow input into the process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Senator Margetts spoke about the bill allowing the minister to appoint the chairman of ATSIC, and you said you voted against it. I did not say, nor did I agree that it was detrimental to Aboriginal people. I do not believe that. In fact it was quite the reverse.
—That is why I think it was a bad example to use.
—It is an example, and that was the only reason—
—But a bad one.

—It is still an example, and that is why I used it. In relation to the heritage protection act, Justice Evatt has produced a report. We are here today really because of the failure of the heritage protection act. Justice Evatt's report has gone out to all interested parties—to state governments and to ATSIC itself—and I would be happy to have a response to that report from you or any other interested parties. Once those responses have been received, the government will collate them and enact legislation which will be up for debate. This is occurring at the moment; it was set in train by the previous government in order to protect secret women's business—or secret men's business for that matter—so we can produce a mechanism and not get into the shambles the previous government got into over this type of thing. The matter is addressed in the Evatt report, and a proposal has been put forward. It is being attended to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few points and place a bit of information on the record because I think this morning we have had from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) an unfortunate contribution which says that this legislation has no problems with the Racial Discrimination Act because it is a later act.
—Because it overrides it.

—It is a later act, and overrides the operation of the RDA. That is the minister's defence. For the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to justify a piece of legislation as overriding the operation of a pre‐existing act is something that I find very hard to accept, particularly since that pre‐enacted act is the Racial Discrimination Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get this clear. The minister wants his certainty, and he claims that he gets his certainty because this act is a later act to the Racial Discrimination Act and, as a consequence, its effect overrides the operation of the previous act. It is a basic, fundamental and constitutional legal principle is what the minister is saying.

They have contended for some time that the principles of this bill do not offend the RDA principles. Today the minister has acknowledged that the reason why there is no inconsistency with the RDA is that this legislation overrides the RDA. Not only is it offensive for the Aboriginal affairs minister to justify legislation on the basis that it overrides the principles prohibiting racial discrimination; it is also totally inconsistent with the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to this parliament that he would not be party to the introduction of legislation which would override the Racial Discrimination Act. That is the first point.

The second point is to pick up on the point Senator Bob Collins made and to read into the Hansard some of the evidence of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee which I think is quite compelling. Senator Collins asked the minister whether anything could stop the construction of the bridge under the law as it now stands—without an amendment. The minister did not answer that. On page 105 of the Hansard of the Senate Legal and Constitution Committee, this passage appears:

Senator BOLKUS —The reality of your answers has been that you do not need special legislation to stop the construction; though, you are saying that you may need special legislation to stop you having to have another reporter. Is that the case?
Senator Herron —Yes.

A very clear answer: he does not need fresh legislation to ensure the construction of the bridge. He needs fresh legislation maybe to stop another reporter, but he does not need fresh legislation to prevent anyone stopping the construction of the bridge.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's obvious.
—You do not need fresh legislation to ensure the bridge goes ahead. That's obvious.
—Who's going to build it?
—Let us look at this. On page 103, this passage appears:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator BOLKUS —The only way that that would not go ahead under existing legislation would be if you issued a section 9 or section 10 order under the act. I think you made it clear in the parliament you do not want to go down that route.
Senator Herron —That is correct.
So he does not want to issue a section 9 or section 10 order under the act. Further down:

Senator BOLKUS —So, therefore, is it not a fact that there is no declaration under section 10 of the ATSIC heritage act preventing the construction of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge currently in existence?
Senator Herron —That is correct.
When I suggested that there was nothing, in effect, that would stop the bridge being constructed, the minister said, `That is correct.' We went on:
Senator BOLKUS —Even if Tickner's declaration had been upheld by the courts, and was currently in existence, could you as minister have either amended or revoked that declaration at any time?

Senator Herron —That is another hypothetical question. But, under the act, it appears that I could, yes. Nothing in the section limits the power of the minister to revoke or vary a declaration at any time.
Senator BOLKUS —That is section (13)6.

TALK.START.PARA: —He confirmed it again this morning.
—As Senator Collins said, he confirmed it this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: We talked about pieces of string for a while, then I asked:
. . . is there any provision in the act, Minister, that compels you to make a declaration in response to any application under section 10?
So he has not made one; there is not one in existence—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Herron —Not a declaration. But, as we mentioned previously, the courts could put me in a position to appoint another reporter.
Senator BOLKUS —But there is nothing that compels you to make a declaration under section 10--nothing in the act?
Senator Herron —No.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right; he has utter discretion.
—Utter discretion. As Senator Collins said this morning, there is a precedent—the Boobera Lagoon case. On page 104 of the transcript, this appears:

BREAK.PARA: Senator BOLKUS —Is it not a fact that Justice Foster in the Federal Court on 17 October recently, with respect to Boobera Lagoon, ruled that you couldn't be forced to make a declaration protecting the lagoon despite the fact that you have received a report recommending protection?
Senator Herron —Yes, that is correct.
I went on to say:

Senator BOLKUS —In other words, you can't even be compelled to make a declaration protecting the bridge site or any other site, for instance, even when you have a section 10 report recommending that you do so?
The minister said, `Yes.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—He says, `That's right' now. So there is nothing to stop the construction. There is nothing to force you to make a declaration. You are not going to make a declaration. Why do you need the legislation? That is the question we asked in the committee and that is the answer that we cannot get. We cannot get it from you, Minister. You have said that consistently and you say it again now. You do not need legislation to stop people from stopping the construction of the bridge; is that right? You don't need legislation to prevent people from obstructing the construction of the bridge.
—That's not what you said in the committee. Read out what you said.
—All right, I will read out what I said:

BREAK.PARA: Senator BOLKUS —The reality of your answers has been that you do not need special legislation to stop the construction; though, you are saying that you may need special legislation to stop you having to have another reporter. Is that the case?
Senator Herron —Yes.
So there is no legal impediment to the bridge going ahead and nothing can obstruct that bridge from going ahead. There is no legal obstruction to that bridge going ahead—right?

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—That is why I find your previous answer quite offensive. You do not need to legislate. Not only are you choosing to legislate but you are choosing to legislate to override the Racial Discrimination Act.
—You're on the record now.

—You are on the record now. You are accusing us of playing politics with this issue. I have had some correspondence and contact with Mr and Mrs Chapman for some time. I was going through my files and I found a letter they sent to me a couple of years ago, and I am prepared to table this letter from the Chapmans—and ask you, Minister, to table your legal advice—in which they say:

BREAK.PARA: The Liberal Party while in opposition used the bridge as a political football and placed themselves in a corner from which they do not know how to retreat.
They go on to talk about Sam Jacobs's report. The letter continues:
It would appear that the Liberal government has given undertakings to certain parties for whatever reason of opposition to the bridge that the bridge will not be built.
It continues:
The Liberal government, having acknowledged that on advice there will be massive claims should the bridge not be built—
this is a state government—

have used yet another tactic by handballing the problem to the federal government by not mediating the perceived political problems in the hope that if there should be a claim for compensation the federal government will pick it up.
This is what the Chapmans were saying two years ago; yesterday I indicated what the Chapmans and their lawyers are saying now.

Since July last year there has been no impediment to the bridge being constructed. They have been telling the state government that, and it is the state government that has been obstructing the construction. We want to know why the bridge is not going ahead. The Chapmans cannot work it out, because on the same land under which Robert Tickner issued a declaration a marina was being constructed at the end of last year. They cannot see why that can go on while this cannot go on.

So, Minister, you came in and made some assertions about legal advice. I still find it quite astounding that you have not sought written legal advice from Attorney-General's on the importance of the statements made by a number of High Court judges since 1982 on the operation of the power of the constitution, section 51(xxvi), the race power. As I said yesterday, quite a number of judges have said that this power can be used for the benefit. You say this is a special measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an amendment.

—As you said to Senator Collins earlier on, a special measure is not a measure of continuing nature; it has an expiry date. When do you think the Aboriginal heritage act will expire? Is it an interim measure? Is it a piece of legislation that has only a short lifespan?
—No, it's not.

—Of course, it is not. The act is not in itself a special measure. You should appreciate that. It is a measure of continuing operation. So if you are claiming the defence of a special measure, you cannot claim that with respect to this particular act.
—I said it is an amendment.

—It is an amendment to the heritage act. As an amendment to the heritage act, it is more offensive to the constitutional law if you do not claim the special measure provision. Quite honestly, senators on this side and anyone listening to the debate would be confused about your position.
—You're confused.
—They would be confused about your position. I do not mean this to be gratuitous, but I would ask for the advice in writing and, if I were you, I would actually table it.

BREAK.PARA: You have given us a few commitments on this matter which you have not met, and I repeat them. You say you went out yesterday to seek advice on the amendment. On 29 November in the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee you were asked about the amendment. That was almost 2½ months ago. It was not as though it were thrown at you yesterday. The whole government does not suffer amnesia at the moment. This was something that was raised on 29 November and discussed in the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee.

You could have got advice then. Do not come in here now saying, `It's last-minute advice because we've just been confronted with the amendment.' You were asked about it on 29 November. It is in the Hansard. You yourself in fact raised it. I was asking you about different aspects to do with racial discrimination and you actually raised the question of the amendment. You could have sought advice then, but you did not. I asked you then, and I would like an answer to it now as much as anything else:

I do not think you have been asked this before; this is separate. I am asking you to amend your second reading speech and the clause notes to make it clear that the act should not be interpreted as breaching the RDA.
Senator Herron —That is not a problem, as I understand it from what I am advised.
Is it a problem now? Why have you not done it?

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't breach the RDA, it's not a problem.
—No, you gave a commitment then that you would amend your second reading speech and the clause notes. You said it would not be a problem. I am asking you: will you do it now?
—It's not a problem.
—If it is not a problem, will you do it?
—I am saying it is not a problem because it doesn't breach the RDA.
—Will you do it?
—Yes, but it's why it doesn't breach it that is the important thing, Minister. Can't you see that?

—Minister, the other thing is that you were asked on 29 November to give us the advice—in fact, it was a rather humorous situation—and you told us you would not give us the advice of 1 November and 6 November, and then you discovered you had in fact given us the advice of 1 November.
—It had been given to you.
—But you signed the letter which forwarded it to us. It was not given to us by some obscure, unknown person. It was your letter that you signed forwarding the advice.
—Why did you ask for it?

—Why did I ask for it? I caught you out. You are the one who told us that you would not give us that advice, but you had already given it to us. But the advice of 6 November is the one that I asked from you then and you said you were happy to consider giving that advice as well. I do find it difficult to accept an overriding of the RDA, but I do also want some pretty direct answers to those questions of changing the second reading speech, changing the clause notes, providing that advice and also providing a copy of the advice that you desperately sought last night from Attorney-General's.

BREAK.PARA: Minister, you may not agree with me—and I do not honestly expect that you would agree with me—but we are not talking here of a special measure of the Aboriginal heritage act. We are not talking here about a special measure. The advice of your lawyers, from what you have told us, seems to rest on the capacity of the government to erode a special measure. If you are not talking about a special measure in terms of the heritage act, that advice that says you can erode a special measure is totally irrelevant to what we are talking about here.

I say to you that you should not dismiss lightly the obiter of the justices, as I mentioned yesterday—the six or seven of them stretching from Lionel Murphy in 1982 to Chief Justice Brennan just a short time ago in the case of Gerhardy v. Brown and including Justices Wilson, Gaudron and Deane in between and also, I must say, a bit of obiter from Justice Stephens as well on the same point. Minister, I do not find your case convincing. I do find it quite sad in that you are prepared to contemplate an argument that says, `There is no inconsistency with the RDA because it is a later act. We're overriding it anyway.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to that. The question raised was: is the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill consistent with the Racial Discrimination Act? The answer is: the bill is consistent with the RDA. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, which the bill amends, as you know, is a special measure for the purpose of the RDA, but a special measure is a measure for the positive advancement of a racial or ethnic group to ensure the group has equal enjoyment of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

SPEECH.PARA: Special measures are exempt from the general prohibition on racial discrimination under the RDA. So the need for an extent of a special measure is a matter for parliament to decide, and this bill would give effect to a decision to narrow the scope of an existing special measure by removing Hindmarsh Island bridge from the application of the heritage legislation. That is what it has been all about, and that does not seem to be understood.

The majority of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee agreed with the Attorney-General's advice that the bill is consistent with the RDA. So it is consistent. If the minister has no intention of issuing a declaration and cannot be compelled to do so by the courts, why is this legislation necessary? That is the question that was asked.

Everything that I said this morning was consistent with what I said in the constitutional and legal committee's hearings. I do not resile from any of that. What I said then was perfectly correct. Put simply, this legislation is the only way of stopping the legal merry‐go‐round. If you want the legal merry‐go‐round to continue, that is your decision. It is the only way of preventing any further waste of taxpayers' money.

The central fact is that a live application remains for a section 10 declaration. If the legislation is not passed, I would be required to act on that application—in the first instance by appointing a reporter. That is what I said in the constitutional and legal committee. I do not resile from that.

That in turn means spending more money on this issue. If the legislation is not passed, the applicants may go to the courts to attempt to compel me to appoint a reporter. It is not beyond the realms of possibility—notwithstanding the Boobera Lagoon case you mentioned, Senator Bob Collins—that the courts might agree to an injunction preventing the bridge in the meantime. Senator Bolkus, you should be listening to this reply because it is answering your question.

Having appointed a reporter and received a report, which may or may not be subject to further legal challenge—every previous report has, as you know, been subject to a challenge—I would then need to consider the report and make a decision in accordance with the heritage act. I could decide against issuing a declaration and that is the evidence I gave before the legal and constitutional committee. However, the bridge construction would remain under a legal cloud until I had made my decision and until the courts had finally—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—Well, if you had been listening, Senator Bolkus, instead of being down the other end, you would know. Senator Collins, you have not only the ability to hear different things from each ear—
—So the developer's lawyers are wrong too, are they?

—Senator Collins, allow me to finish my answer to Senator Bolkus. Of course I could decide against issuing a declaration. However, the bridge construction would remain under a legal cloud until I had made my decision and, importantly, until the courts had finally dealt with any challenges to that decision. Given previous experience on this issue, any refusal to issue a declaration could be challenged in the courts on procedural grounds.
—Yes?
—Yes? You agree. So why don't you vote for this legislation and put an end to the sorry affair? So for six or 12 months now, given the litigious nature of the adversaries in this case—
—You can't stop people going to court in this country.

—No, but we could find ourselves back where we are today, possibly entailing hundreds of thousands of dollars—Senator Collins disputes up to a million. Wait and see, Senator Collins, if this bill does not go through. It is on ATSIC's budget, remember, Senator Kernot. That is where the money comes from.
—Don't use that as a threat, Minister.

—It is not a threat. It is a fact. It comes out of ATSIC's budget. Therefore, even if there is no way of forcing a minister to make a declaration, there is only one certain way of stopping the legal carousel and any further waste of taxpayers' funds. The only certain way is to put a legislative stop to it and that is the import of this legislation. That is why this legislation is necessary. It is the only sure way of bringing this sorry saga to a conclusion and that is what we are trying to do. The only sure way to guarantee finality, to end the expense and stop wasting money and time is to pass this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I said yes to the only other question that Senator Collins raised. Senator Collins, your statements are correct, but the minister would have to go through another process before deciding not to issue a declaration, as I have mentioned. Such a process would no doubt be subject to the same level of litigation as I have mentioned, so I think I have covered Senator Collins's statements. I do not resile from those statements that I made before, Senator Bolkus. I am happy to produce that legal advice, which I have read into the Hansard anyway. I am happy to table that. It is in the Hansard.

Let us get on with it. Let us have the vote. Stop the sham. Stop all this nonsense on the other side. If you want to continue it, as I said, be it on your head. The albatross will still hang around your neck.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the minister's argument, he says that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act is a special measure and, because it is a special measure, the Racial Discrimination Act does not operate. Is that the argument that you are putting?
—No.
—The argument is that because it is a later enactment of the federal parliament it prevails to the extent of any inconsistency that is involved. In other words—
—Order!

—If that is so, if the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act is not a special measure and it is just another enactment of the parliament—you have been through this again and again but it is terribly difficult to see; if you do not put that as a proposition—the present bill must breach the Racial Discrimination Act due to the various things we have said.

SPEECH.PARA: I had taken you to say—and perhaps you could comment on this—that, because the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act was being amended, the character of the present legislation being that of an amendment somehow cured the problem. But if—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was yesterday's argument.

—It just does seem terribly difficult. If you do not hold the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act to be a special measure then, as Senator Bob Collins and everybody else says, it just follows as night follows day that the Racial Discrimination Act must be contravened by this. I think the distinction being made again and again—I cannot do any better than people have already, but I want to go on the record as having been part of this—is that a later act can override an earlier one. Is the policy behind the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 being denied in any way by the present bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Cooney, I agree that it is difficult. I think the answer to your question is pretty straightforward, although for non-lawyers it certainly sounds a bit confusing. But it is fairly clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act is a special measure for the purposes of the Racial Discrimination Act. I think we all accept that. A special measure is a measure for the positive advancement of a racial or ethnic group to ensure the group equal enjoyment of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Special measures are exempt from the general prohibition on racial discrimination under the Racial Discrimination Act. I think we all accept that. The need for and extent of the special measure is a matter for parliament to decide.

This bill would give effect to a decision to narrow the scope of an existing special measure. The amendment itself is not a special measure but it does correctly narrow the scope of a special measure—I think that is where the confusion appears to arise—by removing Hindmarsh Island Bridge from the application for heritage legislation. So the amendment itself is not a special measure but, yes, it does amend a special measure.

The legal advice I have from the Chief General Counsel is that the bill is, as previously advised, not inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act. Obviously, there have been previous examples, Senator Cooney, where your government made laws reducing the rights of Aboriginal people under the land rights act by introducing a sunset clause on land claims and also restricting the veto over mining, presumably using the same constitutional power—although I am happy to hear argument about that.

Those amendments, like these today, were based on the fact that special measures can be amended from time to time in light of changed circumstances. Surely it must be so. You cannot lock things in forever and a day. Those amendments can include qualifying them or rolling them back. Again, it is of necessity that that should be so, as indeed is contemplated under the Racial Discrimination Act and the international convention which envisages that special measures shall be temporary, not permanent. That is the nature of a special measure.

Additionally, in the advice from the Chief General Counsel to the Attorney‐General's Department of 27 November, which I referred to in the Senate committee hearings and in fact I tabled, the Chief General Counsel indicated that there was no basis, particularly constitutional, on which a court could invalidate the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill once it passed. As I mentioned previously, this bill has been through all the normal checks and balances that any government would go through. It has been through various departments, including the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. So I think we have clarified that particular aspect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —You say that the original Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act is a special measure; we say it is not. That is not a question of policy, I would have thought; that is a question of law. If it is a question of law, then it is not, as it were, an issue for this chamber to decide because we discuss policy here. If, in fact, as a matter of law we on this side are right, is not that an awful situation for us to be in, given the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act?

SPEECH.PARA: From the debate so far, it is quite clear that everybody in the chamber, including you, Minister—and I say this with full enthusiasm—is very much in favour of the Racial Discrimination Act. If there is a question of law not a question of policy about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act, are we not now in a very difficult situation if we leave it in the air—as it is now left—where there is a body of legal opinion that this is in contradistinction to the Racial Discrimination Act? If that is so, should we not at the very least—not as a matter of policy but as a matter of law and as a matter of getting to the position where we all want to get to—agree to the amendment that is suggested by Senator Bob Collins?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cooney for the question. The High Court decision in Gerhardy v. Brown (1985) 159 CLR 70 recognised on pages 137 and 138 that the need for and extent of a special measure was a matter for political and not legal judgment. It is, therefore, open to the parliament to conclude that there is no longer a need for special heritage legislation to apply to a particular community or to a particular area or areas. In this regard, the bill is no different to a bill that was to exclude the heritage act from applying; for example, in all national parks or in areas where buildings have already been constructed. I think that answers your question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, Senator Cooney can come back to that matter, if he wishes to. I would like to get away from the special measures point and get to the central issue, which is whether or not this bill offends the Racial Discrimination Act. If we could remind the minister of one essential element that he left out of his explanation as to why it did not; that is, the continued assurances from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) down that this government will not enact legislation that has that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I am grateful to the minister for tabling this short advice from the Chief General Counsel. The advice was not necessary, of course. As the Chief General Counsel has pointed out in the last paragraph, he canvassed this matter at the Senate committee hearing; indeed, I have read what he said about it.

Before I get on to that, and just as an indication of just how little grasp the minister has personally on any of this—unless he is handed a note or has the whole night to get a script prepared—what the minister said just a moments ago about the problem if the status quo is maintained of having an interim injunction put on, is a complete contradistinction of the evidence he gave the Senate committee on exactly the same issue. What the minister said just a few minutes ago is that if the bill does not pass, if we maintain the law as it currently is, then you run the risk of having another interim injunction issue, we will be back into the courts and so on. Let me advise the Senate of what the minister said on this very issue to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee at page 105:
Senator Bolkus —You were challenged over the refusal to issue a declaration. That led to the proceedings before Mr Justice Foster, concluded on 17 October.
Senator Herron —Yes.

Senator Bolkus —So the answer to the first question was yes. In those proceedings, isn't it a fact that Justice Foster found in the Federal Court on 17 October that the court could not issue an interim injunction against the activities that Hal Wooten described as `desecration' because it had no power to order you to make a declaration of protecting the lake?
Senator Herron —Yes, I believe that is the case.

Senator Bolkus —No‐one can force you by way of interim injunction to issue a declaration. No‐one has the power to force you to issue a section 10 declaration at the end of the day, so, for the bridge to go ahead, there is no real need for special legislation . . .

In other words, that Federal Court judgment, where the judge specifically found he could not even order the minister under an interim injunction, because there is no power—and you have confirmed that, Minister, and it is correct—shows there is no real need for special legislation. This bill confers upon you—as, I might add, it was intended to do by the minister and the parliament—very wide discretion. What you told the Senate this morning is in flat contradiction of what you advised the Senate committee.
Leaving that matter aside, let us turn to the most offensive thing you said.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no; we won't leave that aside. I will come back to it.

—No, I am leaving it aside for the minute, Minister. I am happy for you to come back to it. Now having left that aside, let me come, Minister, to the legal advice you just tabled, which, as the Chief General Counsel has pointed out, has already been given to the Senate committee. Let me remind you, Minister, of what you said just a few moments ago. What you said—legally correct and factually correct— gives the big lie to the constant protestations by you and the Prime Minister (John Howard) that the government will now transgress the RDA—and no way will it do that.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in debate here yesterday, the reason you do not want to accept this amendment in the same way that you were happy to accept it with the social security migration waiting period legislation, is that, if there is a doubt, you do not want a court to be able to determine that it is inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act. That is what I said—this is a sledgehammer indeed to crack this egg. You and the government want the assurance that, if it is inconsistent, it will prevail over the Racial Discrimination Act, and that is exactly what the Chief General Counsel has said.

All honourable senators should examine this short advice. If anyone has got the slightest concern about the interests of Aboriginal people—rather than simply passing on black letter law from Attorney‐General's, which is correct—this is as compelling a reason for supporting our amendment as I have yet seen. Listen to the advice:
You asked me on 5 February, on behalf of your minister, for urgent advice on the following questions concerning the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill.

1. If the bill, as proposed, is enacted, would it be subject to challenge on the grounds of inconsistency with the Racial Discrimination Act? Answer: No. The bill in my opinion, as I have previously advised, is not inconsistent with the RDA. As a later act, the bill, once enacted, will prevail in any event over the Racial Discrimination Act. Hence, there will be no basis for a challenge to the bill, once enacted on RDA grounds. WA v. Commonwealth . . .

And so on. Absolutely correct. The whole argument you are relying on, and you ran it this morning—I am quite happy to hear that from the Attorney‐General, but I find it highly offensive hearing it run by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—is that it is not inconsistent in the sense that, because this bill, if enacted, is a later Commonwealth enactment, if it is inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act, it will prevail over that act to the extent of any inconsistency. We all know that, but that is what we are saying should not happen, Minister. Can't you get that message?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes; you can't
—We do not want that to happen, Minister—at least I do not, and I hope a majority of senators do not. But in case you are in any doubt, have a look at the last two paragraphs.

SPEECH.PARA: 2. If the opposition amendment were included, to make the bill subject to the RDA, would the possibility of such a challenge be increased? Answer: Yes.
And I agree: yes, that is why we want it in there.

TALK.START.PARA: —More legal challenges.

—Listen to why we want that opportunity to be available to Aboriginal people, Minister. Yes, such an amendment could encourage a legal challenge to be brought—why? It would require a court to examine and pronounce on whether the amended act as enacted was in fact consistent with the Racial Discrimination Act.
—It is almost possible.

—Exactly. That is why we want this amendment. Minister, you may disagree with it and Attorney‐General's may disagree with it, but you are well aware that there is a profound body of legal opinion—and, I might add, very respected and expert legal opinion; not just Frank Brennan—that the heritage protection act is not a special measure, and I ask, Minister, if you would address yourself to this, despite the smirks on the faces of your advisers—and I ask them if they would not mind having a just bit of decorum when they are in here; it is up to the Minister to put that on, not you.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a view that I have, in common terms. I do not believe that this heritage protection act is a special measure, because, although it might make Aboriginal people the agents for protecting this heritage, that heritage also belongs to me as an Australian—and to my kids and the kids that will come after them. I believe that my interests as an Australian are also benefited from this priceless heritage of our indigenous people being preserved for all time. So I do not see this bill, simply as a common man, as being a special measure for the protection and benefit of Aborigines; it is for the benefit of us all, at the end of the day.

Leaving that aside, you know there is a strong legal opinion that that is the case. You also know that there is a strong and respectable legal opinion that this bill is consistent with the Racial Discrimination Act. Even if that is wrong, we believe that that opinion is expert and respectable enough.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Is it not true that you told cabinet in your submission on options for reducing funding for the ABC and SBS that `the position of ABC chair becomes vacant on 23 July 1996. The new chair could be asked to support a review, including terms of reference agreed by the government and a short list of suitably qualified consultants'? I ask: did you, the Prime Minister or any other officials raise with Mr McDonald prior to the announcement of his appointment as chair of the ABC the prospect of a review or anything relating to the proposed review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a recollection of the precise details of any discussions that I had with Mr McDonald, and nor was I privy to any discussions he may or may not have had with the Prime Minister. The essence of that comment in the submission was that the government itself, because of the statutory independence of the ABC, was not in a position to suggest that an internal review take place or to do any more than perhaps suggest; it certainly could not organise it or ensure that it occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: It would seem to me that there would be nothing improper in any event in it being canvassed. But I do not recall whether it was or not. Certainly the discussions with Mr McDonald were at a very superficial level in the sense that he was simply asked whether he was prepared to take on the position on the merits. The government did not in any way indicate to him that he was expected to ensure any particular outcome or approach. Quite clearly, I would have been interested in canvassing Mr McDonald's views on the ABC, its capacity to change and the importance of the ABC as a national cultural institution. But beyond that, I am not able, nor do I think it appropriate, to go into any further detail about potentially private discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you say that you cannot recollect. I put to you whether at any stage you, Mr Howard or any official made it conditional upon Mr McDonald's appointment that he support a review that subsequently became the Mansfield inquiry?

—No. Certainly not. Mr McDonald's appointment was not made on any conditions. There was a widespread view in the ABC itself, even prior to the expiry of Mark Armstrong's term, that the ABC needed to look to its financial position. I think you will find that Brian Johns was on the public record prior to 23 July talking about the need for fundamental change and indeed canvassing the fact that they had overspent their budget over a period of five years and that there needed to be some significant changes to the system. The best way for them to achieve that would have been to have conducted an internal inquiry or to have commissioned outside expert advice. That is what I understand they did. Price Waterhouse was commissioned. It certainly was not on the basis of any suggestions on our part about who should undertake any inquiry, and nor was our opinion sought on the matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. With the Wik decision affirming the coexistence of native title on pastoral leases, leaseholders now find that they have lost many rights other than for grazing activities and have had doubts cast on many accepted grazing practices, including the loss of management autonomy and development rights, and access to water supply, bores and dams. According to legal advice, they can no longer sell or auction their land, remove quarry material, allow broadacre clearing or have farm tourism, plus there are losses in asset value, with banks publicly concerned about effects on pastoralists' income generation. Would the government consider compensation for any rights finally lost by pastoral leaseholders who acquired their leases in good faith and have had their rights extinguished because of the Wik decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell for his question. I can understand the legitimate concern that he and others have raised regarding native title and the Wik decision in particular.
