The coalition government position has always been that the Native Title Act in its current form proved to be unworkable and required amendment. We are very concerned about the uncertainty which now exists following the Wik decision of the High Court and its wide implications for land management, some of which were outlined by Senator Boswell. We have been particularly concerned about the anxiety and hardship that has been caused by the continuing uncertainty to indigenous people, pastoral industry developers and others.

ANSWER.PARA: The High Court's Wik decision does not in itself call into question the validity of leases or pastoralists' ability to exercise their rights, whether they were granted under a lease or through the relevant land act. There is, however—this is what Senator Boswell was alluding to—the possibility that the Native Title Act, as it stands, may effectively reverse the High Court's view that the rights of pastoralists prevail over those of native titleholders where they are inconsistent. Advice from the Attorney-General's Depart ment which has been released suggests that the issue is very real for pastoralists, the mining industry and state and territory governments.

In view of the uncertainty which now exists, we are currently seeking a fair and just resolution that will provide a stable foundation for economic development that is so important to the future of all Australians. Senator Boswell will be aware that the government, and the Prime Minister in particular, are now consulting widely with state and territory governments, indigenous groups, pastoralist organisations and the mining industry. Any solution must be one which is based on racial equality and basic fairness and justice but which also promotes Australia's national interest, which obviously includes economic interests.

The Wik decision fundamentally changes one of the key understandings of the Native Title Act in that it was never envisaged that the grant of a leasehold estate did not extinguish native title. In fact, it is worth remembering that it was the former Labor government that gave explicit assurances of this to the pastoral and mining industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the preamble.

—I am not surprised to hear an interjection from Senator Bob Collins. We can all remember 20 December 1993. I am not surprised that he never got through that law course, because when speaking of Queensland pastoral leases, he said in this place:

ANSWER.PARA: If those titles are valid, they extinguish native title.
Furthermore, in his typical style he went on to say:
Anything to the contrary is absolute nonsense.
He was assisted by the then aspiring chief justice of the High Court, former Senator Gareth Evans. He said that when the High Court addressed the matter next time it would:
confirm that properly granted pastoral leases . . . do in fact extinguish native title.

It is not surprising that the pastoralists who now find themselves disadvantaged by this decision—those who relied upon the Labor government's argument that it put before the parliament of Australia—are not only disillu sioned but also very frustrated. Senator Boswell, we will treat this matter as urgent—it is being treated as urgent—and with the importance that it obviously merits. I hope that we will get a resolution, in the form that I have outlined, as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, led by the Speaker, Mr K. B. Ratnayake. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and worthwhile. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the chamber.
—Hear, hear!

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mr Ratnayake was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to your comments on 24 January in which you described Radio Australia as `expendable' because, amongst other things, its audience reach had fallen from 100 million 15 years ago to fewer than 20 million at present. Yesterday you said that Radio Australia now has an audience of less than five million, but no-one can really tell you what the actual audience levels are at the present time. Is it not a fact that the figure of 100 million given to the 1981 Dix review of the ABC was a guesstimate made in the absence of any survey research? Is it not a fact that, as the head of audience research at Radio Australia has pointed out, the 20 million figure which you used on 24 January excludes the two most populous countries in the world, India and China? In view of these uncertainties in your use yesterday of a new figure of five million, what precisely is the best estimate of Radio Australia's audience?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds to me as though Senator Lundy has not bothered to read pages 41 and 42 of the Mansfield report because it is all spelt out there. What Mansfield says is that in 1981 the audience reach was estimated at 100 million and today it is now estimated to be 20 million. The actual audience, which is much less than the audience reach—in other words, the actual rather than the potential—is something of the order five million, but no-one can be sure.

ANSWER.PARA: It is reasonable, I would have thought, to expect that Radio Australia would have some idea of the actual audience reach and, indeed, I thought I canvassed this yesterday. I think on page 41 Mansfield goes into a rough breakdown of the figures. I think from memory there is something like 2.8 million for Indonesia, a million for PNG and 0.8 million—in other words, 800,000—for the People's Republic of China. I do not know where you get the suggestion that the figure excludes audiences in India or China. Certainly Mansfield does not say that.

What Mansfield does say is that the onus is on those involved to demonstrate that Radio Australia has continuing relevance. No‐one is saying that Radio Australia ought to be put out of business or that somehow there is not a role for Australia in the region. The real questions are: in what manner can Australia be most effective in the region; are there a number of others already providing the same sorts of services; and is this really value for money in terms of the scarce resources available to the ABC?

At the end of the day, Mansfield says quite clearly that the ABC can well and truly cope on half a billion dollars a year. It has then got to cut its cloth accordingly. If it has to make a choice between domestic and international, in his view the Australian public would clearly come down on the side of the domestic service. That is not to say that he is recommending the abolition of Radio Australia. Indeed, he says that they ought to have the ability to continue to provide that service.

You have to ask yourselves the hard questions and look at whether or not it is being effective. If the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is not able to say that unequivocally then you start to see the dimensions of the problem. It seems to be one that is now arguing that it is very important.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure you that it has not always been arguing as fiercely as it might seem it is arguing now. The fact of the matter is that even that department has significant reservations about the effectiveness of the current service. Unless and until you can address that fundamental question and demonstrate who the audience is and what benefits they derive from it, then it is a very easy, cheap political cry to say, `Why don't we do this? Why don't we have more of that? Why don't we have our own satellite service in the region?' These things all cost money—$20 million is the cost of Radio Australia improving transmission services at the present time. Mansfield simply invites you to make the hard decisions. You clearly have not because you have not even read the report. Unless and until you do that, it is a bit hard to have a sensible debate on the issue.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will you assure the Senate that no decisions about the future of Radio Australia will be taken in the absence of a rigorous survey and analysis of its audience?

—I do not know where Senator Lundy was even yesterday. You are talking to the ABC as much as you are talking to the government. The government's responsibility is simply to negotiate, on an ongoing basis, for the balance of the triennium. It is a matter for the ABC, in the first instance, to take a good hard look at the effectiveness of the service.
—That is not what you said in your cabinet submission. That is not what you put in your options to cabinet.

—If what you are on about, sport, is option 2, which was putting it at risk, then that has absolutely nothing to do with Mansfield. Let us confine ourselves to that. I have just been handed the correct figures. The audience reach is estimated at 4.9 million. It is 2.8 million for Indonesia, 0.8 for PNG and 0.7 million for China.

BREAK.PARA: It is up to the ABC itself to look at the effectiveness of the service and to address the propositions that Mansfield puts forward. They had a meeting yesterday; they did not make a decision on the subject and presumably they will be doing it in the very near future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Would the minister advise the Senate what the procedure is for those wishing to access individual submissions made to the Mansfield inquiry into the future role and functions of the ABC and is there any good reason why submissions to the Mansfield inquiry on behalf of political parties should remain confidential?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very interesting question. I am only disappointed I did not have more notice of it, though it was quite sufficient. But the fact is, as we know, that there are privacy considerations that apply to the department and, therefore, it has to be sensitive about the release of certain submissions. Indeed, some people might have personal or confidential information that they would not want to have see the light of day. They might want to put in various matters that somehow are very personal to them, reflecting their own experiences.

ANSWER.PARA: But I would have thought that the vast majority of the 10,115 people who put in submissions were putting them forward because they thought that they were contributing to the public debate. In those circumstances, I would have thought it only reasonable to ask the question: what have those who refused to disclose their submissions got to hide? As we know, back in about mid‐August, Hugh Mackay, eminent Australian and until recently the deputy chair of the Australia Council, writing in his column in the Australian, said, `Who is the opposition spokesman on the ABC?' I suppose Senator Schacht managed to read that, because he said, `Would you believe me if I said it was Senator Schacht?' I believe him, but I am not sure too many others did. Undoubtedly, Senator Schacht read this and he thought, `For heaven's sake, I only have two weeks to go before submissions close for Mansfield. I had better do something about this.' So he got himself into first gear and he thought about it.

But as we know, from discussion in the parliament on 16 September, he kicked the best own goal in history by volunteering that 11,000 people had managed to get their submissions in, but he had not and he would be putting one in shortly. He said:
Minister, you may be interested to know that I have indicated to Mr Mansfield that I will be putting a submission in.

The fact is, if you look at appendix 2 to the Mansfield report, that you will see `Senator Chris Schacht, Canberra, ACT'. I do not know whether he has moved to Canberra, but I presume he put down that address because he is making it clear that this is a submission on behalf of the ALP. I presume it was not marked confidential; and I presume Senator Schacht has not put down any embarrassing personal viewing habits that he would not want us to know about. This was not a submission to SBS so you really do not have to worry too much, I would have thought.

What the public is interested in knowing is where you stand on the big issues. You must have had time to go away to read Dix and to read the Senate committee report. There is a heap of material on the ABC. So you have had bags of time to really do a bit of solid reflection and get all the advice that is, no doubt, available from your office and elsewhere, and put it all together.

We want to know what your alternative blueprint is. So tell me now, once and for all, are you prepared to make your submission available, because there are clearly others who can make FOI applications. There are people who could move motions for return to order. It is not for me to say. But I would have thought, at the very least, we ought to have a debate about whether or not your submission could stand the light of day. What are the big issues that you think are important, and to what extent have you addressed the future of the ABC and its level of funding? If you have some very good reasons why it all has to remain private, we ought to know about it.

Madam President, I hope that has answered Senator Patterson's question. I hope that Senator Schacht will now be forthcoming and once and for all put his submission on the table so we can have a sensible, deep and far ranging debate on the future of the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was all very interesting, Minister, but I actually did ask you what was the procedure for getting a submission.
—Is that a point of order?

—No, it is not a point of order; it is a supplementary. What is the procedure for getting a submission and is it beholden on the person who has put the submission in to release it? Is that what you are getting at?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting a bit sick of this. Time and again I am getting supplementary questions of which I have had no notice. I do not want anyone to be under any misapprehensions, because there are certain people who may have very good reasons why their submissions should remain confidential.
—Why don't you table your submission, Richard?

—It has been on the Net for weeks, Bob, so if you have not bothered to surf it, that is not my fault. The department holds the submissions. It is bound by the Privacy Act; there are, therefore, certain procedures that have to be followed, subject to those rules. But, in fact, the department's view, as an interpretation of the Privacy Act, is that it is prevented from disclosure of personal information about individuals unless the person has consented or is reasonably likely to be aware that such information will be disclosed.

ANSWER.PARA: I would have thought that if anyone was on notice, it has to be Senator Schacht. Will you voluntarily do the right thing, or will others have to resort to more extreme measures? I very much hope you take the former course. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Minister, did the Department of Administrative Services brief the Minister for Administrative Services on the nature of the offences of the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services, Senator Woods? If so, when did this occur? Minister, did the Minister for Administrative Services then brief the Prime Minister? If so, when did that briefing take place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner has asked a number of questions in relation to the Minister for Administrative Services. I have a brief here which answers some of those questions and if there is any additional information that the Minister for Administrative Services wishes to make available, I will inform you. The knowledge that the minister had of the AFP investigation into Senator Woods was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The minister—
that is, Mr Jull—
was informed in either September or early October 1996 by the Attorney-General that the AFP were conducting an investigation.
I will refer your other matters to the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —That, I must say, is an unsatisfactory answer from Senator Kemp on a number of important questions. Yesterday, I asked Senator Hill a number of questions. He undertook to provide a response to my questions before the Senate rose that evening. I ask you, Senator Kemp, by way of a supplementary question, to be absolutely clear, so there can be no cover‐up: will you come back to this Senate before it adjourns tonight with an answer to these questions?

—Let me be absolutely clear, Senator Faulkner, so there is no misinterpretation on your part of my response. I will put your questions to Mr Jull and if he is able to and wishes to provide an answer, I will get back to the Senate as soon as practicable.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of the unfair distribution of funds for vocational studies reported in Age today? Can the minister explain why it is that in Victoria $1,700 will go to each private school student but Catholic schools will receive only $433 per student and state schools just $300? Can the minister table the figures for other states? Will the minister accept that the government has made a serious mistake in the allocation of these funds and rectify the situation immediately? Or can we assume that this is yet another attempt by the Howard government to damage public education? In any event, is it not completely contrary to the undertakings given to the Australian Secondary Principals Association by both DEETYA and the minister's office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I thank you for all of those questions, Senator Allison. You seemed to have shoved quite a few into one minute. Nonetheless, I understand what it is you are asking about, and I will give you such information I am equipped to give you at this time. If there is any further information that I can get for you, then I will get it and give it to you. Nonetheless, I think you are under a little bit of a misunderstanding, and I equally think that the article in Age perhaps might have benefited from its author knowing this information prior to the writing of the article.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian National Training Authority ministerial council has agreed that $80 million over four calendar years of VET funds be provided to support the expansion of VET in schools. This is something you should support. It is a pathway to a real job. This government effort is concentrated on getting schools to give something to those kids who might otherwise not be going to university.

This proposal was endorsed by the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs. So there is pretty well a national agreement on this matter. If you are looking for a trouble spot, I am not sure that you are going to find it here. Funding has been provided to help prepare all students for the needs and demands of the work force. It is not just the students currently enrolled in vocational education programs. I am not sure whether you understood that point.
The majority of non-government schools are systemic. Their students have the same right to vocational education as students in government schools. The break‐up of funds—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just give it a pause and I will give you an answer. The break‐up of funds between the government and non‐government sectors was the subject of consultations with government, Catholic and independent school sectors in each state and territory from October to November 1996. There was consultation on this, including with the government sector. Members of the MCEETYA VET in schools task force agreed to the allocation. The Australian Secondary Principals Association received and commented on the draft guidelines, and the final version was sent to the ASPA in early December 1996. The allocation between the sectors was not raised by the ASPA with the Commonwealth at that time. It was always the Commonwealth's intention to review the allocations for 1998 and following years in consultation with the government and non-government sectors.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not have information on state by state breakdowns. Victoria is important to me, but so are the other states and territories. If I can get you any of that information, I will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for her answer. However, my question was about the inequities. I am familiar with the figures that the minister quoted. I ask the minister how she expects that state schools can manage this year on one‐fifth of the funds given to private school students for vocational training? Does this not indicate that the government has no real interest in delivering quality education in state schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, when you are involved in an educational system that has more funding for the government schools from the states and more funding for the non-government schools from the Commonwealth, necessarily you might expect that in any disbursement there may be an occasion where you want to take into account those monies that should be put towards VET in schools by the states.
—These are Commonwealth programs. What a joke!

—The states can make a contribution and we can acknowledge the capacity of the states to put money in. I see Senator Carr, who could not get a vote to get into the shadow ministry, interjecting here and scowling away, in the new year, with such an unpleasant disposition. What is the matter with you? Heavens above! It is a sensible thing to take into account the fact that the states could make a contribution here. If the states do not recognise the need to put more money into VET in schools, perhaps you could raise it with them. I am sure they would be pleased to hear from you.

—My question is also addressed to Senator Vanstone, but this time in her capacity as representing the Attorney‐General. I refer the minister to yesterday's report that a man charged with possessing $5 million worth of heroin stands to be freed from a Sydney gaol as a direct result of the $120 million cuts her government has made to legal aid. Minister, do you agree with the Attorney‐General's statement in the House yesterday that this is entirely a matter for the New South Wales government? Are you aware that this particular case only proceeded under state law because the Commonwealth authorities decided that they did not have sufficient information to charge the defendant with importation, a Commonwealth offence? Doesn't this appalling case demonstrate the artificial nature of the distinction your government has been seeking to draw between Commonwealth and state matters, or don't you regard the war against drugs as a national priority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, your normal charming disposition has left you today. Fancy making the allegation that anyone in this chamber does not care about the devastation created by drug abuse in Australia. That was an unnecessary and cheap remark and, frankly, below your usual standard. Nonetheless, if your remarks in your question are to be taken seriously, you are in big trouble on the legal and constitutional affairs committee because, as I understand it, your argument is, `Look, if there was a bit more information this bloke would have been able to have been charged with a federal offence; therefore the Commonwealth should pay.' Will that apply if someone is charged with an offence and there is not enough evidence to prosecute them? Would you say, `Oh, if there was a bit more information we would have been able to prosecute you so we will anyway'? Of course you would not say that. That was a ludicrous assertion for you to make, that because there was not enough information for a Commonwealth offence we should treat it as a Commonwealth offence. The bottom line is, as I understand it—
—This is an utterly artificial distinction in respect of funding.

—It is not an artificial distinction at all, Senator. The allegation made in the Sydney Morning Herald article of 5 February, if we are referring to the same one, about Zoran Udovicic is, I am advised, a very mischievous statement. The case referred to is a state law prosecution. It is a state crime which is to be tried in a state court, and it is the responsibility of the New South Wales government to provide adequate funding for representation of the accused in matters of this type. There is absolutely no case for asserting that the Commonwealth has responsibility for state prosecutions.

ANSWER.PARA: It is precisely because in the past Commonwealth funds have been diverted to subsidise the cost of state criminal law matters that the Commonwealth has limited its funding for legal aid services from the start of the next financial year. So that is not exactly associated with this particular prosecution. The limits are from the next financial year.

The Commonwealth estimates that there was a $10 million subsidy of state matters by the Commonwealth in 1995‐96. The New South Wales government's refusal to pay for all matters for which it is responsible, particularly criminal law matters, has forced the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission to plan for a substantial reduction in next year's funding and to take action to reduce the amount of money it spends. To minimise the impact upon the justice system in New South Wales, the state government needs to provide funding and not to rely upon the Commonwealth.

BREAK.PARA: The great majority of service cuts announced by the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission relate to offences under state law. The Commonwealth has in place case guidelines to enable it to fund expensive criminal cases arising under the Commonwealth law through legal aid commissions. It has consistently advised the state governments to put similar arrangements in place.

I will come back to the original point. Senator, if you think because there is not information there for a Commonwealth prosecution we should treat it as a Commonwealth prosecution, there is not a defence lawyer in the country who will ever bother speaking to you again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I hope you will go back and look at my questions and answer them, rather than look at the contents of your brief which were not directed to the questions that I asked. Further, though, I ask: the New South Wales Attorney‐General said today that New South Wales will dump legal aid assistance for federal cases unless your government reverses its decision on the $120 million cuts to the legal aid system. Is it true that your government's draconian cuts were based on faulty figures? Is it also true that your government has undertaken no preparation towards the setting up of a separate federal legal aid system despite having prior notice of the New South Wales government decision? Will the government accept a moratorium that Senator Bolkus has called for against the cuts to the legal aid system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not time in the minute that I have to respond to the six or seven questions that you were able to put into a one‐minute question period. There is one in particular I will answer. I will take the others on notice and, if there is anything relevant, I will come back to you with the answers.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular point I want to raise is this reference to the Commonwealth having used incorrect figures in its assessments. These claims have been made in the press and at recent hearings of the committee of which you are a member. The claim that we have used incorrect figures or have admitted to using incorrect figures is untrue. The govern ment has not used incorrect figures. As I am advised in a brief prepared by the Attorney‐General's Department, what we have said is that the 1994‐95 figures show a subsidy to the states and territories of $33 million. The 1995‐96 figures suggest that the subsidy has declined but nonetheless the subsidy remains. The figures for 1994‐95 were the latest complete data available to the Commonwealth at the time of the budget—and still are. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. In its response to the draft environmental impact statement on the proposed Jabiluka uranium mine, the Australian Radiation Laboratory has stated that the higher grade ore at Jabiluka deposit will expose employees in some work categories to radiation doses exceeding those recommended by the International Commission on Radiological Protection. Does the minister accept that, given ARL's findings, the draft EIS for the development of the Jabiluka deposit is inadequate and that, unless the ARL's criticisms are addressed, approval for mining cannot be granted?

—I was made aware of that particular submission—one of many submissions—to the draft EIS. That is obviously the purpose at this stage of the process: to enable third parties to put points of view and those points of view will be analysed and addressed. I understand that quite a bit of the criticism is actually criticism about methodology, but no doubt that will be part of what is examined. I will see the response in the final EIS, and I will be making the appropriate recommendations on the basis of that final EIS in due course.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does this indicate that the comments by the Australian Radiation Laboratory will be accepted like any other submission and not given greater weight in relation to their technical comments? Is the minister aware of the fact that their concerns are that the problems in the methodology mean the radiation levels may be underestimated by a factor of two? Is the minister not concerned that this means the company needs to go back and do its homework? Wouldn't that be your immediate response to these serious allegations?

—That is exactly the case. If you have correctly interpreted the submission, then the company would have to go back and do its homework. That is the whole purpose of an environmental impact statement. At the draft stage you call for submissions, you get the submissions, you analyse the submissions, you take them into account and you respond to them in the final EIS. I then act on that EIS, not on the draft. What I am saying to you is that the submission from the radiation laboratory will be properly taken into account in this process.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, the Prime Minister has just informed the House of Representatives that he asked Senator Woods to discuss the timing of his resignation with you. Did Senator Woods do that? If so, when? Was the detail of Senator Woods's resignation letter and associated media release discussed or cleared with you or a member of your staff?
—Yes, he did discuss it with me. He discussed it on Monday. I did not see his letter or media release and whether any of my staff did, I do not know.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, this week the ABARE conference was told that farmers are `facing falling export returns and financial losses in 1996-97'. The conference was also told that farmers are `on average looking at business losses of $4,700 this financial year'. Is it true, Minister, that your government has done nothing to arrest this disastrous situation for Australian farmers and has no idea what to do? What will your government do to prevent food imports such as oranges from South America, pork from Canada and chicken meat from Thailand and the USA being dumped onto our domestic markets and destroying Australian farmers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —A good emotional question, Senator. A rhetorical question, I would have to say. Everyone is very much aware of the problems within the rural industry at this stage. Senator, you have asked me a number of questions. The answer to one question is: yes, the rural industry is going through a difficult problem.

ANSWER.PARA: Bear in mind that something like 80 per cent or 90 per cent of our rural products are exported. For example, look at the meat industry which, curiously, you did not mention. That is the one, if you look at it across the board, that has suffered most. The meat industry is suffering because of a range of things. The most significant one is the market itself. The world market for meat has declined. People have made investments and they are losing money.
Let me just touch on the other questions your have raised, Senator Woodley. You mentioned the chicken situation. Let me point out just where we sit on chicken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Warwick `Chicken Man' Parer.

—Old `Chicken Little' Collins. The minister has indicated in regard to chicken that AQIS was going off to get another scientific study to follow up on the first one. As everyone would know in this place, the decision is made by AQIS. It is worth pointing out that the minister's actions in regard to the final round of testing on chickens have been supported in a press release put out today by the NFF and the New South Wales Farmers Federation. I know that the Democrats have great difficulty in coming to grips with that.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot chuckles. Do you know that Senator Kernot would not see the executive director of the National Farmers Federation for a long period of time. What a great friend of the rural industry are the Democrats. You come in here, Senator Woodley, beat your breast and say, `Guess who's the friend of the rural industry?' in the face of our National Party colleagues who are the great voice of the rural industry and who have been, I might say, since their very inception.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Woodley, you raised other questions and also used a nice bit of throwaway language. We all know that proper scientific advice has to be given in regard to various products—whether they be chickens—to AQIS. AQIS makes the decision. You did not mention salmon, I noticed, because the story came out the way you would have liked. It was done on proper scientific assessment. You also used the mischievous throwaway line, `So much for keeping the so and so's honest' when you talked about products being dumped.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about oranges?

—Senator Bourne interjects and says, `What about oranges?' Let me just give you the situation, as I know it, with regard to oranges. It is part of the world market. There is a price problem with regard to frozen concentrate. There is no doubt. There is a surplus of concentrate throughout the world. We are in a world market. You cannot get away from that, Senator. Because of the actions of this government, we are getting record prices for fresh oranges in markets where we have not been before. You know that and I know that. So do not pretend otherwise. (Time expired)

—I have a supplementary question. Is it true that all Minister Anderson could offer battling Australian farmers at this year's ABARE conference was to tell them that they are at the mercy of world markets and that many more of them would have to leave farming? Minister, again, what is your government going to do?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister was reported as saying that. I should also say that he was misreported in one of the papers—I think it was the Herald‐Sun —with regard to the quote about agriculture being a basket case. His precise words were: `I do not believe that agriculture is a basket case.' I would just like to correct that.

ANSWER.PARA: Minister Anderson said, `I don't run away from the difficulties and there is no doubt that, unfortunately, we are looking at another very difficult year.' Absolutely true. He stressed that the key to farm recovery after 13 years of Labor will be economic reform, including lower interest rates, which have already been delivered, lower inflation and, of course, the industrial relations regime, which is vitally important to the farming industry.

There are other significant benefits to the rural community. You asked what the minister was doing. There is an extra $170 million for drought relief. If you think Minister Anderson can make it rain, maybe you can because of your previous occupation, Senator, but Minister Anderson cannot. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Vanstone. Senator, on Meet the Press on Sunday, 2 February, Michelle Grattan asked whether you and the Howard government could get unemployment down `significantly' and you said, `What do you mean by significantly?' You then proceeded to avoid answering the question. Minister, to enlighten you the Macquarie Dictionary defines `significantly' as `meaningfully' or `of consequence'. Without asking you to set a target, which you refuse to do, can you state, yes or no, that your policies will cause a meaningful shift of some consequence—and I do mean downwards—in the unemployment rate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am surprised you had the stomach to get up and ask that question. You are normally quick enough to pass that sort of thing onto someone else. You already know that this government is not going to go into the bread and circuses arguments that you did about setting yourself targets. For example, you claimed you created some 700,000 jobs, or 400,000 jobs—whatever it was you claimed—forgetting that all you did was replace jobs that you wrecked in the recession we allegedly had to have.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, you also do not go on and indicate what else I said, which is, quite clearly, this government does have a plan to resolve the shocking ingrained unemployment left after 13 years of your party being in government. You should understand, Senator, that after 13 years you left government with unemployment at an ingrained high level. You have come in here and somehow suspected that we on this side of the chamber are going to be silly enough to say, `It can be fixed in 10 months or 11 months; it can be fixed overnight.' If you think it can be fixed in 11 months, why in heaven's name did you not fix it in 13 years? Why, if we have had 11 months, did you not fix it in 13 years?

You have no credibility whatsoever to ask this question. You have no moral or political authority to ever comment on unemployment again. With the number of people that you put on the unemployment queues and the devastating high level of unemployment that you left us with for so long, I can tell you that electors will neither forgive nor forget your disastrous performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I did not ask you about a target and I did not talk about 10 months. I asked whether you could give an assurance about a meaningful downward shift of some consequence in the unemployment rate. Minister, in light of your non-answer, do you stand by your previous statement that, if your government cannot get unemployment down in any meaningful or significant way, you will not deserve to be re-elected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you choose to roll a question and an answer into one and allege that I have said the whole lot. It is abundantly clear to me that electorates should judge governments on the achievements they make. I went further on the program on Sunday and said that, of course, people will judge what we have done to get rid of this ingrained unemployment. They will look at the structural changes that we have made—look at some of them that we have made already. They will judge us on our performance.

ANSWER.PARA: That is what I am very happy for the electorate to do. You, however, should be hiding your last performance, which was a pathetic performance that left unconscionably high levels of unemployment in this country. We had 13 years of Labor. You created the problem. We have only had 11 months. Why don't you go home and read a book.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Papers presented at the ABARE outlook conference now under way confirm that it has taken only 10 months for the Howard government to return confidence to our vital minerals, oil and gas industries. Can you confirm that those papers and their positive forecasts herald a new era in the development for our minerals, oil and gas industries? The answer will be good music.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Eggleston very much for that question. Senator Eggleston has always had a great interest in the mining and resources industry because of the many years that he spent as a general practitioner in the Pilbara region. He, if anyone, knows the benefits that flow not just as export income but also the regional benefits that come to small business and the job creation that goes on when all these developments take place.

ANSWER.PARA: This renewed confidence now evident in our minerals and oil and gas industries comes from the certainty and solid management that is a hallmark of the Howard government, which is totally focused on real job creation. Today's optimism about these industries contrasts sharply with the deepening pessimism fostered by Labor's continued attacks on these industries, particularly by the fringe lunatic groups.

I just heard an interjection, `What about families?' The Labor Party has never understood that probably the most important things in the minds of families are security and the creation of real jobs. They are the things on which the family hinges.

Confidence in our minerals industry is absolutely vital to Australia. It provides the climate for investment and that means direct and permanent jobs in new mining and oil and gas developments, and—I might say—thousands and thousands of service jobs. This means small business jobs. The bakers, the caterers, the fuel suppliers and the multitude of local providers are all winners, to say nothing about the boost to the local and regional economies.

These industries are all major export industries. Every new project means more exports and a major contribution to lowering Australia's international debt. Remember the great debt the Labor Party created? This is another problem that the Howard government has had to confront along with the black hole and the Native Title Act. This is one of the major problems that we have had to address because of 13 years of misrule. This is why this government is determined to encourage the development of the resources sector which—we all should know—is vital to Australia's prosperity, a fact that seems to have escaped some of industry's opponents. We want to get away from unnecessary impediments to allow development to continue. We have to reduce perceptions of sovereign risk.

This government is building on the confidence now evident in the minerals industry, moving to downstream processing or value adding. This means more real jobs for Australians, direct and indirect. The move has been significant in the past few months. Even in the past few days, people who attended the ABARE conference have come to see me personally. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, how is the regional minerals program helping the minerals, oil and gas industries?

—Isn't it interesting that when we get good news and a good positive program these people, who caused the economic damage to this country and were thrown out because of it, laugh. They think it is a joke that we are getting this country back on track. One of the most positive developments for the mineral industry is the regional minerals program which this government established in 1996. Basically, it means that we have committed $1.2 million over the next four years for studies into several prospective regions.
—$1.2 million for a $10 billion industry?

—We believe in self‐help, Senator. Equivalent contributions will be made by the states and the industry itself. After talking with the states, the government has decided on three province studies: the central west of New South Wales, western Tasmania and the Gawler Craton in South Australia—which will please South Australians here. We also intend to pursue a coal initiative in the Surat‐Dawson valley in Queensland. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Do you agree with Mr Howard's statement in his 1995 Headland speech that:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government's—
that was the Labor government—

economic projections for the next four years were downgraded below four per cent. This is an admission by the Government that it cannot sustain growth in the range necessary to further substantially reduce unemployment rates . . .

Given the Treasury's mid‐term review—and I must thank you for the copy you gave me—has forecast growth of only 3.5 per cent for each of the next four years, is this an admission by your government that you cannot sustain growth high enough to reduce unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the question from Senator Cook because it is an extraordinary thing that a former senior Labor Party minister should stand up here and ask questions about unemployment.
—It is not surprising at all—it is question time.

—I would have thought there would be just a modicum of recognition of the appalling performance that your government had over 13 years. In your supplementary, Senator Cook, you might use part of your one minute to indicate what right you have to ask about the unemployment levels, when your own performance was so absolutely pathetic. What you left us with after 13 years was a huge mess. What we are putting into place are the structural reforms which are needed in this country, which are serious—
—Industrial relations.

—Yes, thank you, industrial relations is one of the very important reforms. Senator Conroy, how savage were the unfair dismissal laws in relation to discouraging employment? Getting the budget back into balance, making sure that we maintain a low interest rate environment and taking the pressures off interest rates—all these structural reforms are going to be very important in creating the basis for strong employment growth.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I have now waited for several minutes for the Assistant Treasurer to answer the question actually put to him. The question was not about the Labor government; the question was about what the Prime Minister said and what the government now reveals in its mid-term review. I ask you to direct him, if you would, to actually answer that question and not one that he has invented for himself.
—Senator Kemp, you certainly should be mindful of the propositions put to you by Senator Cook.

—Indeed I am. That is why I am responding by looking at the reforms that we are putting in place to encourage employment in this economy. It was appropriate to reflect on the fact that Senator Cook and in his party during 13 years in government utterly failed in this key area.

ANSWER.PARA: Since we came to government in March, a conservative figure would suggest that over 124,000 jobs have been created because of the reforms and the confidence that we are engendering in the economy. We believe, as I said, that the changes that we are making in fiscal policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order again, Madam President. I will at another time be interested in what reforms the government is making. But the question was: Mr Howard said in his headland speech that below four per cent will not address the problem of unemployment, and the Treasury said in its mid-term review of this budget that the growth rates for the next four years were 3.5 per cent—that is, below what Mr Howard said was needed to address unemployment. Would the minister actually answer that question; does he agree with that or not?

—The question was in regard to the key issue of jobs. I have pointed out that, since we have come into government, over 120,000 jobs have been created. I have also pointed out very clearly that what we are putting in place over a whole range of areas are the reforms necessary to ensure continued strong employment growth.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I note that Senator Parer and Senator Vanstone have just lectured this Senate on unemployment. Can the Assistant Treasurer tell me: was the Prime Minister therefore wrong when he said that growth rates of less than four per cent will not substantially reduce unemployment; and, if he was wrong, where was he wrong?

—Senator, you will be aware that one of the big issues in the election campaign was employment, and the Prime Minister was dead right when he pointed out to the Australian public your truly pathetic record and your failure in your 13 years in office to address in any real and meaningful way the unemployment problem.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December I undertook to Senator Reynolds to get her some material about a question she was asking. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that additional information and I table a copy of the Privacy Commissioner's guidelines that Senator Reynolds requested.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response by Senator Newman, Minister for Social Security, to question taken on notice from Senator Reynolds.

QUESTION.PARA: In Question Time on 5 December 1996, Senator Reynolds asked me about the Government's policy on data-matching and privacy protection.

In her question, she quoted selectively from comments Senator Knowles had made about data-matching in November 1995, in order to imply that the Government had previously been opposed to data-matching.

A less selective reading of Senator Knowles' speeches reveals that Senator Reynolds' implication was misleading. Senator Knowles clearly stated that the then-Opposition supported data-matching but was concerned to ensure that privacy was protected and that data-matching was cost-effective.

The Government believes that privacy has been adequately protected through the adoption by the Department of Social Security of the Privacy Commissioner's guidelines on data-matching and that the savings now being made through data-matching indicate the measure is cost-effective.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December I also took on notice a question to the Attorney-General from Senator Evans, which I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

Senator Chris Evans asked Senator Newman on 5 December 1996 whether it is true that veterans who commit offences under state laws the cause of which offences is contributed to by the war caused disabilities suffered by these veterans will now not be entitled to receive Commonwealth legal aid funding from 1 July next year. He asked whether the Commonwealth denies that it has any responsibility for the legal consequences of the war related injuries suffered by these veterans.

Senator Evans by way of a supplementary question also asked whether it is true that many of the victims of the Voyager disaster have had to rely upon legal aid funding to bring action for compensation under state law. He asked whether these veterans would have been unable to obtain justice, without the support offered through the Commonwealth provision of legal aid in a manner which did not discriminate against them, on the basis that their claims arose under state as opposed to Commonwealth law.
The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable Senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth's proposal that its funding be used only for matters arising under Commonwealth laws will mean that anyone, including veterans, charged with an offence or bringing actions for compensation under State or Territory law will no longer be able to access Commonwealth funds for this purpose from 1 July next year
The Commonwealth expects States and Territories to provide funds for legal aid for any matter which arises under State or Territory law.

It is not accurate to characterise offences under State or Territory law as `legal consequences of war related injuries'; the Commonwealth will continue its responsibility for veterans who wish to challenge a decision in relation to a war caused disability and such assistance will be free of any means test and free of any contribution by the veteran—a scheme unique in legal aid.
In relation to damages claims arising out of the HMAS Melbourne /Voyager collision, I am not aware of claimants having received legal aid funding. However:

QUESTION.PARA: - the Commonwealth, as a defendant to those claims, has paid claimants' costs where appropriate as a normal consequence of litigation, and will continue to do so;
‐ under settlement schemes established in 1993 and 1995, the Commonwealth has paid costs in relation to claims settled pursuant to those schemes.

PARA.TAB: Also, for the purposes of the Commonwealth's decision in relation to legal aid, common law damages claims against the Commonwealth will be treated as matters arising under Commonwealth law.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 December I undertook to inquire further as to the details of a meeting of departmental secretaries that was being held in Sydney in December. This was at the request of Senator Faulkner. I have that information now and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

For several years, departmental secretaries have met outside Canberra for up to two days in the year to discuss matters relating to the management of the Australian Public Service. Such a meeting was held on Friday, 13 and Saturday, 14 December 1996.

Meetings outside Canberra enable secretaries more easily to deal with broad issues of common interest without the distractions of everyday business. In 1994 and 1995 the meetings were held in Bowral. The December 1996 meeting was held at the Reserve Bank Training Centre in Sydney, at similar cost to the Bowral venue. The Prime Minister and the Minister assisting him for the Public Service addressed the meeting, something which had not happened in the past. The cost of the meeting was $9,819.42, plus normal travel costs where necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator McKiernan today, relating to Commonwealth Funding for legal aid.

The Australian legal system is in crisis, and it is quite apparent that no-one on the government side cares. We are talking here of an urgent issue. We have had cases in New South Wales, South Australia and the ACT that either have been deferred or possibly will not go ahead because of the absence of sufficient legal aid. There is an absence of sufficient legal aid because of the decision taken by this government unilaterally to cut back its commitment to the legal process.

Action is necessary—in fact, virtually today—because the New South Wales government has made it very clear that they will be pulling out of the cooperative agreement with the Commonwealth. It is not just New South Wales, both the ACT Attorney-General and the South Australian Attorney‐General have indicated that as well. We need to have a national legal aid system working in this country.

We have had it for quite a number of decades, and it is the obligation of the Commonwealth Attorney-General to ensure that it continues. Unfortunately, it appears that he is not up to it. It is also unfortunate that Senator Vanstone seems to be leaving the chamber right now because some of the answers that she gave to the parliament this afternoon were also wrong, which indicates that she does not understand.

She asserted that there was no mistake in the Commonwealth figures. She asserted that the Commonwealth took a decision on the basis of principle and that that principle was applied clearly and transparently. She made it very clear that it was her view and the government's view that the federal government had not made a mistake as to how their figures and their formula applied.

I refer the minister to the Canberra Times of 22 January when the ACT Attorney-General, not just someone of her own party but also someone of her own faction, made it clear in a leaked letter—I do not say that Gary Humphries leaked it—from the Commonwealth Attorney-General to his ACT counterpart Mr Williams admitted that the government got its sums wrong. Senator Vanstone, I suggest to you that, straight after this question time, you ought to get back to your office and get your answer clarified by the AG's office. Not only has Gary Humphries had correspondence in which the Commonwealth Attorney-General acknowledges that they got the figures wrong but it is my information that Gary Humphries is not the only one.

Not only have we got faulty figures but we have a faulty principle. And hasn't it been exposed pretty well in the last 24 hours? You have a suspected international drug runner who has been the subject of joint investigations and cooperative agreements. You use Commonwealth and state organisations to track these drug runners down: there is cooperation in targeting suspects, there is cooperation in getting the evidence together and there is cooperation in getting these people to go to court. As happens so often, you may not be able to pin them on some charges so you get them on others. Yet, with the cooperative spirit of law enforcement in this country, this person was charged under state law and not under Commonwealth law.

You know, under your principle they would never have got Al Capone because he could have claimed a jurisdictional excuse. When it comes to drug running, international crime or national crime you cannot draw a distinction between a state responsibility and an international one. Not only do I say that, but it was the experience of the Costigan royal commission some 10 years ago that drug networks do not run any longer in terms of a province, a suburb and a state. They are international and they are national. There needs to be that national cooperation in order to pursue them and to prosecute them. As I said, it has been a long‐term practice of law enforcement in this country that if you cannot get them in respect of some charges you sting them in respect of others. What this decision by the Commonwealth shows very clearly is that they are not serious about the prosecution of drug importers and drug runners.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just a joke.

—No, it is not meaningless at all because, were they serious, they would ensure that adequate resources were put into the prosecution of these people. They would ensure that adequate money was put in so that they had money to face their responsibilities and to face justice. What you have done by your decision here has given just about every international crook, national crook and petty crook in the country a chance to avoid justice.
—You would know about petty crooks, wouldn't you?

—You can make any snide comments you like but, if you do not believe me, Mr Nicholas Cowdery, the Director of Public Prosecutions in New South Wales, has made it very clear time and time again that that is going to be the direct impact of your decision in this matter. Faulty principle, faulty decision, faulty figures and a system in crisis—and this government does not care.
—Your performance is like Fawlty Towers .

—It is very much like Fawlty Towers when you look at this Attorney‐General. This Attorney‐General is sitting back and fiddling while the legal aid system is in crisis. That is the reality. It is Fawlty Towers on your side. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me dispel one myth which has been put forward by Senator Bolkus and that is that the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) got the figures wrong in relation to legal aid. What happened was that the figures which the Commonwealth used were the 1994‐95 figures. They were the only figures available at the time and they were provided by the states. Since then, the 1995‐96 figures have become available and the Commonwealth has reassessed the position.

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence was given to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee on this very point in Brisbane just recently, where there was a revision of the intended cuts to the Queens land Legal Aid Commission. The intended cut, they said, was in the region of $4.9 million and that was reduced to $0.9 million as a result of the revision of those figures. So the Attorney‐General did not get any figures wrong. Senator Bolkus is quite wrong in that respect. The Attorney‐General was operating on the only figures available at the time and those figures had to come from the states.

The question of this man's trial having to be aborted because of a lack of Commonwealth funding is entirely spurious. It is precisely because, in the past, Commonwealth funds have been diverted to subsidise the cost of state criminal law matters that the Commonwealth has limited its funding for legal aid services. In that respect, the Commonwealth estimates that there was a $10 million subsidy of state matters by the Commonwealth in 1995‐96.

So what the Commonwealth says is that we were not only funding Commonwealth matters, but—to the tune of $10 million—we were also funding state matters. That, I think, is an important point to remember because it demonstrates that the Commonwealth was not only funding representation for laws that it promulgated, but it was also providing funding for laws which the states themselves promulgated.

There is the principle that if a government enacts legislation then it should provide the legal aid for the representation in relation to that legislation. It is also a fact, I am advised, that the New South Wales state government has refused to pay for all matters for which it is responsible, particularly criminal law matters. That has forced the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission to plan for a substantial reduction in next year's funding.

I understand that the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission met this morning—I am not aware of the outcome—to discuss Mr Udovicic's case and the funding for that. What Senator Bolkus cleverly fails to point out is that there is an inquiry which the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee is conducting at the moment from which evidence is forthcoming, that there is ongoing negotiation between the Commonwealth and the states via the attorneys‐general and their offices, and that the Commonwealth has indicated that it is only too willing to arrive at a negotiated agreement.

In evidence in Canberra the Commonwealth indicated, via the Attorney‐General's Department, that there was a problem getting the states to the bargaining table and that it was the Commonwealth that was anxious to resolve matters and to sort this funding question out. Therefore, it is not a matter for the Commonwealth but a matter very much for the government of New South Wales in relation to this particular matter.

Hopefully, over the next couple of months, the states and the Commonwealth can arrive at a solution in relation to the legal aid question and the question of next year's funding. It is a point that there is funding in New South Wales which involves the Commonwealth paying for state matters and that points to a derogation of responsibility on the part of the New South Wales government. So perhaps Senator Bolkus should address his remarks to the state government of New South Wales and not the Attorney‐General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address some remarks to the motion to take note of the answer given by Senator Vanstone. I would also like to join with Senator Ellison in expressing the wish that Commonwealth and state attorneys get together in coming months to overcome the problem that there is truly a crisis in the legal aid industry in Australia or, indeed, wider than that, in the justice system in Australia. The focal point of my question to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General (Senator Vanstone) was New South Wales and the possible release of a person who is charged with the possession of a very large amount of heroin because there are no legal aid funds available to give that person legal advice or representation before a judge in a future trial. That truly is a worry for the citizens of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not unique to New South Wales. The same concerns have been expressed in every state and territory in the Commonwealth. The unfortunate part about this is that the decisions of the attorney and of the cabinet are based on faulty figures. That is clearly admit ted, and was clearly admitted by the attorney himself in a letter to each of the state Attorneys‐General—we have copies of those letters on file.

We are not arguing in committee here. As Senator Ellison said previously, in Queensland the Commonwealth has not only admitted that they based their calculations on faulty figures but they have gone to the extent of reinstating something like $4 million to the promised funding from 1 July this year. As Senator Ellison said, the proposed cut for Queensland was $4.9 million. In the hearing in Brisbane last week we were told that the cuts are now only going to be in the order of $0.9 million. We also got evidence from the Attorney‐General in the Australian Capital Territory that the Commonwealth has admitted that the figures on which the calculations were based were not accurate figures, but that those figures will not be reinstituted.

Similarly, in the Northern Territory where we took evidence two weeks ago, we were told that the Commonwealth has admitted that it made some errors in the calculations, not only errors based on the figures that were available but errors on what were territory matters and Commonwealth matters as they impinged on the Northern Territory. There has been no offer to reinstate the funding that should have been due to them prior to the cabinet decision of last year to cut $120 million from the legal aid system.

In Victoria last Friday morning I attended a forum. Again, we were told there that the earlier figures were based on faulty figures but there has been no promise to reintroduce the funding. It will appear at this point, although evidence still has to be taken by the committee in five of the other states, that Queensland, at this stage, is the only state to get its funding partly restored. It is my understanding that all other states are at the same level.

We are truly in a crisis. The focus of the crisis in the legal aid industry today is about a person who is allegedly in possession of drugs in New South Wales. But it comes even closer to home. In response to my question, Senator Vanstone said that the cuts do not come into effect until 1 July. Senator Vanstone, as a legally trained person, would know that legal aid commissions right around Australia, in every state and territory, are now budgeting on the cuts that the attorney told them they were going to have in August last year. They are already imposing cuts to the funding of family law cases.

I heard of a case in Victoria last week where the money ran out for a particular litigant in the Family Court, right at the time when her case needed to cross‐examine her opponent—her ex‐partner—who was accused of physical violence against her. She had to get up and represent herself because the legal aid funds had run out. This is not next year, it is not from 1 July—it is this year. I hope this parliament will not have the blood of some poor individual on their hands merely because of the absence of legal aid funding and representation in the courts by virtue of this cabinet decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan's over‐dramatisation did his cause no good. Nor did he do his cause any good when he added supplementary and quite unnecessary padding to his question to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General (Senator Vanstone). There is no doubt that the question of legal aid is a matter of concern within the community at large and of particular concern to a number of senators who are part of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs References Committee which is inquiring into this very matter. Sure it is an emotional topic. It is good to try to grab headlines, but to suggest that there might be blood as a result of a government decision on funding is really, Senator McKiernan, doing your cause no good and does no justice to some of the difficulties that governments go through from time to time when they try to negotiate an agreement with the states.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting, when you look at the debate and go to the states, to note that it is the Labor parties—because they are mainly in opposition these days—who are attacking the state governments, saying that they should get the situation right, and federally the Labor Party is blaming the federal government. It is a situation that needs to be worked out and dealt with. I think we are moving in the right direction. The first situation that has to be debunked absolutely is the assertion that the Commonwealth dealt with faulty figures. The reality is that they dealt with figures that were accurate. They were the figures for 1994‐95.

At the time of certain assessments being made, the 1994-95 figures were the only ones available and they indicated a subsidy to the states and territories of about $33 million. The legal aid commissions, I believe quite properly, indicated to the government that those figures may no longer represent the situation from their own experience.

In fact, what has occurred is that the 1995-96 figures have now come to hand which indicate that the $33 million subsidy from 1994-95 is a little bit less in the 1995-96 year. So that needs to be factored in. To say that the government dealt with faulty figures is wrong. What it dealt with were the previous year's figures because the other figures were not to hand as yet.

Can I gratuitously suggest to Senator Bolkus in particular that it is of no credit to him or anybody else to try to use an individual's case to get cheap headlines to try to make cheap political capital. First, you have the problem of sub judice, and I think Senator Bolkus may have skated very close to it with some of his comments. I commend Senator McKiernan for using the word `alleged' in his comments, but if we do want to use individual examples and get excited about them, there is a duty on us senators to be very careful in the way we express ourselves in using those individual examples.

It is also interesting that Senator McKiernan talked about blood and Senator Bolkus talked about drug importation without, in the whole context, acknowledging any responsibility for the government's financial dilemma. Remember you went to the people saying that the budget was in surplus. We came into government and found a $10 billion shortfall. We had to look around to save and to try to share the balance of funding in matters between the Commonwealth and states. Where we had been funding somewhat more generously than the states we thought the equation should be evened out. The only reason for having to go on these exercises, Senator McKiernan and Senator Bolkus, is your government's previous mismanagement.

We as a government would be delighted if we had an extra $100 million to spend on legal aid. But you guys in the Labor Party should have recognised the problems that you would cause this nation by your overspending, especially in your last couple of years in government. That is the root cause of this problem. If you want to talk about blood, it will be on your head, not on ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz—and I acknowledge he is a person who has a great respect for the law and for the working of it—has put his finger on the problem, and it is this: the government is in a financial dilemma.
—Costello's black hole!

—Costello's black hole, or anybody's black hole, for that matter, Senator Woodley. The inference in that remark is this: that somehow the doing of justice has a price on it—whether a person who is in danger of going to goal experiences that fate depends upon the financial situation in which the government finds itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, that is a very serious proposition to put. You yourself have had experience of visiting people in prison, people who you may well have thought had not been properly defended. To have to go to somebody who has been in gaol for 10 years or more, or even less, and say, `Look, you're doing time. Your career's ruined. Your reputation's gone. But, against that, there's been a saving to government, and you've got to realise that government has fairly heavy demands upon it for all sorts of things. Unfortunately, we've had to let you go to gaol but you will be well pleased that you've saved the government some thousands of dollars,' whether that government be Commonwealth or state. That is, in my view, a consideration that should never arise. In other words, the financial state that the government finds itself in should never be a factor in deciding whether people get justice.

In that context, it is very interesting to hear what Mr Michael Rozenes had to say on his leaving the position of Director of Public Prosecutions at the end of last month. Mr Michael Rozenes is a man of undoubted ability as a lawyer. He was an outstanding defence counsel before he became the Director of Public Prosecutions for the Commonwealth and, I think it is conceded, performed outstandingly well while he was in the position of Director of Public Prosecutions.

Mr Rozenes said that, in so far as the prosecution of people was concerned, he had never failed to have adequate resources. In other words, he has always had adequate resources to prosecute people. He then went on to say that he, unfortunately, could not say the same for the defence. In other words, the people accused had not always had the resources adequate for their proper defence.

That is the situation that faces this Senate, this parliament and this country. We are now arguing about whether the federal government, any particular state government or, for that matter, any territory government, should pay for the proper carrying out of justice. That is what we are arguing about—as to who should do it.

While we are arguing about that, the system is coming under strain. It is getting to the point where it is becoming a scandal. The way that the justice system in Australia is operating at the moment is less than adequate. It is not a matter—this is a phrase that is often used—of a Rolls Royce system; it is a matter of a very bad system getting worse. I say this in fairness to the legal profession. The only reason it is running as well as it is is that the legal profession is subsidising what is really the responsibility of government. If the legal profession of this country were not doing what it is now in subsidising this system—the system that the government should be running—it would not be a scandal but a shambles. It would not be running correctly. The whole society in which we operate would be under furious attack.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to a question without notice asked by Senator Allison today, relating to the distribution of funds for vocational studies.

I would like to ask what we are to make of a government that says it supports Australia's battlers but then chooses to sit back and do nothing about vocational studies funding arrangements, whereby five times the amount of funding is going to private school students compared with state school students.

The minister says, as usual, that it is up to the states. Last year, the Australian Secondary Principals Association was assured by officials from DEETYA and the minister's own staff that the inequity being perpetuated by this government in relation to its general funds for schools would not extend to funding vocational training studies. This is an assurance that the minister now chooses to forget. The principals went away with those undertakings. Now they discover that the funds have been allocated by ANTA, the Australian National Training Authority, not on the basis of merit or the location of particular programs and not even on a per capita basis but rather on the proportion of year 11 and 12 students—I gather this figure was prior to 1996 last year—in each school sector. That occurred irrespective of the actual number of students in vocational studies programs.

The Victorian figures, which were confirmed in today's Age by the secretary of the Victorian Department of Education, Mr Geoff Spring, demonstrate the unfairness of this arrangement. I will quote them. The independent sector received $764,000 for just 440 students; that is around $1,730 per student. The Catholic sector received $996,000 for 2,300 students; that is around $433 per student. In the government sector, $2,873,000 was given for 9,600 students; that is $300 per student. I might add that, in the electorate of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), Brighton Grammar will be receiving $1,700 for its students while, down the road, Brighton Secondary College will receive just $300.

It is unacceptable for the minister to come in here and suggest that there are no other figures for the other states. I ask how ac countable that is. I will be pressing the minister to give those figures at the earliest possible date.

Not only is this inequity grossly unfair on its face but its unfairness is compounded by several other features. Firstly, generally the more disadvantaged students undertake vocational studies programs. The vast majority of them are in government schools. They are also students who will not expect to go to university. Secondly, it does not take into account the particular nature or location of a program.
