For example, a program might be slightly more expensive because it includes additional features, the school is in a low income area or it has a very high proportion of non-English speaking families. Thirdly, many vocational studies programs in the government sector are run in schools in very disadvantaged areas. Those schools already tend to be under‐resourced. This sort of inequitable funding further exacerbates that disadvantage.

Finally, Minister Kemp has gone to great lengths to trumpet the importance of the coalition's pathways to jobs program and to endorse the notion that vocational studies and training in secondary schools are an important feature of bringing down high youth unemployment levels. Of course we agree with that. We already know that youth unemployment is much higher in low income and disadvantaged areas. We already know that educational disadvantage is a direct consequence of low income. Just last week, ASPA revealed that retention rates are also directly linked with that income.

Given these three things, it would seem to me, and I suspect most other Australians, that the government should not be seeking to advantage private school vocational studies students at the expense of state schools. I urge the government to address this inequity not next year or by the year 2000 but right now.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for taking note of answers has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Last year, two votes were taken on the matter of woodchip regulations. On both those occasions, seven current senators stood to declare that they held shares in woodchip companies. In other words, they were meeting the provisions of procedural standing order No. 17, section 5, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a senator shall declare any relative interest:
(b) as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate . . .

Today the regulation which I moved to disallow was clearly to advantage woodchip companies to the tune of $88,000. I believe that it was incumbent upon senators who hold shares in woodchip companies to similarly declare that interest. However, no senator stood.

It may be that there has been a mass disinvestment of shares in woodchip companies. If so, that is not noted on the register of pecuniary interests so far as I can tell. It may be that there has been collective amnesia about the declarations made last year. I am very concerned that if there are senators who have interests in woodchip corporations through shareholdings they have, on the face of it, breached standing orders.

I would be satisfied if, having now notified the Senate of this, those senators were to get to their feet and make a declaration of those interests. If that does not occur and there are such interests, a wilful component will come into the matter. I will be seeking to further investigate the register of pecuniary interests. I understand that there may be extenuating circumstances. I am really standing now to facilitate the rectification of any breach of standing orders which may have occurred this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just doing it as another stunt.
—The honourable senator says that it is another stunt. A breach of standing orders is a very serious matter.
—Put your jacket on.

—He says, `Put your jacket on,' and then laughs. This is a serious matter. What I am saying is that, on the face of it, there has been a breach by a number of senators of a very important standing order. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, if you would ask the President to investigate the matter and see whether there is a case for the Privileges Committee to be acquainted with the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: That said, I leave it to the individual senators concerned to make good their breaches of standing orders this morning, if indeed there are any such senators who took part in that vote who have shares in woodchip companies and who knew they were voting for a regulation that was going to directly advantage, in monetary terms, those companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have listened carefully to what Senator Brown has said. I would also seek your ruling, since we are seeking advise from the President and the Deputy President, on whether Senator Brown's remarks comply with standing order 193(3) which relates to imputations of improper motives and personal reflections on members of this chamber.
—I would not think so because Senator Brown is raising a matter about the standing orders which concerns him.

—I consider this matter to be serious. There is a potential breach of standing orders. I am also saying that here is the opportunity for any senator who may be in that situation to make good. I would be quite satisfied with that. What I am not going to be satisfied with is a situation where, having brought this before the Senate, it is found that there was a breach of standing orders this morning and no remedial action is taken by those involved.
—As you mentioned in your remarks, I will refer your comments to the President.

—by leave—As one who has declared on several occasions in the past an interest in a woodchip company—and I declare again that my wife and I still have shares in Boral which has an interest in woodchips—I point out that it was not immediately apparent to those of us who have shares in woodchip companies whether those companies would be advantaged or disadvantaged one way or another by the motion Senator Brown moved—motion No. 1 for today.
—That became clear in the debate before the vote.
—I do not think senators could really understand whether what you moved this morning would advantage or disadvantage the particular companies. I think as a consequence—
—If they vote on it, surely.

—I agree that I should have declared the interest just to make sure there was no disagreement about it. I am not arguing about that. I declare that interest right now. I also make the point that I am not sure that it was obvious whether there would be any advantage or disadvantage and whether there was any real interest.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee on the abolition of the Development Import Finance Facility, DIFF, and seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO THE REPORT ON THE INQUIRY INTO THE ABOLITION OF THE DEVELOPMENT IMPORT FINANCE FACILITY (DIFF)

Majority Committee Recommendation: that all companies holding DIFF Letters of Advice at the time of termination of DIFF be processed in the normal way and that additional funds be made available in 1996/7 and subsequent years to finance successful applications (page 3 of the Senate Report refers).

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The government does not accept this recommendation because it, in effect, resurrects the DIFF scheme. As explained at pages 104, 112 and 113 of the report, resurrecting the DIFF scheme would break a clear pre election commitment to terminate the DIFF scheme and would undermine the government's efforts to reduce the fiscal deficit. It should be noted that some high priority projects at the letter of advice stage will be supported with funds provided through the bilateral country programs to China, Indonesia and the Philippines.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Majority Committee Recommendation: That the Australian Government not wait for 1997/8 to introduce another mixed credit scheme to replace DIFF (page 3 of the Senate Report refers.)

SPEECH.PARA: 2. The government does not accept this recommendation. The government has referred the broader issue of a revised mixed credit scheme to the Simons review. The Simons review is due to report in the near future to government. The introduction of any revised mixed credit arrangement is dependent upon the government's response to the Simons review of the Australian aid program as well as the level of funds made available to the aid program. For these reasons it would not be feasible to introduce new arrangements before 1997/8. The Australian government has informed partner governments that the earliest any new arrangements could be introduced is 1997/8.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Majority Committee Recommendation: That any replacement mixed credit scheme be based on the following criteria: primarily a development scheme; emphasis on humanitarian/poverty alleviation/environmental activities; all projects nominated by recipient governments; integrated into AusAID's bilateral program; and all projects be open to competition among Australian companies (page 4 of the Senate Report refers).

SPEECH.PARA: 3. As noted above, the introduction of any new arrangements is dependent on the government's response to the Simons review as well as budget considerations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Majority Committee Recommendation: that the percentage of projects under the Green DIFF component in any new mixed credit scheme be raised to 40% (page 4 of the Senate Report refers).

SPEECH.PARA: 4. As noted above, the introduction of any new arrangements is dependent on the government's response to the Simons review as well as budget considerations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Committee Recommendation: that the terms of reference of the Simons review of Australia's aid program be enlarged to the extent necessary to examine certain details of mixed credit arrangements such as the overall impact of the multiplier effect, flow on trade and export opportunities etc (page 106 of the Senate Report refers).

SPEECH.PARA: 5. The terms of reference for the Simons review are wide ranging and allow all matters relevant to the future of Australia's aid program to be canvassed. Consistent with these terms of reference, the Simons review is considering the appropriateness of introducing a reformed mixed credit scheme. Given the time constraints placed on this review it is unlikely that an analysis of the detail suggested could be completed without significantly delaying the finalisation of the Simons review. For this reason, the government has not amended the terms of reference for the Simons review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

(a) notes that the recommendations of the review of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), undertaken by Mr Bob Mansfield, are a complete rejection of the Government's ideological attacks on the ABC;
(b) welcomes Mr Mansfield's support of Triple J and Classic FM;
(c) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) with concern, the draconian funding cuts which the Federal Government made to the ABC which led Mr Mansfield to recommend the transferral of program making, except in news and current affairs, to independent external producers and to recommend the abolition of Radio Australia and Australia Television, and
(ii) that it is in Australia's national interest to have an external broadcasting service;

SPEECH.PARA: (d) calls on the Federal Government to make a separate funding allocation to provide a service similar to Radio Australia and Australia Television;
(e) supports Mr Mansfield's recommendation that the legislative prohibition on advertising and sponsorship remain; and
(f) welcomes Mr Mansfield's support of regionalisation, with his recognition that radio and television in smaller States and regional areas are critical to community well‐being.

It was most fortuitous that yesterday we were able to give notice of a motion to come on for general business today. The motion concerns the Mansfield report and the future of the ABC. Yesterday we had this most extraordinary and convoluted defence by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) of his own cabinet document, which he partially disowned. He partially said that he could not remember whether he signed it or not, and said that the covering note was wrong and written by somebody unnamed whom he disowned but would not identify.

It is an extraordinary situation. In my time in the Senate I have never heard a minister of any party disown or refuse to accept a cabinet submission lodged in their name in the cabinet process, or reject it and say that what was in it was wrong when they lodged it and they approved of it under the cabinet process. But that just goes to the core of the matter of this minister and this government in its treatment of the ABC.

My motion, now before us as general business, is to deal with the Mansfield report. There is no doubt from the leaked cabinet document from last year that this minister, Senator Alston, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) wanted a quite different result from what Mr Mansfield delivered. They wanted, according to the cabinet submission, political control of the ABC. There are phrases throughout that leaked cabinet document that indicate that they want a redefined ABC, they want reduced funding, they want something that will give them an opportunity to directly and indirectly influence the running of the ABC and its programming content.

During much of last year, both before and after the Mansfield review was announced and before and after the draconian cuts of $55 million a year were announced—before the Mansfield review had even begun—there were remarks by the Prime Minister, the minister himself and the Treasurer attacking the ABC, its content and its performance. This minister, of course, the year before, as chairman of a Senate committee, when in opposition signed off on a Senate report about the ABC which supported the ABC's programming—

TALK.START.PARA: —We reminded him about that too!

—We reminded him about that on several occasions. He signed off on a report saying that the management was doing a good job and that the funding had to be maintained. That was when he was in opposition during 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: When he becomes the minister, he immediately launches a vicious attack with the full support of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer on the ABC. They succeeded in cutting $55 million per year off the budget over the next four years. In total, with other efficiency dividends, this is $209 million straight off the budget of the ABC.

The leaked cabinet document shows that Mr Mansfield's role was actually to justify the cuts post the decision to make the cuts. Even Mr Mansfield, if you read between the lines in his report, indicates that that is the wrong way to go about any review. You would normally have the review and the recommendations, and then see, because of those recommendations, what the funding should be. This government does it the other way round: cut, cut, cut, then have a review to justify your cuts.

Hasn't the government got a real shock from what Mr Mansfield came down with? Mr Mansfield clearly, and quite rightly, has not stuck to the letter of the very restricted terms of reference he was given. If he had followed them right through very narrowly, this report would have been quite different. At the time the terms of reference were an nounced we in opposition criticised them because they were aimed at getting a political outcome to meet the political wishes of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the minister—contrary to all their promises before the election.

In the recommendations, Mr Mansfield has rejected a narrower focus for the ABC. In recommendation No. 3, dealing with the role and the functions of the ABC, he has recognised the ABC as having to have a broad role in the community as a broadcaster. So straight off, in one of these most important recommendations, he rejects the ideological attacks on the ABC.

I think Mr Mansfield is proud of the fact that he actually wrote the report himself; he did not rely on a team of experts and so on, producing volumes and volumes of appendices, et cetera. He wrote a succinct report of around 50 pages, which is very readable. It has a common theme through it, overwhelmingly defending the ABC, as the people of Australia would want it. He says in his report that he was amazed at the strength of support in our community for the ABC.

He points out that he received 10,600 submissions as of 10 December 1996. He points out that, overwhelmingly, those submissions were in support of the ABC. Those that were critical of the ABC ranked at no more than one or two per cent of the nearly 11,000 submissions. So the evidence given to him from the community was absolutely contrary to the ideological obsessions of this government, led by the Prime Minister, the minister and the Treasurer.

He made the comment on the public record, in interviews, that, as a person who has come from the private sector—as a person who has had a distinguished career in the private sector—you would give anything to have brand loyalty for your product that the ABC has. He makes the point very strongly that the support for the ABC in Australia is unparalleled to the support for any of our other public or private institutions. That shows that what this government is on about has been completely misplaced.

It is a great credit to the Australian people that they responded so strongly over the six months in their submissions. I recollect that a few weeks before the end of last year the minister admitted in this place that he had received 17,000 submissions or letters of protest concerning cuts to the ABC. That is 17,000 letters to the minister and 11,000 to Mr Mansfield—28,000 submissions. That is an unparalleled number of submissions from the public, overwhelmingly—nearly 100 per cent of them—opposed to what the government was doing.

What Mr Mansfield has also commented upon publicly and privately—he was very generous with his time when he came to see me and Mr Beazley, representing the opposition—was that the letters were not all pro forma. People had sat down and written, with passion and conviction, their own submissions about the ABC and why it had to be maintained. I think that certainly had a great influence on him in making his recommendations. Recommendation No. 3 states:
That the principal function of the ABC should be defined as broadcasting for general reception within Australia.

That is, it should be a comprehensive broadcaster to all Australians. That was bottom line opposition policy. It has been the Labor Party policy for the ABC for decades. The ABC is a comprehensive broadcaster. So Mr Mansfield rejected the position of the government in trying to fix the terms of reference.

On the issue of funding he said that the government should re-establish the triennium funding arrangements for the ABC for 1997‐98 onwards. It was the Labor government in office that established triennium funding for the ABC for the first time. In its first six months in office, this government breaks its commitment to triennium funding—its promise in Better Communications to maintain funding and the triennium process—and takes $55 million off the base. That will be the base for the triennium funding for the next three years—a total of $209 million. He says that the triennium funding has to be re-established.

Mr Mansfield was given a couple of very nasty positions to have to deal with. How does the ABC survive with these imposed cuts, these draconian cuts, these cuts made without rationality, of $55 million a year? He wanted to report clearly. I would have hoped that he might have rejected the cuts, but he accepted the cuts because that is what the government wanted, and he had to find further savings in his report. Already the ABC has identified cuts of $28 million. That $28 million is costing nearly 900 jobs in the ABC across the board. It has reduced programming, particularly in metropolitan radio services across Australia.

There was still nearly $25 million to be found. In the end he had to make Hobson's choice. He said, `I received fewer submissions about the future of Radio Australia than I did about any other area.' That is not surprising. The people who listen to Radio Australia are not in Australia; they are overseas. Most of those people do not have access to the means of putting in a submission as to why they want Radio Australia to continue. Mr Mansfield said that Radio Australia should be abolished and that Australia Television should be abolished and the savings maintained for the ABC to make up that remaining black hole in the cuts. That is how you get to $55 million—by abolishing the external broadcasting service.

I do not think it was a decision he would have liked taking, or a recommendation that he liked making. But one thing is clear: already the Australian public is not accepting that Australia should not have an external broadcasting service. We in the opposition want to have a comprehensive external broadcasting service to service Australia's needs—not only in Australia's national interests but also in the interests particularly of the Asia‐Pacific region, remembering that Radio Australia is listened to consistently across the Asia‐Pacific and the rest of the world. In fact, people believe what it says. It is not a propaganda statement for the Australian government as are some of the other short wave radio broadcasting services that governments have run—and still run. The ABC and Radio Australia have credibility.

We will argue strongly that funding should be maintained, preferably within the ABC, for independent external broadcasting, and that includes television. We do not accept the minister's glib line, `Well, short wave radio is disappearing, reducing in listeners; therefore the technology is outdated and we should abolish it'. The reality is that if short wave is going out of business, what do we replace it with so that Australia's voice can be heard in the region with which our future is so inextricably linked? So we will defend very strongly the need to have an external broadcaster. But we acknowledge that Mr Mansfield was put in a very difficult position when he had to make that recommendation.

The other recommendation Mr Mansfield made which we take issue with and will not accept in its entirety relates to the outsourcing of production. We believe the ABC must maintain critical mass and have the capacity to produce Australian drama on television and radio for broadcasting across the ABC network. If it is all outsourced the ABC will lose the ability to have a creative influence; it will lose the ability to contest whether what is being proposed by the private sector is cost efficient, and it will also lose its independence when it comes to making programs that no‐one else will want to make.

Can anyone imagine a private sector organisation going along to Channels 9, 7 or 10 and saying, `We want to show Frontline on your channel'? Of course not. Frontline is a comedy which makes a point in a wonderful way about the vagaries and the cynicism of current affairs television in the commercial sector in Australia. Frontline was made by a group outside the ABC who went to the ABC knowing that it would be the only broadcaster game enough to fund and show it. That is why we have to have creative content in the ABC; otherwise there could be many programs that will not be made.

Over the Christmas break I noticed that the ABC replayed a couple of its most famous successes, including Brides of Christ. Can anyone imagine outside sources coming up with the idea to make a program such as Brides of Christ? That was an internal ABC production that has had enormous critical acclaim. Every time it is replayed, people watch it again. There was also the replay of Scales of Justice. Even though it is 13 or 14 years since it was first shown, it is still as relevant today because—

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially with New South Wales police corruption.

—It is about corruption, about the way endemic cultural corruption operates in a police force. I have to say that watching it again still chills the spine when I think that this is based on what has been going on in Australia. Can anyone imagine a commercial service making Scales of Justice ? Of course not. That was made in‐house. That is why we have to maintain critical mass inside the ABC.

BREAK.PARA: Even if we allow some programs to be made under contract in the private sector, the opposition still believes the tenders should be tested against inside costings. For example, if a particular concept goes to the private sector for tender, in‐house production at the ABC should also be able to tender for it to test that the pricing and the creative instinct is what it is supposed to be. The ABC should not be left totally dependent on the private sector when making its TV dramas. My only other comment would be that we would all like to see the ABC have more money to make those sorts of world‐famous TV drama productions.

They are the two main areas we disagree with Mr Mansfield about—external broadcasting, Radio Australia and ATV, which we believe he was forced to recommend to try to show how the cuts could be digested, and outsourcing, with which we have to disagree, although I have to say that Mr Mansfield gave considerable latitude to the management of the ABC and the board. He said that outsourcing should be at least 51 per cent, but that the actual percentage should be a matter for the board. It was not a draconian all‐or‐nothing recommendation. But he made it clear it is a matter that should be left to the board to carry out.

But what did we see in the press yesterday? We saw the most extraordinary bullyboy performance by this minister yesterday when he said to the board of the ABC at its meeting, `If you don't accept completely all outsourcing of TV drama, we won't give you any money for digitisation and modernisation on the technical side, on the equipment side of the ABC.' That is direct interference, and it threatens and blackmails the ABC when he says, `Either do what I want or we cut the money even further.' In his report Mr Mansfield makes it clear that the ABC should get some special one‐off funding to help with the digitisation program. He actually recommends increased funding for this specific area of the ABC. But this bull‐headed, bullying minister says, `If you don't do exactly as I want on all outsourcing, you won't get any money for digitisation.' He also says, `Any government of any persuasion would have rocks in their head to give you the money unless you accept complete outsourcing.'

Let me tell the minister that a Labor government in the future will never blackmail the independent board of the ABC to say, `You will spend the money how we say or we cut it off.' That is contrary to the act itself and the guaranteed independence of the board. This minister does not understand the independence in the charter of the ABC. He is about nobbling it, about threatening it, about getting a political outcome. That outcome is explained clearly in the cabinet submission of July last year that has been leaked.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like an episode of Scales of Justice .

—Actually, Senator Forshaw, you are dead right. There are aspects in the way this minister is carrying on that could actually become quite a sensational political drama that the ABC could produce called the `Trials and tribulations of Minister Alston' or `How you interfere with the running of the ABC'. It would be either a black comedy or a straight comedy—I don't know which. It would certainly be bizarre to see him in a drama.

BREAK.PARA: People say overseas, `This has to be pure fiction.' Here is a minister saying that he did not sign his cabinet submission, that he disagrees with the front page of his own cabinet submission. `It is a kerbside` quote. Some bureaucrat made it, but I forgot to change it; I disagreed with it.' For a minister to try to get around his own submission by saying that he did not write it would be seen overseas as something that only a minister from a fourth world political regime would say—maybe in the back end of Ethiopia—not a minister from a first world country.

I draw to the attention of the Senate not only the summary—the document itself—but volume 2, which is a summary of all the submissions received and the details of what they talk about and the range of them. If you look through those pages at the beginning of volume 2, you will actually see very effectively laid out what the Australian people believe about their ABC.
On page 9, it is interesting to note that under a section called `Favourable quotes', it states:
A small number of responsibilities were primarily critical of the ABC or suggested significant diminution of the ABC's role and services.

How many? Thirty‐two out of 11,615 wrote in in line with the government's view that the funding should be reduced and the ABC should be curtailed. That is an astonishing number. You would have thought that Senator Alston, being a political animal, might have actually got half a dozen Liberal branches to write in. I would have thought that he would have got a few of his backbenchers to write in to at least get it into triple figures. The reason he could not and why they did not turn up is that most Liberal Party supporters disagree with their own government on this.

The fact is that anyone who looks at the survey figures of the ABC and its listenership—any market research over many years—will see that, despite all the paranoia on the other side about left‐wing bias in the ABC, the majority of its listeners are conservative voters supporting either the Liberal Party or the National Party. Despite all this so-called left‐wing bias, the people who consistently listen to it and appreciate it are overwhelmingly Liberal Party voters. So, supposedly, the left‐wing bar has not done much because they keep voting for the Liberal Party. It just shows you what a joke this is.

When you go out to the bush, in the regional areas overwhelmingly the defence of the ABC is from people who vote National Party. What has happened is that overwhelmingly the Liberal Party supporters have dumped on their own minister and Prime Minister. You would have thought they could have rounded up at least a hundred out of 11,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're supposed to have a big party structure.

—Yes, a big party structure. More likely, if you went through and were able to match the list of Liberal Party membership and National Party membership across Australia with the list in here, you would find thousands of submissions from card carrying members of the Liberal Party and National Party saying, `Hands off the ABC. We like it as it is. We do not want the funds cut.' The document lists where the submissions came from. It mentions that only 32 respondents wanted the money cut.

BREAK.PARA: Some Liberal members, such as Mr Bradford from the Gold Coast area, say Triple J should be abolished. A Liberal member of this parliament wants Triple J closed down. Page 9 of the report states:

The areas of ABC activity which prompted the more significant levels of response were the ABC radio networks Classic FM, Radio National and Triple J. Altogether, ABC domestic radio services received 11 217 favourable comments. ABC‐TV received, by comparison, 2 809. A summary . . . is provided in Table 5 on page 13.
It just shows how out of touch the government is. Overwhelmingly the specialised radio work services were supported by their listeners.

Triple J, for example, is commented on very favourably by Mr Mansfield. As an organisation with a very small staff and a running cost of about $3 million per annum, it services 2.5 million listeners across Australia every week. Half the total radio listenership of the ABC are Triple J listeners. As Mr Mansfield commented when he first got this job, his own son said to him, `Dad if you recommend the abolition of Triple J, I'll get lynched.' That was the response from his son. I have to say that for most of us who have either teenagers or children like I have in their early twenties, the one comment they make is: will this government be mad enough to turn off Triple J?

Bob Mansfield made it very clear that Triple J is not only a successful radio station but also a service to young people. With its spread into the rural area, under a Labor government policy going back to 1989, Triple J is now a national network not just for the cities but in rural areas. Rural people want Triple J to continue because it encourages their young people to stay in the bush. They have a service that they know gives them the same sort of information, music and interest issues for young people as their young city counterparts. They want Triple J.
This government in the last budget stopped the expansion of Triple J. That is what they did in the last budget because some idiots, like Mr Bradfield, do not like occasional bad language.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would have to ask you to not refer to a member of the other place in that manner.

—In what manner? As an idiot? I withdraw, of course. But Mr Bradfield's views to close down Triple J are idiotic to say the least. It is the same with Classic FM music. These are under threat. When you read Senator Alston's cabinet submission that was leaked, you will see it is in there starkly written out that, if these cuts go ahead, one of these options I am putting forward, Triple J may close, ABC Classic FM music may close, ABC Radio National may close. They were starkly laid out. That is what this government wanted. It wanted to close down the services because occasionally, apparently, they do not like some of the comment that is broadcast on these services.

BREAK.PARA: As my time now comes to an end, for the overwhelming recommendations the opposition compliments and congratulates Mr Mansfield. Firstly, he rejected the ideological obsessions of the government that commissioned him to try to fix the ABC. Secondly, he recognised the overwhelming support of the Australian people for a comprehensive and diverse ABC. Thirdly, he has come up with significant and well thought out ideas on amending the charter of the ABC, not changing its comprehensive nature but emphasising a couple of areas. For example, he thinks regional and youth affairs should be written specifically into the charter. Why does he want to put youth affairs in? I think this is a recognition of the role Triple J has played for young people in Australia.

We will have a very close look at any recommendations the government may wish to put up in legislation to change the charter, but let it be quite clear: we will never vote in favour of removing a comprehensive nature of the ABC as a broadcaster across Australia. We will be sympathetic to putting in specialised areas to make sure they are recognised for the diversity of our culture and of our country, but never at the expense of comprehensiveness.

We will not support recommendations to destroy the in-house capacity of the ABC to make drama as they have so successfully done in the last couple of decades. We will not support the abolition of an external broadcaster. We will look sympathetically at the idea that it could be a new one‐line budget allocation, but one thing is clear: we will not support an external broadcaster being run by the foreign affairs department or any other government department. Whether the funding line is separate or not, it will have to be run by the ABC under contract so that the credibility of what is broadcast is seen as factual and independent and not the voice of government propaganda. Those are the issues that we lay down.

We hope the government has the guts to admit it was wrong in trying to trample on the ABC and accepts the overwhelming thrust of this report as we do. We look forward to the debate in the community and we look forward, I have to say, to keep rubbing into this minister's grubby face the fact that he tried to fix the ABC. Mansfield has stopped him and we will ensure that he does not get away with fixing the ABC in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Coonan, notwithstanding the emotions in a debate of this kind, I do not think that the description of the minister is appropriate. Would you withdraw?
—I withdraw the description and say that his grubby—
—Your time has expired, so sit down.
—No, I just withdraw and say—

—If you want to have a debate about it, Bill, fine. I withdraw the remarks at your request, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think the minister's track record on this speaks for itself. It is appalling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —What a turn up for the books this really is. I must say, a sense of deja vu pervades this debate about the ABC. I remember being on my feet in this chamber only last November speaking to a motion moved by Senator Schacht. He was alleging draconian cuts to the ABC, and only three months previous to that again, opposition senators were debating yet another similar motion.

SPEECH.PARA: When I spoke to Senator Schacht's motion in November, I spoke about this government's commitment to the future of public broadcasting in this country, specifically about the commitment to creating conditions for creative renewal in the ABC. What do we see today? We see—goodness me!—that now there is some approval of the process we have undertaken!

At that time I also spoke about the need for an independent review of the role and functions of the ABC. That need was met by the Mansfield review—the first such review in 15 years. I can recall at that stage addressing the Senate about the virtues of an independent review and how the Mansfield report would meet that very need.

Since Senator Schacht's earlier motion we can see today a change—that is, the Mansfield report has actually been handed down, and what a different story we see. What a change of tune we have. What do we find? We find that not so very long ago, Senator Schacht noted and, indeed, welcomed—which was just a few minutes ago—many of Mr Mansfield's recommendations. Today's motion even goes so far as to say that Mr Mansfield's recommendations in the Challenge of a better ABC are a complete rejection of the government's ideological attacks on the ABC.

BREAK.PARA: Could this be the same Mansfield review that Senator Schacht told this very chamber had `terms of reference that almost predict the outcome of the review'? They were terms of reference that were `narrow' and `aimed at restricting the ABC from being a broad based national independent broadcaster'. Could this be the same review about which Senator Schacht moved the following motion on 22 August 1996:
That the Senate—
. . . notes with grave concern, the appointment of the Mansfield review of the ABC, with restrictive terms of reference which are clearly aimed at destroying the independence of the ABC;
Senator Schacht was obviously wrong about that because what do we have today? In his motion today he:

(a) notes that the recommendations of the review of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) undertaken by Mr Bob Mansfield, are a complete rejection of the Government's ideological attacks on the ABC—
‐ that is a bit of a turnaround—
(b) welcomes Mr Mansfield's support of Triple J and Classic FM;
(c) notes:
(i) with concern—
‐ and I will be saying something about this shortly—
draconian funding cuts—
alleged draconian funding cuts—
which the Federal Government made to the ABC which led Mr Mansfield to recommend the transferral of program making, except in news and current affairs . . .

The assumption implicit in what Senator Schacht has said is that so‐called draconian cuts were the causal connection for this recommendation by Mr Mansfield. But that is not so. Senator Schacht's about‐face motion then goes on to say:
(ii) that it is in Australia's national interest to have an external broadcasting service.
I do not recall the government ever having maintained anything else. Next, he:
(d) calls on the Federal Government to make a separate funding allocation to provide a service similar to Radio Australia and Australia Television;

We have heard the minister say in the Senate today that it is up to the ABC to do what it likes with its funding. We will secure the funding and, if it wants to have a service similar to Radio Australia or Australia Television, or to maintain it in some form, that is a matter for management. The motion of Senator Schacht then:
(e) supports Mr Mansfield's recommendation that the legislative prohibition on advertising and sponsorship remain; and
(f) welcomes Mr Mansfield's support of regionalisation, with his recognition that radio and television in smaller States and regional areas are critical to community well‐being.

It seems that Senator Schacht has almost run out of superlatives to endorse Mr Mansfield's report. What a change from the motion put forward to the Senate in August condemning the Mansfield review and its terms and predicting dire outcomes for the review.

One might ask: could it be the same Mansfield review that Senator Schacht told this very chamber had terms of reference that almost predicted the outcome of the review? If it did, certainly Senator Schacht did not seem to know what the outcome would be. He said they were terms of reference that were narrow and aimed at restricting the ABC from being a broad‐based national independent broadcaster. It appears that Senator Schacht was not too good at predicting the outcome of the Mansfield review and the government's role in appointing Mr Mansfield to conduct an independent review.

The cynicism about the Mansfield review, which I am suggesting to the Senate cannot be borne out under any circumstances, really is the old chestnut of never holding an inquiry for which you do not already know the outcome. That is not something that this government is party to. Senator Schacht was wrong in being cynical about the Mansfield review, and about the very motion that we are debating today, because he has noted, welcomed, endorsed and seeks support for the recommendations of the Mansfield review. That he is doing that attests to the fact that it was an independent report. The submissions for the Mansfield review involve very, very few Liberal Party supporters—absolutely no branch stacked supporters, no parliamentarians apart from the odd one here or there. This suggests, of course, exactly what it is. It is an independent report. It is not one where the outcome was in any way predicated. That is not the way the government has operated with respect to the independent review.

Mr Mansfield has reaffirmed that `our ABC' should remain free of advertising and sponsorship and that it should continue to provide programming across the content spectrum. The review also reaffirmed the important role of ABC radio's Triple J and Classic FM networks. So whatever criticism anyone in the government had about Triple J, it certainly did not affect Mr Mansfield's view, and it certainly has not affected his recommendation.
The review has recognised the crucial role that the

ABC plays in providing information and entertainment to Australians in isolated and regional areas. Now these are important matters. They are important matters that needed to be reviewed and, having been reviewed, the recommendations are there for all to see.

The Mansfield review did, as asked in the terms of reference—it is only fair to mention this—take account of the government's broader fiscal strategy. Indeed, recommendations in the report reflect the necessity for some belt tightening within the ABC. That is not much of a surprise, having regard to some of the matters that have been referred to in the Senate.

As Senator Schacht, however, has obviously discovered, the Mansfield review was not some kind of veiled attempt to destroy the ABC, whatever fiscal constraints and budgetary cuts were necessary. It certainly was not a razor gang. It was, as the government has been saying all along, an attempt to produce a wide‐ranging and forward looking blueprint to meet the challenge of a better ABC. And wasn't it a good idea, as it turns out, that the government had the foresight to appoint Mr Mansfield to conduct this review?

In announcing the Mansfield review of the ABC in July last year, the government indicated that it sought a redefined role for the ABC—one which strengthens its effectiveness in key areas by better articulating the scope of services and activities. In an article written in the wake of the ABC's own `One ABC' initiative, the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr Brian Johns, described the new structure in the following terms:

The new structure gives practical form to the operating principles that will enable the ABC to secure its place in Australian society—the primacy of quality Australian content, acknowledgment of diverse audience needs, the opportunities opened up by digital technology and efficient management of assets and other resources.
One can say it is clear that even Aunty recognises the need to take a fresh look at herself, and that is exactly what the government was proposing with the Mansfield review.

Much has been made of the Mansfield review's recommendation that program production be outsourced and, in today's motion, Senator Schacht attributes that decision purely to draconian budget cuts—nothing else at all. He does not in any way refer to the reference in the Mansfield report to the fact that there will be huge savings not only in capital and infrastructure but also from buildings that are not entirely utilised, buildings that have to be upgraded and real estate that will not be necessary if some outsourcing takes place.

There is much to be said for the positioning of the ABC in the mould of commissioner‐broadcaster other than possible budgetary savings. Of course, we could not expect Senator Schacht to actually mention any, but I am going to do that. Few have put the case better than Michael Gordon Smith, who is the executive producer of the Screen Producers Association of Australia, in his opinion piece in the Australian on 4 February:
The ABC will provide the best and widest range of programs if there is a contest open to anyone with ideas and skills. That means using the independent sector and outsourcing.

Some of the ABC's most successful programs are already contributed to by the freelance sector, and I will mention just a few. We have heard Senator Schacht refer to Brides of Christ that he has seen three times and I do not know how many times he has seen The Dismissal but, presumably, he now knows what that is all about. In any event, other programs include: GP , Joh's Jury , Blue Murder and Seven Deadly Sins —these are examples of programs that have been made with the contribution of the freelance sector.

Frontline is a particularly pertinent example of an independent product. Frontline was mentioned by Senator Schacht and it is something that we have probably all enjoyed. Frontline is a program that seems to get to the very heart of what goes on in news and current affairs programs. It is an award winning program which has been successfully on‐sold to overseas markets. Incidentally, the original pilot for Frontline was initially rejected by the ABC. If, indeed, there had been some contribution by the private sector, who is to say it would not have been there for all of us to enjoy much earlier in the piece than we have seen?

In its own submission to the Mansfield review, the ABC identifies the option of commissioner‐broadcaster role for itself as one of the alternatives to be considered within the process of restructure. Admittedly, the submission does not address itself to the possibility of outsourcing with the degree of enthusiasm that they might now do. But our national broadcaster indicated a willingness to consider the possibilities—as well it might, because it needs to be flexible; it needs to be able to respond to the sorts of imperatives that it has to face not only in terms of budget but also in terms of the new technology it has to buy.

The options are well worth considering. If one draws an analogy with the role that Triple J plays in fostering Australian music, we begin to see how ABC television may have a role to play in fostering Australian drama. Triple J sees an important part of its role, no doubt, as highlighting new, innovative and adventurous music. I certainly enjoy listening to it. I know that Triple J has now adopted as one of its promos Senator Hill's answer that he was listening to Triple J one morning. It is fostering particularly Australian music in an environment which is not constrained by commercial pressures.

One of the benefits of this approach is the fostering of independent Australian bands recording on independent Australian labels, labels which are small to medium Australian businesses. Similar exposure is given from time to time from artists who have produced self-funded recordings. Why cannot this be used as a model for drama on the ABC? What tremendous possibilities and opportunities could be opened up by similar fostering of independent television production; what exciting and diverse discoveries might there be ahead of us. Greater use of the independent production sector can only benefit the ABC's audience. Most ABC listeners, I would think, do not care very much about who made a program; they care about the content.

An example has been given that having completely in-house production of drama and non-news productions in the ABC is a bit like Triple J having its own band and its own singers—it is an absolute nonsense. The ABC has to go out and employ actors. It has to employ a lot of creative talent; it does not have it all on staff; and it is absolute nonsense to suggest that economies and efficiencies cannot be made by outsourcing.

The ABC has been loath to make a comparison between a commissioner/broadcaster role for itself and the role played by the magnificent Channel Four in the United Kingdom. The ABC points to the fact that Channel Four operates in a larger industry and has `no internal production culture to retain and protect.' These are givens at the current time, but surely they do not preclude us from aiming for the kind of exciting, diverse and, at times, fearless—and I emphasise the word `fearless'—programming for which Channel Four is known throughout the world.

What precludes the ABC from doing this? External bodies already contribute in the vicinity of 28 per cent of non‐news and current affairs programming. The ABC already outsources all its writing requirements, and frequently enters into co‐production agreements to gain access to the skills of creative producers. There is nothing to fear from the ABC undertaking a program of significantly outsourcing its non‐news product.

Recommendations to close Radio Australia, if that occurs, will no doubt be of concern to many people. But, as Senator Alston said today in the chamber, with half a billion dollars given to the ABC and a total cost of $20.5 million this year to run Radio Australia, it is up to management to make decisions about the importance of Radio Australia and ATV and about the place of Radio Australia in the future of the ABC—what role it serves, whether or not it should be retained and if so, in what form. It is not a government decision.

On current information it is almost impossible to find any evidence to really be able to evaluate how effective Radio Australia and ATV might be, or to come to conclusions about how effectively they further Australia's trade and diplomatic objectives in the region. It is very difficult to know, for instance, what role Radio Australia and ATV played in allaying fears expressed in some countries in the South‐East Asian region about the scurrilous Hanson debate. It would be very interesting to know to what extent Radio Australia and ATV might have had a role in that. It is impossible to gauge without further information. It is up to the ABC to decide on the place of Radio Australia and ATV.

The government has welcomed the Mansfield report. It is edifying to see that so many of its recommendations are embraced wholeheartedly by those on the other side, who accept and welcome it. Concerns about outsourcing and about Radio Australia and ATV will no doubt become as hollow as Senator Schacht's motion last August, which was terribly concerned about the terms of the Mansfield inquiry and predicted dire things for the outcome of that report. On any view, Bob Mansfield has provided a blueprint for a future ABC. The government will not be ignoring its responsibilities to ensure that the ABC is given a clear and sustainable role for the future. I said this in, I think, November and I am saying it again today. There is nothing to suggest that this is not a commitment we will honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The notice of motion given yesterday by Senator Schacht calls on the Senate to note `that the recommendations made in the report of the Mansfield review are a complete rejection of the government's ideological attacks on the ABC'. I have to say that the term `complete rejection' there is a trifle generous on Senator Schacht's part. The Democrats believe that certain sections of this report do make recommendations that accord with the government's ideological attacks on the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the report redrafts the charter of the ABC to reflect a dramatically reduced role in the functions and services of the ABC. The revised charter removes key terms such as `innovation' and `comprehensive'—both absolutely key terms. It takes away the requirement for the ABC to deliver educational material and musical, drama and other performing arts programs. So culture and the performing arts seem to go out the window.

It removes the orchestras from the parameters of the ABC. It also removes the terms `high standard', `national identity'—both of those would go—and `international broadcasting', which has been the subject of heated debate over the last couple of days, as we have heard. It removes the requirement for the ABC to deliver programs adding to the cultural enrichment of our society, and it removes the requirement to broadcast specialised programs. In the proposed charter, independence relates only to news and current affairs programs broadcast on the ABC and to no other programming. It is a much diminished charter.

Let us not forget that the leaked cabinet submission—which Senator Alston now says is not his own and he did not sign off on, but which was certainly there before the Mansfield review started—proposed a new charter for the ABC. That charter in that leaked cabinet submission is exactly the same as the one proposed in the Mansfield report. I do not think that is a coincidence. Surely that cannot be described as anything other than delivering the government's ideological agenda, at least as far as the charter is concerned.

What about the call for the ABC to have the majority of its programs outsourced to the private sector? I do not think that Senator Coonan, when she spoke about it, really understood the difference between outsourcing and co‐production. The effect of outsourcing on the ABC would be well and truly negative. The recommendation for majority outsourcing is made at a time when many other broadcast ers, including commercial broadcasters, are moving in the opposite direction, to shore up their production capabilities and rights in a marketplace which is increasingly cross selling its product onto other free to air networks, to pay TV and to other services.

In other words, you want those rights in order to make a substantial profit out of this, and you cannot have those rights taken away from you. Money to the ABC is diminishing all the time, and they have to find other sources from which to get it. One of those sources is to have the rights to co‐productions and to their own productions.

This recommendation does not take into consideration the need for, or the importance of, the national broadcaster engaging in the selling of its productions to other markets. It does not take into consideration the fact that the majority of the ABC budget and its staff is directed to production activity. It is downsizing—another dreadful word—in its most blatant form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sacking!

—Sacking—thank you, Senator West. It also does not take into consideration the experimental nature of program innovation and of production, which have been immensely successful. It is no accident that the ABC is the broadcaster that continues to win industry awards for the material it produces. Senator Coonan also told us that the original pilot for Frontline was rejected by the ABC. I did not notice that it was picked up by anybody else. None of the commercial broadcasters appear to be showing it now. I watch it all the time, and it is on the ABC. So the ABC eventually picked it up—nobody else did. I think that tells us something.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not forget that Mr Mansfield admits he has found no reliable costings—none—to demonstrate where the ABC in‐house productions are higher than those produced by independent production houses. That is no sound basis for such a strong recommendation, particularly for one which the government finds so gleefully nice. It also amounts to promoting the private sector with government money. I should not say government money: promoting the private sector with our money, with my money, with your money, with every senator's money and every Australian's money. This is not the government's money; this is my money as much as theirs.

Would the taxpaying public actually appreciate their money being used to prop up the private sector? I do not. It looks to me as though this recommendation does deliver the government's ideological perspective for the ABC. In relation to funding, the report makes no recommendations—and, yes, I know about all the terms of reference—to reverse the proposed government funding cuts. Indeed, it states that about $500 million is enough to operate a national broadcaster. It does not say why, how or where that figure comes from. I know exactly where that figure comes from. It merely states it as a figure. That figure was picked out of the air by the government and now has become a fait accompli.

The report makes no recommendations about how additional regional services could be funded without axing other key programs, although it acknowledges that those services are extremely expensive. On the basis of Mr Mansfield's report, the ABC will be an even poorer cousin to the private sector than it already is. The ABC has suffered a real cut in funding of 30 per cent over the same period that commercial broadcasters have increased their revenue by 30 per cent. The report is extremely light on detail about how the $55 million could be saved. This does deliver the government's agenda on the ABC.

The report also makes recommendations to divest Radio Australia and Australia Television. Radio Australia is unique in a number of aspects: it is Australian, it is commercial free, it is broadcast in languages of our region, it has a vital role in communications and in cultural education, and it promotes information flow to areas where local media is very restricted. That includes places where it is very difficult to receive anything other than short‐wave radio, such as Papua New Guinea, and it also includes totalitarian and military regimes such as Burma. This is very important and is not considered.

When Jose Ramos Horta, the Nobel Peace laureate, was speaking yesterday, he was talking about how Radio Australia is so terribly important to the people of East Timor who do not get ordinary old news the way we expect it; they get news that is extremely censored and is exactly what the regime in Jakarta wants them to hear, unless they are listening to Radio Australia, in which case they hear an independent news broadcast. That is another reason why it would be a terrible shame for Radio Australia to be run by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and not by an independent broadcaster. Its independence is very important to it in the region, it is very important to its culture and is valued enormously by people who cannot be counted by any independent census of listens. Who knows who listens? The point is: who can listen? This is an extremely small amount of money for the good that it does in the region.

Despite the promises of Better Broadcasting—a wonderful piece of paper which does not mean very much at all—which are in accordance with the governments economic ideology, axing Radio Australia and selling Australia Television is simply a cost‐cutting, mealy‐mouthed attempt to save a tiny amount. In terms of the budget, this is an absolutely tiny amount of government expenditure. There are some other pieces of the motion which was introduced by Senator Schacht that I really should mention. I have mentioned part (a). Part (b) states:
(b) welcomes Mr Mansfield's support of Triple J and Classic FM.

We certainly do welcome the support of Triple J and Classic FM but, in fact, we think that every single one of the radio networks, and the television network, are well worth supporting and we would welcome support of those as well. Part (c)(i) states:
(c) notes:
(i) with concern, the draconian funding cuts which the Federal Government made to the ABC—
how true—

which led Mr Mansfield to recommend the transferral of program making, except in news and current affairs, to independent external producers and to recommend the abolition of Radio Australia and Australia Television.

I am not sure that it was completely the funding cuts which led Mr Mansfield to that conclusion. Whether it was or not, we note with concern the draconian funding cuts and we do not like the recommended transferral of program making, except in news and current affairs. We certainly do not like the abolition of Radio Australia and Australia Television. Part (c)(ii) states:
(c) notes
(ii) that it is in Australia's national interest to have an external broadcasting service.
I guess that is international broadcasting service as well. Part (d) states:
(d) calls on the Federal Government to make a separate funding allocation to provide a service similar to Radio Australia and Australia Television.

I do not know why it should be similar. I think they are quite good as they are, particularly Radio Australia. I should mention there also that Senator Coonan said she wondered what sort of a part Radio Australia had played in the debate regarding the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and her views on race in Australia.

I have just been to Hong Kong with the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Human Rights Subcommittee. We are looking at the transfer of sovereignty to China and, I must say, under the new austerity, we paid for ourselves. We had a very good program. I must say I was shocked by the number of people who raised the words and the views of the member for Oxley with me and when I asked where they had obtained that information from, it was not from Radio Australia; it had come from their local radio and television stations. Most of the people I spoke to gave it as their opinion that the local press particularly quite enjoyed writing quirky stories about Australia. The view in general was that they thought this was just typical and that we had never really got over the White Australia Policy.

I must say that I do not believe that is the view of the vast majority of Australians. Just because a majority of people in one seat voted one person into the federal parliament—who did have `Liberal' after her name after all—when they did not really know her views at the time, I do not believe that a majority of Australians feel that way. I think it is a great shame that local press in particular around the region in South-East Asia have chosen to run those stories when it is not in anybody's best interests that they do. I do not think it is fair on the vast majority of Australians.

But I can assure Senator Coonan that, from what I heard—I did ask everyone who asked me about this, and there were a lot of people who asked me about it in Hong Kong—none of the reports which sensationalised those words came from Radio Australia. In fact, Radio Australia played a really straight bat on it. Radio Australia was reporting exactly what was going on here. That is, therefore, absolutely not any sort of a reason to get rid of Radio Australia.
Part (e) of Senator Schacht's motion says that the Senate:
supports Mr Mansfield's recommendation that the legislative prohibition on advertising and sponsorship remain;

Absolutely. The Democrats have always agreed with that. We did not vote for advertising or sponsorship on Australia Television. We just do not like having advertising or sponsorship on the national broadcaster. We will not vote for it at this time or at any other time. It is just not an option as far as we are concerned.
Part (f) of Senator Schacht's motion says that the Senate:
welcomes Mr Mansfield's support of regionalisation, with his recognition that radio and television in smaller States and regional areas are critical to community well-being.

That is exactly right. We would agree with that. We think it is tragic the way that the current cost cutting has meant that some regions have far less local content. It is an absolute tragedy that that is happening.

That is something that really has to be reversed. There are two ways that that can be reversed. You can cut down on other key programs and you can put the money into the regions. That is not a good option. It is not encouraging the ABC to grow or to be more innovative or to be more comprehensive. In fact, it is encouraging it to be far less. I wonder if that is in fact the government's agenda. The second option is to give them more funding. You can reverse that funding cut. You can put it back to where at least 86 per cent of Australians, according to the last poll, want it to be and you can make sure that the regionalisation of the ABC continues and is not going backwards the way it is at the moment.

To sum up, there are areas in the Mansfield report which the Democrats agree with and for which we are grateful. I think Mr Mansfield is an honourable man and he has done as good a job as he could in the time he was given, but I just do not agree with some of his amendments. In fact, I think that probably his recommended charter was something that was put before him by somebody from the department, with which he probably agreed, but I do not think he wrote it.

I do not think he wrote those words. If he did, it is just an extraordinary coincidence that they accord absolutely word for word with the suggested charter in Senator Alston's—if not Senator Alston's then his department's, because he is denying knowledge of it now—cabinet submission which came before the recommendations of the Mansfield inquiry. I think that that is a particularly interesting point which we should never lose sight of.

It is a great pity that Mr Mansfield has delivered so much of what the government wanted when it actually commissioned this review. On the positive side, Mr Mansfield's findings with which we concur include the retention of the status quo on domestic advertising and sponsorship and the retention of existing domestic networks. That is a terribly important point and one on which I think he should be congratulated for putting down, because I do not think that is part of the government's agenda. I think they wanted to get rid of a couple. We also concur with the independence of news, current affairs and basic information programs—that is absolutely basic and very important. In fact, I believe that the government acceded to that before the report came down.

Another finding with which we concur is triennial funding. That is an interesting one; we will have to see what the government wants to do about that. We concur with current cash flow difficulties being taken into account, another interesting one. It will be fascinating to see what the government does about that. We also concur with the importance of the ABC as an outlet for Australian creativity, so I am glad he has used the word `creativity' somewhere.

But there are key areas of that report with which we have great difficulty. Most of these stem from Mr Mansfield's acceptance of the government's vicious funding cuts for the 1997‐98 financial year and onwards and his acceptance that the national broadcaster can operate on a budget of $500 million per annum. It has not operated on so small a budget for a long time. It is a very large broadcaster. It has a national television network. It has several national radio networks. It runs many more things than Channel 9. Do not compare it with Channel 9. Do not compare it with Channel 10. Do not compare it with any radio network. It is an amalgam of all of those things and it does everything that they do, only better.

We are opposed to the outsourcing of the majority of non‐news and current affairs television productions. It has not been convincingly demonstrated that this would lead to a genuine reduction in costs to the ABC or to programs equal in quality to those currently produced in‐house.

The relative size of the Australian broadcasting marketplace invalidates any comparisons with the UK or the US. As far as the sale of real estate assets is concerned, this looks a lot like short‐term expedience with the serious risk of creating long-term cost.

The Democrats see no problem with the report's emphasis on the importance of services to regional Australia. Despite the technological revolution, regional and rural Australians are still plagued by the tyranny of distance and will be for a long time yet to come. Those difficulties cannot be underestimated, but the ABC should not be expected to provide programs to those regions at the expense of other Australians—at the expense of urban Australia. You cannot forget that the vast majority of Australians live in the capital cities and they should be able to see the ABC to the same extent as regional Australians.

The ABC should be adequately funded to broadcast the same high quality, comprehensive, innovative product to every single Australian. With the possible exception of news and current affairs programs, the implementation of all of those recommendations would leave the ABC exposed to having to provide the leftovers of broadcasting—programs that commercial stations reject as too boring or too expensive.

Mr Mansfield recommended many changes to the charter. They can only be concurred with by parliamentary approval. We will give careful consideration to them. I heard Senator Schacht say that the Labor Party would give careful consideration to them. We really ought to note that we should all be extremely wary of any changes that weaken the charter. The Democrats will certainly not be voting for any changes that weaken the charter.

The removal of the obligation for international broadcasting almost certainly comes under that category, especially with regard to Radio Australia. I cannot understand how anybody could maintain that Radio Australia is not one of the best and most important parts of our foreign policy. It is difficult to accept that times are so tough in Australia that we cannot afford to pay the ABC to produce Radio Australia. They are so tough that the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Sir Julius Chan, yesterday offered to help us pay for Radio Australia because it is so important, as he said, to every Papua New Guinean.

I cannot believe that times are so tough in this country that we would damage our international reputation, standing and influence in our region to such an extent just to, firstly, save a minuscule amount of money in the budget and, secondly, punish the ABC. I find it extraordinary that anybody could even consider such a thing. It reminds me extraordinarily of the DIFF scheme, although I hate to say such a thing.

If a lot of these recommendations in the Mansfield report are implemented, they will prevent the ABC from functioning effectively or efficiently. They will lead to the continued shedding of staff and programs for all audiences. This is a disaster for every audience in Australia. This government's obsessive determination to punish the ABC hangs like a death shadow over every one of its actions on the ABC. You cannot help wondering why they have done this. Every time the ABC is mentioned, you cannot help wondering why this is happening and what the real reason behind this is.

The leaked cabinet submission on the ABC vividly showed the difficulties that faced Bob Mansfield when he undertook this review. I have never doubted Mr Mansfield's integrity and I do not doubt it now. But I do not doubt how history will judge this report. I believe that it will be judged as a tool in the coalition's orchestrated campaign to strangle the ABC and ultimately force the ABC into irrelevance whereby it can be gotten rid of. That is the stupidest move—I said it yesterday and I will say it again—that this coalition government has made. It will be seen at the next election to be the stupidest move this coalition government has made.

People will vote based on this. The government has no idea how many letters and phone calls I get on this. The government probably does have an idea, because Senator Alston probably gets more than I do. If that is the case, he is getting thousands of letters on this. I do not think he is asking Mr Johns to personally reply to every one of them—I doubt it very much—but he is getting those letters. He must realise that this is a big mistake on the government's part. Sooner or later, they will pay for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the chamber as moved by Senator Schacht reflects the opposition's consistent stance in support of the ABC and its recognition of its importance to Australia in providing a broad range of services to the Australian people. Labor has a clear commitment to a comprehensive, independent and properly funded ABC. That sentiment was strongly reflected in the submissions by 10,616 persons which were received by Mr Mansfield in his review of the ABC. I can think of very few other Australian institutions that would evoke such strong public support and reaction amongst ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the recommendations made by Mr Mansfield are commendable; the opposition acknowledges that. We welcome particularly the support of the highly successful Triple J service and Classic FM. They are networks which were only recently introduced. They represent part of an expanded role for the ABC as it met more fully its charter under the previous management of David Hill. The ABC today is a much stronger organisation than it was even 12 years ago. It is the strength of that organisation that this government fears. It is the commitment by the Australian people to that organisation that this government fears.

I am particularly pleased with the way in which Mr Mansfield advocated the retention of the legislative prohibition on advertising and sponsorship for the ABC. This prohibition is a central point in the ABC's present charter. Labor has strongly supported that position for many years. Unfortunately, Mr Mansfield had very restrictive terms of reference. He was forced to respond to the government's predetermined program in terms of its budgetary bottom line. It is in that context that Labor opposes a number of the recommendations which Mr Mansfield has brought forward. We believe that a number of the recommendations in Mr Mansfield's report, if implemented, would weaken the ABC and narrow the focus of its services and capacity to serve Australians. It would, particularly if its services in the international arena were reduced, weaken Australia's reputation within the broader international community.

It has been quite clearly a very difficult task for Mr Mansfield. He has undertaken it with some skill; we have to acknowledge that. He has been forced to conduct a review in the context of quite a determined government campaign. This government has launched a cynical, predetermined, premeditated campaign; its cabinet documents quite clearly reveal that. On the other hand, this government has a minister in charge of this area who, in many respects, is able to pursue an agenda which he is firmly committed to, despite in earlier days his commitment to broad liberal philosophies.

This agenda is essentially geared to the function of reducing the capacity of the ABC to meet its charter and commitment to the Australian people as a comprehensive, independent broadcaster. That is really at the heart of the government's campaign to reduce its budget by $55 million annually. The impact of that will be to reduce its capacity to service the Australian people and meet the demands of the Australian people for a comprehensive broadcasting service.

The government's problems are quite immense in terms of trying to implement this agenda. How can they provide for a budget reduction of some $55 million for an institution which is so widely respected within the community at large and so strongly supported internationally? How can they do this when they have employees who command great respect and admiration amongst Australian people at large? How can the government do this when in opposition they made so many statements in support of a policy which is quite clearly contrary to the one they are pursuing in government. I recall only recently that this minister signed off a report entitled Our ABC where he committed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure he signed off.

—He did sign off on that. He may have forgotten about his signatures on other matters, but he did sign off on that. In March 1995, Senator Alston was chair of the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations—another inquiry set up to get the ABC. It started from the premise of a presumption of fault on the part of the ABC. Do you remember the terms of reference for that inquiry? They were so clearly aimed at fixing the ABC for their alleged misdemeanours.

SPEECH.PARA: When the committee examined the evidence they could not demonstrate the claims being made in the terms of reference as originally put before this chamber. What they found was that the basic structure of the ABC was sound, the organisation was considerably stronger and more relevant to the Australian community than it had been 10 years earlier and it was strongly placed to meet the challenges ahead.

I recall only too well the debates that took place in that committee. The committee supported the maintenance of current funding levels in real terms and supported favourable consideration of any application for the provision of additional funding to ensure the viability of new joint parliamentary and ABC approved charter activities.

This minister sought to woo the arts community and the general public during the election campaign with a policy which he quite clearly never intended to carry out once in government. It strikes me that it takes considerable political skill to engineer a backflip of that dimension.

The minister's response has been quite clear. First of all he has been able to get his colleagues to attack its credibility in the public mind. We have seen numerous attacks upon the ABC in terms of its alleged political correctness and its incapacity to meet the demands of the Australian people. We have seen attempts to silence internal dissent within the ABC—particularly in relation to changes to the board.
