We have seen a slashing of the budget which engenders a wide sense of fear, intimidation and disillusionment within the ABC, which directly saps the morale of the organisation and the capacity of the organisation to defend its legitimate role within Australian society.

The government set up a review which is supposed to provide the straight track on which the budget bottom lines are delivered and on which the conservative political agenda, which has been well documented throughout the 1990s, will be delivered. What happened? The review came down with findings which quite clearly do not meet the needs of this government. When the real problems emerge we see that this government blames other people. That is par for the course for this government, and this minister in particular. He finds it necessary to blame other ministers, blame his office and blame other persons for the government's failure to keep this agenda secret. What we have found is that when he is finally caught out he says that he is just the loyal soldier doing what he has been told.

What strikes me is the extraordinary capacity of this government to evade, to engage in double speak and to be deceitful in the way in which it camouflages its strategy. The actions of this government are crystal clear. Most of the industry understands that the government's strategy revolves around attacks on the integrity of the ABC. In recent times, we have seen the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, Mr Kennett and other senior Liberals make comments which seek to denigrate the ABC and undermine public confidence in the ABC—one of the great Australian institutions.

In June last year the Prime Minister entered the fray with his unsupported accusations that there had been political correctness in the ABC to a fault. There had been allegations that the ABC concentrated on one political point of view. Nothing could be further from the truth. I am sure many on this side of the chamber would be quick to say that the ABC has, on many occasions, offended the Labor Party in the way it has presented issues. I will not say that that has always been justified, but this claim that the Labor Party gets special treatment from the ABC is totally incorrect. In my judgment, the ABC has maintained its independence in its coverage of politics in this country.

I recall that in March 1996 Mr Kennett was somewhat less than subtle, as he often is, when he described the ABC as a great leech on society. He stated that if he had his way he would close it down. He said that he felt it was a view shared by many of his federal colleagues.

In the cabinet submission the government undertook a program to get the ABC board to accept its agenda. We know that that is quite contrary to the legislative framework within which the ABC is supposed to operate. The government, through their cabinet submission and cabinet processes, set out to get the ABC to acquiesce to this campaign of denigration. They sought to ensure that a review would produce results that they thought would be compatible with their political interests. The whole problem is that Mr Mansfield has not delivered the report that they were seeking. The Mansfield review was designed to justify the savage expenditure cuts and to politically nobble the ABC in a manner which would suit the Liberal Party.

Mansfield's review has not done that. Mansfield has quite rightly, I think, acted with integrity and produced a report which, of course, does not justify the cuts that are being made to the ABC. He rejected the criticisms of bias and supports past actions of the ABC. He rejected attempts to significantly narrow the focus of the ABC. He supported the ABC's role as a comprehensive provider—and I think that is a fundamental issue in terms of the question of public discussion about the role of the ABC. He sought to broaden the philosophical outlook, in terms of the ABC, within his report, and he quite clearly reflected the widespread community support that the ABC enjoys.

As I said, what has occurred with Mansfield's report is that there has been a substantial rejection of the government's ideological attacks upon the ABC. In that context I am quite certain the minister has not welcomed Mansfield's report. He has not welcomed it. He is obliged, of course, to say encouraging things about Mansfield, but quite frankly, within the context of the political agenda set down by Senator Alston, Mansfield has not fulfilled his expectations. Of course, it is in this regard that Mr Mansfield is to be commended. It is unfortunate that he has had to respond, and felt it necessary to respond, to the government's review in terms of the budgetary allocation for the ABC: a budgetary reduction which we believe is nothing short of vandalism.

Of course, we strongly disagree with Mr Mansfield's contentions in regard to recommendations which would have a severe impact on the capacity of the ABC to function as a comprehensive broadcaster. Mr Mansfield's recommendations, when combined with the government's budget cuts, do produce a picture which would see the ABC stripped of many of its staff, many of its creative assets and many of its strongest performers, in terms of providing that comprehensive broadcasting service. The result of the budget cuts will see the reduction of some 300 jobs, which will affect all aspects of the ABC's operations, but, of course, would substantially reduce the effectiveness of the ABC when you look at the impact of those job losses on programming.

That, of course, is going to be the case, particularly, on metropolitan radio. We see another 600 jobs are scheduled to go as a result of the budget targets, which will have a severe effect on radio networks and Australian content on ABC television. On top of this, I think some of Mr Mansfield's recommendations, if implemented by this government, would see a further reduction of 1,300 to 1,400 jobs. Two hundred of these jobs would be lost by a push to contract out ABC support services.

Mr Mansfield's recommendation that a majority of the non‐news and TV production be contracted out could result in as many as 1,000 jobs being lost within the ABC. In my home city of Melbourne that would have a dramatic impact on the creative community and, of course, would have a dramatic impact on the capacity of the ABC to produce distinctly Australian programs, such as Janus, Phoenix and the other great productions that have come out of Melbourne.

With regard to radio, I fail to see how contracting out of production could not result in a major deterioration of programming. The experience of the BBC, which has been driven by its government to undertake a similar ideologically determined position, has seen, quite simply, a reduction in the quality of service of the BBC.

If we look further at the job losses, we see that another 170 jobs will be lost if this government proceeds with its recommendation to abolish its international broadcasting services and to scrap what I regard as the very important services provided by Radio Australia. Of course, I do not have to remind the Senate, I am sure, of the impact that that would have on Melbourne, especially given that the Melbourne complex at Southgate has a very significant component providing services for Radio Australia. This was the very point that this minister made in opposition about the ABC and these were the concerns he expressed at the time about the loss of services for the ABC in Melbourne. Once again, we see the hypocrisy come shining through.

Mr Mansfield was forced, in his judgment, to choose between international and domestic broadcasting, at the behest of this Liberal government's agenda. That is essentially the framework in which he had to operate, as he saw it. Radio Australia is clearly viewed by the government as a major sacrificial lamb to be slaughtered in its determination to extract funds from the ABC. It would save some $20 million if it was ever implemented and, of course, it would provide some movement towards the achievement of the $77 million of savings targeted for over the two‐year period.

Quite clearly, once again, this is a position that stands in very sharp contrast to the pre‐election commitments this government made when it was in opposition. On Radio Australia, coalition policy was quite emphatic and many Australians could be forgiven for believing that this government actually meant what it said when it was in opposition. Hopefully, by now, they would understand that that was a mistaken view. Hopefully, they understand, by now, that this government is quite clearly made up of politicians who are prepared to say and do anything to secure power.

But the Liberal opposition at the time stated bluntly—quite bluntly—that Radio Australia `has a proud place in the ABC'; it recognised that Radio Australia has served the expatriate community and other nationals in our region for half a century and that Radio Australia's existing services would not be prejudiced or downgraded in any way. That is what the Liberal Party said in opposition. That is quite clearly not what the minister is saying now.

The minister's downgrading of the value of Radio Australia is quite clearly in sharp contrast to the commitments that he made to the Australian people prior to the election. I think it is quite extraordinary for him to say in this Senate, as he said yesterday, that because short wave transmission, as a technology, is declining, there is—somehow or another—a justification for the removal of Radio Australia.

What is quite clear—I am sure he would be only too well aware of this—is that there is a strong movement within Radio Australia to move to satellite and on‐line technology. It is no longer simply confined to short‐wave technology. He would equally be aware of actions within the BBC to commit to short‐wave radio for the next 20 years. As a technology it is still very useful. But to say that the ABC is stuck in the past, as he is trying to suggest, is quite clearly a cynical misrepresentation of the facts.

As the former chairman of the board said yesterday in an article in the Australian, to suggest that because short‐wave radio is declining as a technology that is a justification for the closure of Radio Australia is like suggesting that because telegraph is an obsolete technology within postal services that should in itself be a justification for closing down Australia Post. Quite clearly that is a ridiculous proposition. But that is essentially what is being argued here. Because there are changes in technology, we close down the organisation; whereas instead we should be looking at ways and means by which the service can be provided on a more effective basis.

It matters little to this government that Australians will ultimately suffer as a result of such a policy, because Australia will become less influential amongst its regional neighbours. Australian culture and Australia's capacity to be able to project an independent democratic view in this region will be lessened. It is extraordinary that, when we spend so much time trying to present Australia to the international community in a positive way, the very service which is so respected should be closed down as result of a budget measure. That is extraordinarily short-sighted as far as I am concerned.

The debate over Radio Australia emerges at a time when our regional neighbours are increasingly questioning this government's long-term commitment to the region. Given some of the domestic developments on issues concerning our relationship with Asia, this could not come at a worse time. It would appear that it matters very little to this minister that the axing of Radio Australia is in quite sharp contrast to the position put by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. To suggest that somehow or another it can be taken over as some sort of public relations arm of DFAT is quite clearly an insult to the intelligence of the Australian people. It is counterproductive in terms of the presentation of this country in a positive manner within the region. It plays into the hands of those like the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), who has a view of Asia which strikes me as being terribly counterproductive to the interests of this country.

There are quite serious implications from this debate, not just in immediate terms on the basis of this government's integrity and its capacity to say what it means and to operate on the basis of some political morality, but also in terms of the future cultural development of this country. The ABC plays a vital role in ensuring the development of Australia's cultural integrity within this region. In a domestic sense it plays a role in ensuring the capacity of all Australians to have their views, their aspirations and their values reflected in a credible way through a public broadcaster like the ABC.

It is indeed an extraordinary irony that the government of Papua New Guinea can offer $1 million to provide such a service to this country. How extraordinarily paltry an attitude it must be from this government to find itself being offered advice from New Guinea on such matters as this.

It is important for the Labor Party that the ABC is properly defended by this parliament. We have an obligation as a parliament to ensure that the comprehensive independent nature of the ABC is protected from a predatory government which is committed to the destruction of this organisation and whose assurances made prior to the election cannot be believed.

The government are committed to the destruction of the ABC for quite base ideological reasons. The comments that they have made to the contrary are absolutely legendary. It does show the cynicism with which this government approaches government and, more especially, the cynicism with which this government approaches the Australian people. They have enormous political difficulty in persuading the Australian people that the ABC is not worthy of support, so they have set upon a program to try to persuade them of that, but they are failing miserably. The Mansfield report demonstrates just how miserably they are failing.

In that context, Mr Mansfield is to be commended. The ideologically determined attacks on the ABC by the Tories in this country—the philistinism of this government—is not being supported by the community at large. The Australian people deeply value the ABC. The Australian Labor Party fully supports the ABC in its capacity to operate as a comprehensive independent service provider to the Australian people. In that regard we welcome Mr Mansfield's acknowledgment of the commitment from the Australian people to the ABC. We reject wholeheartedly this government's determination to undermine and white‐ant that commitment.

The motion before the Senate is appropriate. It acknowledges that the draconian funding cuts by this government cannot possibly be supported by the Australian people. The government's cynical attempts to attack the ABC will be rejected by the Australian people. We acknowledge that it is in the international interest of this country to ensure that there are external services and to ensure that the comprehensive nature of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's charter is widened and deepened, not narrowed and undermined. In that capacity we call upon the federal government to make separate funding allocations if necessary to provide for Radio Australia and Australia Television.

Quite clearly, many of Mr Mansfield's recommendations should be supported because of their refusal to accept the legislative prohibition on advertising and sponsorship that have been so strongly challenged by elements of the extreme right within the Liberal Party itself.

Finally, we welcome Mr Mansfield's support of regionalisation with its recognition that radio and television in smaller states and regional areas are critical to community wellbeing. These are all sentiments that this government acknowledged the importance of in opposition. We call upon them now in government to put their money where their mouth is, to acknowledge the commitments they made and to fulfil those commitments to the Australian people. We call upon all senators to support such a worthy proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also in support of the motion moved by Senator Schacht, recognising the valuable contribution and service that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides these days to the whole of Australia and to many overseas places: to expatriate Australians but also in the language services to people of non‐English speaking countries. The ABC provides them with a service of news and information about Australia and about world events that can be seen to be objective and analytical in its content. For some people it is the only alternative point of view that they are able to hear.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we heard the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) say that there were a small number of letters from people in the People's Republic of China—or from China; he did not say whether it was the PRC or the Republic of China and Taiwan. But I would suggest to the minister that he should think carefully about the ability of people in some of those countries—not necessarily in China—to communicate with us in this country. Certainly, people in Burma listening to Radio Australia on the short wave are not going to be writing to anybody at the ABC or to anybody in Australia to say how good the ABC is. The last thing that they want is for SLORC to identify the fact that they are getting information and news from anywhere other than that tyrannical regime.

For the minister to dismiss the number of responses and therefore the number of listeners as being insignificant is to show gross ignorance of what the conditions are in some of those countries, particularly Burma—I will single out Burma—where human rights do not exist, where protest can well be met with death, and writing to and listening to the ABC could be seen as protest.

People say we do not know how many of these people there are. Sure, you do not know how many because there are people out there listening whose lives depend on the regimes in the countries in which they live not knowing that they are listening. I think it behoves the minister to take that argument and that consequence into consideration when he is entering into this argument about the ABC and Radio Australia.

The ABC is a very important service. For a number of people in this country, the ABC is the only radio service, the only television service, to which they have access. I am really pleased to see that Mr Mansfield recognises in his report the importance of rural and regional services provided by the ABC.

In the report he has quoted John Cobb of the National Farmers Federation saying why they in fact rely on ABC Radio more than their parents' generation did because there are fewer people working on farming properties in isolated and remoter areas of Australia. There are fewer people working there and there is less outside communication and interaction with people, so the radio becomes the source of their interaction with the outside world. We have certainly seen some changes in access with the use of portable radios, transistors and such things.

Many of us who grew up in rural areas grew up—and people still grow up—knowing only ABC Radio. I certainly grew up in an area that is not all that remote and isolated but where, of an evening, the radio reception on anything other than the ABC was totally impossible. So we were forced to listen to the ABC. That is where you become totally dependent on that source of entertainment, music and information.
I thoroughly recommend the comments that John Cobb is quoted in the report as making. Following some of Mr Cobb's comments that are recorded in the report, Mr Mansfield says:

I am very strongly of the view that the ABC's Charter should establish a clear obligation for the ABC to maintain a regional presence and to broadcast programming with a regional focus. Unless this is done, the temptation will always exist for management to cut in these areas because it could provoke a less audible outcry than cuts in areas where the strength and volume of opposition may be greater. I believe this would be a genuine tragedy if it were allowed to occur.
I could suggest to Mr Mansfield that the audibility of the outcry if rural and regional ABC Radio in particular were tampered with would be one that he would not need any amplification to hear.

I think that that conclusion he has reached is a little bit inaccurate because I put to you that people in rural and regional Australia will complain a lot more loudly than people in the city areas about any tampering and any cuts to their ABC because, as I said earlier, for many of them that is the only source they have. So I want to see it in the charter—I think it is very important—but I say a word of warning to Mr Mansfield that I do not think that it is a totally correct assessment. There might not be the volume of people there but there is no choice of alternative media in the bush like there is in the city and there are therefore many more people listening.
I have some concerns though. At the bottom of page 24 it states:
I do not propose to recommend minimum levels of regional programming. I believe that the ABC Board and management should have responsibility for determining the appropriate mix of services including:
. the balance between radio and television services;
. a mix of local and networked programs;
. the level of specialised programming for regional audiences (such as rural programs and reports); and
. the extent to which regional studios contribute to national programs.

I have concerns that he is not prepared to write into the charter anything other than that there should be a clear obligation to a regional presence. I am not sure what his definition of a regional presence is. Is a regional presence just putting a service emanating out of a capital city on to the translator and sending it across the network? Just how much here has to be answered? How much are they talking about local production, local content? These are important issues.

Currently, with the ABC regional service—on radio at least—in most parts of rural and regional Australia, we get locally produced programs and programs emanating out of the local station starting at 6 a.m. and going through to about 11 a.m. The rest of the time, from 11 a.m. on, it is networked. It might be produced for regional Australia—that is, non-metropolitan Australia or maybe non-Sydney and Melbourne Australia—but it is networked. You do get breaks for local news at 12.30 p.m. and at 1.30 p.m. with a weather bulletin but the rest of the time until about 6 o'clock at night, until PM comes on, it is regionally networked. So it is emanating out of one or two studios across Australia.

After 6 p.m., it is the same service that is heard in the capital cities and everywhere else. I am not saying that it is not a good service and program, but I want some clarification. I think it is very important that we are aware that when we are talking about localism and regional focuses we are talking not just about having a translator there and having access but also about the content that emanates from the rural and regional areas.

There are some differences that I see when I look at couple of the recommendations. Recommendation No. 6 talks about rural and regional; recommendation No. 7 talks about the `provision of services for children as a programming priority'; recommendation No. 8 also talks about youth services; and recommendation No. 9 states `That the ABC should make use of Australia's creative resources'. That is fine. Then we get on to recommendation No. 15, which states:
That the ABC moves to outsource the majority of non‐news and current affairs television production over the next three years.
I see some conflict there because there are many very good programs that are sourced and produced within the ABC for rural areas and specifically designed as rural programs.
The same goes for children's programs. They are made in-house. I am thinking of Bananas in Pyjamas and Playschool

TALK.START.PARA: —That we all watch.
—We do all watch. There are some very big kids in this world. I am too old to have grown up on Playschool because television was not in this country when I was old enough to go to preschool.
—You poor old thing.
—I know, Senator Calvert. You were there ahead of me, though.
—You're not that old, surely?
—Unfortunately, yes.
—You don't look old, Senator.

—Thank you, Senator Brownhill. As you and I well remember we did not grow up with Playschool , but many of our children did and our grandchildren are still growing up with Playschool . Parents get just as much joy and delight watching Playschool with their children now as they did 30 years ago when they were children.
—The fastest growing interest in any children's program in the USA is Bananas in Pyjamas .
—That is also a very interesting comment from Senator Neal. It has been very important. At least Bananas in Pyjamas teaches them how to say `Z' correctly, too.
—`Zee'.
—You have been watching too much Sesame Street , Senator Forshaw.
—That's on afterwards!

—I just want to draw people's attention to the point that there is a push and a move for outsourcing of the majority of non‐news and current affairs programs. Senator Schacht spoke very eloquently about the need to maintain a critical mass. That becomes very apparent when you think about the need to ensure and maintain that we have the production capacity for rural programs such as Landline . But there has to be a cooperative effort with programs that are put to air on both radio and television.

SPEECH.PARA: When I think of the ABC I tend to think of it as a structure somewhat akin to a tree and that the rural programming area is one of the big branches. But you have other branches: you have Radio Australia, you have Triple J, you have Australian Television, you have the orchestras, you have the classical FM stations and you have Radio National. When we know there be will be a cut of $55 million to the ABC, we have to cut into that tree somewhere to make that saving.

I do not know how you cut into a tree without causing it permanent damage by just lopping off a whole limb, because in a strong wind that affects it balance; it blows it over. You ringbark it. I think this $55 million cut is basically akin to ringbarking it. We all know that many trees, most trees, do not survive ringbarking. I have grave concerns about the future of the ABC if we see these big, wide, mad slashes into the ABC.

I am glad also that there is a recommendation in here from Mr Mansfield about maintaining Triple J. I am forced to listen to Triple J because my staff, my younger members of staff—and that includes staff over the age of 30, particularly here—always have Triple J on. So I am forced to listen to Triple J in my office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought they would have had the Senate on.

—No amount of my pleading, orders or anything else will make them switch off Triple J. It was very interesting when the people of Cobar in western New South Wales were given a choice of Radio National or Triple J. The community was in uproar. There were public meetings and hundreds of people at those public meetings because they were being offered Radio National and they wanted Triple J. They were given Triple J. The kids in Cobar are happy and the parents are happy because the kids have something to listen to. They have sources of information. I keep saying to the parents, `Listen to the words,' but the parents are happy.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had no complaints about Triple J from this area. The kids, the adolescents are getting information they require, are hearing programs that relate to their needs, are hearing thoughts expressed that express the turmoil that they may well be feeling as they go through adolescence—and adolescence is not an easy stage. So this becomes vitally important. Obviously the people of this country, be it in the country or the city, like Triple J.

BREAK.PARA: We have seen the expansion of the Triple J network cancelled. That is a shame. This means that many in the smaller areas and rural areas are going to miss out. That is something the government should really think very closely about. They are going to have to review their cabinet submissions. They are going to have to review this again when it goes to the ERC in the current budget process.

It is of vital importance that these programs that are in demand, that are some of the most popular programs on any radio station in Australia, that have a listening audience that no other radio station can match because of the content, are continued. The content is pitched to the market and the market likes the content, and that is why they are listening. It is for no other reason. It is the content they want. It is vitally important that it is continued.

It concerns me greatly that Senator Coonan talked about Triple J's effect upon the rock music industry in Australia because it allowed a number of small bands to actually get airplay, to progress and to make their way in the world and then likened that to program production. I would remind Senator Coonan there is a vast difference between program production and the work that would go into a series and an independent person or a group making a record. When you have a production house, you do not want to be stopping and starting. Senator Coonan likened this to record production in the rock areas, and we all know that there are many bands and many groups that come and go. We cannot afford to have that sort of thing happening in the production area.

The ABC has been at the forefront with its own record label in the regeneration, the extension and the rebirth of the country music industry in this country. It has had a major input into the regeneration of that. That has proved to be the boom for so many artists, for so many people in this country, and has led us to not only being internationally competitive on that but also providing jobs for people. But they do not seem to be caring too much.

I have concerns when I think of the future. Let us look at the cabinet submission, particularly at attachment D, which is the coordination comments. The Department of Finance was `strongly opposed to the submission's recommendations' because `the submission provides no strategy for achieving the required contribution by the portfolio to the government's savings targets'. It cautioned against the review that was proposed because:
They would create an opportunity for the ABC's constituents to place pressure on the Government to retain or expand the ABC in its current form.

How right they were—11,000 submissions. I wonder what Finance's reaction is going to be to the Mansfield report. I wonder what is going to happen next time in the ERC because we all know the stories of Finance—that is, they are a legend in getting their way or almost being like a lover slighted. They do not like having their recommendations ignored, particularly when they state openly that it would create an opportunity for constituents to place pressure and, as I say, 11,000 of them did. Treasury is critical because it:

. . . notes that the Minister's recommendations do not identify means of achieving savings of $50m commencing in 1997-98, as was the clear intention in ERC's decision of 3 June. The Minister's earlier submission noted that the introduction of advertising on the ABC could achieve revenues of this order, thus allowing budgetary savings without reducing the overall funding available to the ABC for the provision of its services.

But, of course, Mr Mansfield has come out saying there should be no advertising. So Treasury's obviously going to have to send the minister back again to say, `Where's the $55 million going to come from because that particular source of the $50‐odd million revenue', according to Mr Mansfield—and I have not heard anybody reject this position—`should not be involved in advertising.' I wholeheartedly agree.

One of the reasons for watching the ABC is that you do not get rotten ads all the time. You can actually follow a program and not have your train of thought interrupted. So I would suggest people look very carefully and ponder what those two departments have said because they have certainly sent a warning there to the minister that they did not like and did not agree with what he was proposing.

In winding up, I would like to draw attention to an area that I am getting a little concerned about and that is things we read in papers such as yesterday's. One of the things we are very proud about the ABC for is its editorial independence and its board's independence. But yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald had a headline on page 5 of `Warning of stark choice for the ABC'. The article said:

. . . the Minister . . . has warned the national broadcaster that it must quickly implement recommendations to contract out most of its television production or risk being left behind in the 21st century.

When the minister is saying these sorts of things one has to wonder how much independence the ABC is going to be allowed to have under its new charter. I hear some of my parliamentary colleagues in rural areas saying, `We will not see the ABC changed out here. I will give you a guarantee.' One again has to wonder just what this government is doing to the independence of the ABC. That is another issue that people need to monitor very closely.

The Mansfield report has done some good things. It has outlined a number of very important issues. The previous speakers have outlined a number of very important points. I wholeheartedly support the position and the motion of Senator Schacht. The ABC is a national institution. The ABC is of the utmost importance to all Australians and has significant international consequences and values as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in this very important matter of general business and to support the motion put forward by Senator Schacht. Yesterday in this chamber we debated a matter of public importance relating to the ABC and the Mansfield report. In particular, we highlighted the double‐speak, the deception and the failure of the current Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) to honour the promises so solemnly made both in opposition and at the last election campaign.

BREAK.PARA: During my contribution yesterday, I highlighted from the report entitled Our ABC, from the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, the clear, unambiguous recommendations put forward by that committee. I remind the Senate that that was a committee instigated and chaired by none other than Senator Alston, the then shadow minister.

There is no doubt at all that, after quite an extensive series of hearings by members of the committee involving public submissions and submissions from government departments and from the ABC itself, the recommendations put forward in that report represented the position of the then opposition. It represented the public position of the then opposition on the ABC. But we know that they have always had another position. They had an under‐the‐table position. We know that because they have always had this view that whenever they could get the chance, if they ever got into government, they would get stuck into the ABC. They would try to reduce its funding, emasculate its activities, narrow its services and direct its operations.

That report that Senator Alston brought down as chairman of that committee contained many fine recommendations supported by all parties. It was entitled Our ABC. Of course, we now know that the real agenda of the then opposition, now the government, was that the term `Our ABC' really meant the coalition's ABC. That is what they really wanted. But they continue to maintain this fiction—this facade—that they support an independent, effective and well‐funded public broadcaster.
In that report in March 1995, one year before the election, on the subject of funding Senator Alston said:

The Committee therefore recommends that where the Parliament requires the ABC to undertake new Charter activities or to expand existing Charter activities, it should provide funds sufficient to ensure that existing activities are not adversely affected.

Remember that recommendation, honourable senators, when you consider what this government has in store for Radio Australia and Australia Television. Remember what that recommendation from Senator Alston said when you look at what was put before the cabinet in the budget considerations last year: proposals to get rid of Radio Australia, to sell off Australia Television and to return to the budget funds that had been advanced to the ABC for the development of pay TV.

That is the complete opposite of what was being recommended only 12 months earlier and clearly was being put forward as the considered views of Senator Alston, which was to provide more funds for these additional charter activities. In that report, Senator Alston and the committee went on to recommend:
The Committee supports the maintenance of ABC funding at least at its current level, the continuation of the triennial funding arrangements and the continued application of the Non-Farm GDP deflator.

Time does not permit me to go into the complex debate about the non-farm GDP deflator. The clear expectation is for more funds but, certainly, it is a recommendation for maintenance at its current level and also a recommendation to continue triennial funding. They were the recommendations of Senator Alston in March 1995 in his own committee's report. It was a select committee set up at the instigation of the opposition at the time, the coalition, to look into the activities of the ABC.

Some other recommendations in the report demonstrated some of the real intent of the then opposition—the now government—and Senator Alston. For instance, they recommended that any future ABC board member nominee should appear before a parliamentary committee to be grilled about their credentials for such an appointment. Talk about political control! What sort of a recommendation was that?

I have to acknowledge that the person who was appointed as the new chair of the ABC, Mr Donald McDonald, was a good appointment. I have met Mr McDonald on a number of occasions in his previous role with the Australian Opera and I believe he is a good appointment, notwithstanding his quite clear political allegiances to the Liberal Party and particularly to the Prime Minister (Mr How ard). I honestly hope that Donald McDonald takes notice of most of the recommendations in the Mansfield report and ignores the pressure and the undoubted intimidation that will come from this government as it prepares to get stuck further into the ABC.

This government has made a habit of cutting funding to government departments, to government instrumentalities and to enterprises and then setting up an inquiry to review their operations. Senator Vanstone did that in higher education. She ripped 10 per cent or so out of the budget—$1.5 billion out of higher education—and then set up a review and said, `We're going to have a look at how it is all going and how it is going to survive in the future.' We are already seeing the effects of that, and the review has only just started.

Similarly, on this occasion the minister for communications has gone to the cabinet with two options on funding. One option is to take $55 million out of the budget of the ABC, get rid of triennial funding, impose the efficiency dividend and set up a review—and see how the ABC can function after that. The second and more draconian option is to get into them in a big way right at the outset and take a minimum of $135 million out of their funding, which is over 25 per cent of the ABC budget. That is what is put forward by this minister.

There is no proposal in line with his own representations that says, `Let's actually maintain the existing levels of funding for the ABC and maybe let's even look at giving them some extra funds so they can do some of the things that need to be done, such as upgrading the equipment and expanding the Australia Television service.' No, none of that. The options are to cut $55 million, cut off one arm; or cut $135 million, cut off both arms and probably a couple of legs as well—and then have a review. In that context, there is no doubt that they expected the review to be something that would deliver them the opportunity to hop into the ABC further.

Now that Senator Alston has been exposed and found out with the leaked cabinet documents, he continues to try to obfuscate his way through his clear breach of promise. We know that, on election night, he used the same words to Jim Middleton as he used in the recommendation in his own report:
Jim Middleton: First of all the commitment close to home about the ABC and commitment to maintain funding in real terms of the coming parliament, does that stand?
Senator Alston: Absolutely.

He said he was going to honour all their commitments. Of course, that was also in their policy. Their policy was to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC. Senator Alston says, `That was only really for the first year of the coalition government.' There is not a person in Australia who believes that and, increasingly, we see that the word of this government cannot be relied upon.

The minister forgets things. The Prime Minister forgets things—forgets things that are so important that they could never be forgotten. The minister does not know whether he or his office prepared a submission. He could not recall whether he had signed off on it. Frankly, the minister thinks up an excuse on his feet on the spur of the moment, ducking and diving to get out of what is clearly acknowledged to be a breach of coalition promises.

But Senator Alston has been found out because in his own cabinet submission he acknowledged that it was a breach of the coalition promise. It said up there on the front page that the options examined in the submission were inconsistent with the government election commitments. He acknowledged that he told the cabinet that these two options were going to get the government into a lot of trouble because the people were going to complain that it is a breach of the election commitment.

So what happened? The government set up the Mansfield review and there is no doubt that they gave the Mansfield review riding instructions. But, fortunately, the overwhelming response of thousands of Australians—representing, I would submit, millions of Australians—made it abundantly clear to Mr Mansfield that he should act independently of this pressure and come down with a report that backed up the ABC.

There is no doubt that if you look at the actual report of Mr Mansfield, you will see there, contained in the appendixes, what this minister was looking for. First of all, he had the $55 million taken out of their budget. Secondly, he had clearly in mind further cuts.

In the terms of reference he talked about a more focused role for the ABC; that is what the government seeks. He also said that the review should `have regard to the need for consistency between the cost of future ABC operations and the Government's broader fiscal strategy'. Well, we know what the government's broader fiscal strategy was—reduce the budget of the ABC.
In the media release issued by the minister, contained as Appendix 1, he stated:
The government will be undertaking a Review of the ABC which would re‐define and re‐position the national broadcaster for the 21st century.
Redefine the national broadcaster in the image of this minister and the coalition. Further, the media release states:

In examining the ABC and the very significant future funding pressures which its many activities are likely to place on the budget, the Government has decided that the current level of funding cannot continue indefinitely.
Of course, they took away the $55 million, imposed the efficiency dividend and suspended triennial funding. Further in his media release he said about Australia Television:
The Government will also ask the ABC to explore the possibility of delivering the services currently being provided by Australia Television more efficiently.

The Government will discuss with the ABC Board the scope for ensuring the maintenance of ABC program content on Australia Television . . . while tendering the operation of the service to the commercial sector.

That is what the minister said in his media release at the time that the inquiry was set up. It is all consistent with what was in the leaked cabinet document because in that document statements appear such as that either option will mean the loss of some ABC services. It was acknowledged that services like Triple J, Classic FM, Radio Australia and Australia Television could disappear.

What the government also had in mind was eventually to have the opportunity legislative ly to get further stuck into the ABC. What they were hoping to get out of this report were proposals which might give them the opportunity to narrow down substantially the ABC charter. Fortunately for all Australians, Mr Mansfield did not cop it.
Let me just very quickly go to the report. On page 11, Mr Mansfield acknowledged that he received many submissions questioning the need for review of the ABC's role and functions. He went on:
Because of the ABC's demonstrated capacity to deliver quality programming over the last 64 years, there is a strong view among its audience that it should be left alone to get on with the job.

When you look at all the other submissions that were made, which recognised the value of specific parts of the ABC whether it be television or radio, it is clear that they overwhelmingly supported the view that, really, this review did not have to take place; that the ABC was going along pretty well as it was; it could do with some more funding; and the public did not want it being slashed to pieces.

I know my colleague, Senator Gibbs, wants to make a few remarks in this debate so I will finish on this note. But I hope to have an opportunity on another occasion to contribute further. The bulk of the recommendations of Mr Mansfield are very good. What he has done is re‐endorse the role of the ABC as a comprehensive broadcaster and recommend that most, if not all, of its services should be retained. He has particularly acknowledged that it needs certainty of funding through triennial funding and that it should have increased funding because it should be able to retain the proceeds of any sales of assets.

But I must say that I am particularly concerned about his proposals on Radio Australia, on ATV and on outsourcing—and others have spoken about that—because there is no doubt that they are important services that the ABC provides. There is no doubt that Mr Mansfield came to the conclusions that he did because it was already clear to him that he had Hobson's choice, that the government had ripped away the funding—the $55 million—and that something had to give if that was going to continue. He was forced to look at what may be sold off or closed down.

But, in any other circumstances, there is no doubt that even he would have recommended the importance of those operations. As he acknowledges, there may still be a place for them to continue, albeit in another form. We reject those recommendations but we understand the context in which they were made even though they should not be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting Senator Schacht's motion, I particularly want to welcome the support that Mr Mansfield gave in recommendation 6 to the regional services that the ABC provides. I also want to call on the government to make a separate funding allocation to provide a service similar to Radio Australia and Australia Television. In doing so, I would like to point out to the senators opposite that the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Sir Julius Chan, has written to the Australian High Commissioner, David Irvine, expressing `considerable concern' about the moves to terminate Radio Australia broadcasting services. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: As you are undoubtedly aware, Papua New Guinea, as a developing nation and regional focal point, has come to depend on Radio Australia as representative of excellence in broadcasting.
He has offered to take a $1 million dollar cut to aid for PNG to help save Radio Australia.

In a large state like Queensland, the regional services provided by the ABC are essential in providing a good quality of life to the local population. The news and current affairs services, the quality programming and the various sports programs are essential in giving people in this vast continent a choice. I was always under the impression that the good senators opposite held dearly to the philosophy that everyone should have a choice.

The people of regional Queensland cannot go to the latest opera, classical concert or other cultural events as can the people in Sydney or Melbourne. The ABC's Classic FM provides a wealth of classical music that can be enjoyed by those who enjoy this type of music. Similarly, not everyone in regional Queensland or regional Australia can afford to travel to one of the capital cities to see their favourite concert or watch their favourite football or netball team play a major game.

The ABC also produces some quality children's programs. Children in more isolated areas have a right to receive programs such as Play School which are watched by children around the country and are educational as well as fun for young viewers. The presenters of Play School are virtually mobbed by their young fans when they go on tour. It would be a sad indictment of this government if the children of the United States of America could enjoy characters like our Bananas in Pyjamas and the children of rural and regional Australia could not. It is essential that these characters and programs are adequately funded.

Reminiscing, I am sure many of my fellow senators tuned into the ABC daily to listen to Jason and the Argonauts, a program which taught children to, among other things, write, and encouraged an interest in exploration. How many, like me, were Argonauts? For generations, the ABC has been the social fabric of Australia. It has provided rural Australia in particular with a wide spectrum of entertainment and information. Even programs like Blue Hills provided relief and light entertainment to many women isolated on large properties.

The ABC also provided, and continues to provide, the capacity for quality public debate on numerous issues. Quality public debate can only be carried out when the community is educated, informed and aware of all the issues involved in any particular debate. The ABC provides the forum for such public debate. It provides information on issues in an unbiased way and free from political interference and commercial considerations. It does not have to make a choice on whether or not a subject has enough market appeal to bring in adequate revenue from advertising. It makes a moral decision on whether the public needs to be informed. It also does not have to create sensationalism and demean the entire quality of the television medium. Listening to the ABC is about choice and about quality. Although it depends on individual preferences, there can be some pretty poor alternatives to the ABC in some regional areas.

BREAK.PARA: There are many viewers and listeners who prefer the ABC. There are also many who appreciate the fact that there is no advertising on the ABC. Another point that this motion supports is the legislative prohibition on advertising and sponsorship.

Is this government going to support the maintenance of these regional services? When it comes to the vote on this motion, it will be interesting to see whether senators opposite will support ongoing services to regional Australia. After all, many of them claim that they represent the regional and rural population. I am sure that the voters in regional and rural Queensland will be very interested in how my government colleagues from Queensland vote on this motion.

On a broader note, the funding of a service similar to Radio Australia is of vital regional importance. We are, after all, very close to South‐East Asia. There are many smaller countries and poor countries that cannot afford to provide the type of quality television and radio broadcasting services that the ABC provides. Australia provides not only a service that assists such countries, but, in doing so, develops a supporting relationship with these countries which can stand it in good stead in the future. There are countries in the area which do not have access to a local uncensored radio news service. Are we going to let the Voice of America be the only alternative available to these countries. Do we want people in these countries to learn more about Australia and what we are doing, or do we want them to have America—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allotted for the consideration of general business having expired, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of committee reports and government responses, but first I call Senator Kemp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time today, Senator Faulkner asked me a question and I said I would refer the issue to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) for additional information. I now have an answer. A copy has been given to Senator Sherry and I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Question without notice of Senator Faulkner to Senator Kemp representing the Minister for Administrative Services on 6 February 1997

Minister, did the Department of Administrative Services brief the Minister for Administrative Services on the nature of the offences of the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services, Senator Woods. If so, when did this occur?
Minister, did the Minister for Administrative Services then brief the Prime Minister. If so, when did that briefing take place?
Response of Senator Kemp
The Minister for Administrative Services has advised me of the following:

My Department did not brief me directly on the alleged offences or their nature. Rather, a senior officer of the Department informed my senior adviser that the AFP had foreshadowed an inquiry concerning Senator Woods' use of entitlements. This was done on a strictly confidential basis and no detail was provided.

Shortly thereafter, and following a confidential conversation between my senior adviser and an adviser to the Attorney‐General, the Attorney‐General informed me of an investigation into Senator Woods' use of entitlements. No further detail was provided.
The Attorney‐General's conversation with me occurred in either September or early October 1996.
I did not brief the Prime Minister as the Attorney‐General had informed me that he had already done so.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 February, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Seante take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with interest that I rise to speak briefly on this tonight. This is a joint committee report. I am not on the joint committee, but I know of some of the very good work that they have done. I am interested that they have selected Indonesia as one of the countries to include in the report about the sale of Australia's service exports to that country. We also have had handed down today the government's response to the report on the inquiry into the abolition of the development import finance facility, otherwise known as DIFF.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the countries that was a DIFF recipient was Indonesia. It seems a little bit incongruous that we are debating this joint standing committee report on the export of services to Indonesia on the same day as we have before us the reply from the government on DIFF. It just strikes me as a little bit unusual.

The report of the joint committee points out that Indonesia is the world's fourth most populous country. It has a growing middle class but, as the report also points out, it has emerging budget deficit problems and a growing foreign debt. There are remaining inequities between the well off and the poor, unsettled industrial relations, a shortage of skilled labour and a challenge involved in maintaining a strong export performance.

In the DIFF inquiry we heard from a number of DIFF applicants who had been involved in Indonesia and who had been, through DIFF, providing, or attempting to provide, services to that country. One of the best witnesses we had before us gave us information about proposals to take education to the rural areas and the remote islands of Indonesia for those children with disabilities. Because of the cancellation of DIFF, this program will not go ahead. The provision of education for children with disabilities in the remote rural areas and the remote islands of Indonesia will be delayed because this government wants to abolish the DIFF program.

There would have been opportunities in the service export area for small companies—despite what the minister said, they are only small businesses—to get together to form consortiums to provide these types of services. If the DIFF program had continued, these companies would have had better potential and better ability to export further services into Indonesia. But this government has chopped off, at the first step, the ability of Australian companies to export services to that country.

It seems to me exceedingly short sighted on the part of the government to do this because it is depriving Australian businesses of export potential. It also seems to me extremely uncaring that there should be no social compassion for the needs of young children in the remote areas of Indonesia who have disabilities.

It is a sad indictment of this government that it does not look at the total perspective of the needs of Australia and our industries. It is prepared to chop off a program that benefited Indonesian children with disabilities living in remote areas and it is prepared to chop off the potential for Australian companies to increase their service exports to that country.

If we had been able to get these programs up and running, the wealthier countries that could have afforded to buy these services would have been able to see them. They would have known what they were going to buy, and known what they had the potential to achieve. They would have learnt from these programs. But, no, not this government. It hops in and chops the lot.

The government's response to the committee reports—the majority and minority reports—was `Does not accept this recommendation. Does not accept this recommendation.' Even in the minority report from the government members, the government was not prepared to amend the terms of reference for the Simons review on the advice or the suggestion of the government members. One has to wonder what sort of budgetary decisions are being made by this government when it is not prepared to take any notice at all of its government members who have sat through many days of hearings.

It just strikes me that there is—I do not want to say double standards—certainly a great contrast when we look at the report that deals with Australia's service exports to Indonesia. I am not saying that we do not have the potential to do a lot of work in this area. What I am saying is that you do not just look at one aspect of how you can conduct business and one thing you can do in Indonesia. You have to look at what you are going to do across the board for the country.

DIFF was an excellent program—a first‐class program. There are many small companies in this country that were able to gain a foothold with our neighbours in Asia. They were able to get a toehold in the business and sale of industries in Asian countries. We need to encourage them to grow and to export. We need to give them an opportunity to learn about what is required when you are exporting to our near neighbours, where there is a different language and culture. English is not their main language. We English speaking countries do have a fairly arrogant attitude that everybody else should speak English and that, if you do not speak English, then you are somewhat of a lesser person.

People who have been involved in trading in the area are learning very quickly the importance of learning that language. Those companies that were involved in DIFF learnt very quickly what a valuable product it was. The abolition of it must have an impact. It was predicted by these companies to have a major impact on the sale of our export services to these countries. For that reason, the government is to be severely criticised.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., I propose the question:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a very small amount of the Senate's time this evening to add a brief note to additional comments on a matter I raised in May 1994 concerning language standards. On that occasion, I drew the Senate's attention to the poor usage of apostrophes on the two information tablets situated in front of Old Parliament House. At that time, a constituent of mine who was visiting Canberra was aghast at the incorrect use of the apostrophe by whoever had prepared the information. After being told that the matter was too costly to correct, I was happy to later receive information that the signs had in fact been corrected. While I am by no means attempting to set myself up as a perfectionist in these matters, I am most concerned at what appears to be a general decline not so much in the actual standards of correct spelling and grammar usage but rather in people's attitudes to whether it even matters. Just recently, I had some correspondence with the Kellogg breakfast cereal company over their marketing usage of the letter `K' to the extent that they were putting in front of Australian school children each morning a product with the word `complete' spelt `Komplete', as in their product Komplete Muesli.

SPEECH.PARA: While their response to my raising this concern with them was sympathetic and understanding, they were unprepared to accept that their actions did anything harmful towards the process of educating Australia's children to spell correctly. I wish to disagree. Senators themselves may be well aware that their staff members are generally guided by personal computer spelling systems which correct documents using an American system of spelling. While this is not always a problem, it sometimes offers suggested spellings that are not totally appropriate to common Australian usage.

Another problem I am constantly faced with is the inappropriate use of the apostrophe in the word `its'. `Its' is only lengthened with the inclusion of an apostrophe when the word is the shortened form of the two words `it is'. A common error is to write `its' with an apostrophe or `it's' without the apostrophe or vice versa. As with much of our distinctive and confusing English language, this is a matter that is best learnt by knowing the particular situation rather than trying to rely on the application of broad rules.

Finally, I refer to another common error in usage, which is regularly to be heard, dare I be so reckless as to say it, even on our venerable ABC. This concerns the difference between `less' and `fewer'. For these words, there is a very simple guide. `Less' refers to quantity while `fewer' refers to number. As I say, I am not a perfectionist in these matters and I have no doubt broken multiple rules of grammar over the years, even in this speech. However, when one sees simple errors used with such regularity, it raises some doubts as to whether our standards are being held in as high regard as they once were.

In this place, it can be reasonably expected that most people have received a little more than basic education. Let us try to set good standards in some of these simpler matters. At the same time, I think it is appropriate that I take this opportunity to compliment the Hansard staff on their high standard of use of the English language. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of Senator Watson's last comment, with which I concur, if it were not for Hansard, the combined might of politicians in Australia would wreak far more havoc on the English language than Kellogg could ever possibly manage.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some remarks on the adjournment debate tonight in response to the document called A northern focus, the statement issued by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), which Senator Tambling spoke about on the adjournment debate last night. That statement is the federal government's response to the report of the Committee on Darwin. Senator Tambling will not be surprised to know that I have a different view from him on the benefit of this report to the Northern Territory.

I note in doing so that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Tambling) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Shane Stone, have publicly welcomed Mr Sharp's statement. Indeed, Mr Stone and Senator Tambling have both claimed that it is a `shot in the arm for Territory development.' I beg to differ. The minister's statement is a crude and offensive attempt to rewrite the recent history of Commonwealth involvement in northern development in order to mask the Howard government's appalling lack of commitment to the region.

But I guess we should be thankful for small mercies, at least on this occasion. Senator Tambling and the chief minister are attempting to at least sing the same tune on this important issue. The reason I make that point is that I have a copy here of a newspaper clipping from the Northern Territory News of 30 June 1995, which clearly demonstrates that they were very much at odds when the Wran report was released in June 1995. The newspaper story, which was quite a prominent one, is headed `Wran report puts CLP pair at odds'. The opening paragraph says:
Chief Minister Shane Stone and CLP Territory Senator Grant Tambling disagree about the worth of the Committee on Darwin report, released yesterday.

Senator Tambling is quoted in this report as saying that the Wran report was a waste of money. He described it as `a feeble and politically safe document'. The chief minister, on the other hand, recognised the worth of a number of the committee's recommendations and described the reports from the 18 consultancies engaged by the committee as `an enormous resource', which indeed they are and remain.

You get the sense from reading the minister's statement that it was written by someone in Canberra with instructions to lower the boom firmly but gently. This begins in the first two paragraphs with a completely erroneous statement that the previous Labor government tabled the report of this committee in June last year in the Senate `almost as an embarrassed afterthought'. The minister then claims that the Wran committee report was `a damp squid'—I am sure that the minister meant to say `squib'—which failed to capture the potential and spirit of optimism about one of the country's most dynamic and outward looking regions. This misrepresentation continues with the claim that the Darwin based Office of Northern Development began life in 1992 under a meaningful charter but `lost its way in latter years' and `lost credibility' across the north as the federal government's main source of information and advice and, thus, influence with Canberra.

Now, sadly, the Office of Northern Development is just lost. The Office of Northern Development was lost when this minister decided last year to close down the entire Regional Development Division of the De partment of Transport and Regional Development, with the loss of 220 jobs. This was announced without any warning before the budget last August in order to lop $150 million off the budget bottom line. You may recall that the minister issued a press statement at the time stating:
There is no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development.

I said at the time, and it remains the case, that this is the most appalling statement—emanating from Canberra and affecting those living outside Sydney or Melbourne—I have seen in my 20 years in politics.

I venture to suggest that when the minister took the decision to lop off the Regional Development Division he probably had no idea that the Office of Northern Development was actually housed within it. Certainly, this came as a complete shock to his parliamentary secretary at the time, Senator Tambling. He was literally struck dumb by the closure of the office. The Darwin media could not get a word out of him.

I am not surprised because the decision came only weeks after Senator Tambling, who then had prime responsibility for regional development, had given public assurances that the Office of Northern Development would not be closed. Senator Tambling pointed out in the press statement announcing his appointment as parliamentary secretary that he had been given particular responsibility for regional development. Now that they have closed down the division Senator Tambling has moved to Social Security. I am not surprised.

The Office of Northern Development was involved in a range of key projects when it was closed down. It resulted in the loss of more than 20 jobs out of Darwin. Importantly, it was also coordinating the work of the joint territory‐federal government task force which was progressing the implementation of the Wran committee recommendations.

It was also busily implementing a major research effort to develop a regional development program for the territory. Let us not forget that the Howard government took the decision to close down the $150 million regional development program before it had even received the McKinsey report, which it had commissioned at cost of $700,000 and which was designed to help it decide on the future of the program. That report found that after only 18 months under the previous Labor government, the regional development program had made a significant start in rejuvenating leadership in Australia's regions.

At the time the Office of Northern Development was closed down I said that it was a victory for the bureaucrats in Canberra who had never made any secret of the fact that they were distinctly uncomfortable with the concept of a highly credible Darwin based Commonwealth agency which was free to range across all portfolios and actually got something done. I said that it also clearly showed the Northern Territory had lost its voice in government in Canberra. If you have any doubt about that, have a look at the press release issued by Senator Tambling on this matter and the statement issued by the minister. The key points in both those statements are exactly the same word for word.

Senator Tambling simply recycled his former master's voice for local consumption. In essence, the statement says that the Office of Northern Development will stay closed. The Howard government will not pick up the recommendations to fund the establishment of an AusAID regional project office in Darwin. It will not maintain a continued AusAID presence in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade office in the city.

I was interested to see that it adopts the same position on the proposed construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway that the former Labor government had in office—that is, the key to getting it built is private investment. This is after years of whingeing about this position when in opposition. It also says that the government will continue with Labor's $850 million defence build‐up in the north which is underpinning continued economic development in Darwin. It picks up a whole range of initiatives from the previous government and then seeks to claim them as its own.

There is not one single new initiative from this government for northern development. Senator Tambling came into the adjournment debate last night and recycled large chunks of the minister's statement. He claimed, as Minister Sharp has, that this government's response to the committee report follows `extensive internal discussions within the Commonwealth bureaucracy and various departments and had very open consultations with the Northern Territory government'.

What neither of them told the public, but what I know to be true, is that most of the work on the federal government's response to this committee had been finalised when it came to government. The lion's share of the work had in fact been done by a high level joint task force comprising federal and Northern Territory officials in February last year—just before the federal election.

Senator Tambling would recall this because he issued a press release during the campaign, as opposition spokesperson on regional development, claiming that the Wran report was `good research,' which had been gathering dust on a shelf somewhere in the Treasurer's office. We reminded him at the time of his previous position, as reported in the Northern Territory News on 30 June the previous year, which I have already referred to.

We then went on to point out to him that the then Minister for Regional Development, Brian Howe, was in fact the man whom Senator Tambling was supposed to be shadowing and not the Treasurer, who had carriage of the government's response. We also pointed out that Mr Howe had announced the appointment of the task force in November 1995 and the final Commonwealth officials paper on the 77 recommendations were due to be considered at a meeting of the joint task group in February last year.

Needless to say, I do not think that Senator Tambling, in terms of his statement that this response is a shot in the arm, has any credibility on the issue. The government's response is not in fact a shot in the arm for the territory; it is a shot in both feet. I must say in closing that, if I have committed the unforgivable sin of getting the apostrophes wrong, I am sure that Hansard will correct them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I will be turning the Senate's attention once again to the failings of accountability in government. You may or may not be aware of recent revelations in Western Australia surrounding the activities of the Court government's former planning minister, Mr Richard Lewis.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole period of Mr Lewis's time as planning minister has been fraught with controversy. Recently he has been the subject of a continuous barrage of criticism from the media and members of the community when it came to light that he made a number of controversial planning decisions during the period of his caretaker duties between 14 November and 9 January.

The caretaker convention requires there to be no controversial, sensitive or major decisions made by government from the time an election is called until a new government is sworn in. In Western Australia people do not have access to a readily available system to appeal against administrative decisions made by public servants and ministers such as they enjoy in the Commonwealth. The existing administrative system lacks comprehensiveness and consistency. In some important areas of government action, there are no appeal mechanisms at all.

As Mr Lewis's recent actions demonstrate, there is also the problem that where an appeal is possible it may be taken before a minister who can arbitrarily make decisions at his or her sole discretion, without giving reasons. This is an unacceptable state of affairs.

The potential for corruption in the exercise of such powers is considerable. This is an area where there are some gaping holes in which executive fiat may operate unchecked and where the decisions of the minister are not subject to appeal or review.

The Commonwealth Administrative Appeals Tribunal and other state appeals bodies, where they exist, believe that a comprehensive, coherent and objective administrative appeals system improves government effectiveness, efficiency, openness, transparency and ac countability and promotes higher standards of government administration and service.

The fact that a planning minister in Western Australia is able to determine administrative appeals raises enormous implications and questions of accountability. This fact was dwelt upon and recommendations, so far unheeded, were made by both the royal commission into WA Inc. and the Commission on Government inquiry.

The royal commission into WA Inc. reported that these sorts of ministerial powers and structures in government administration lead to improper, corrupt or illegal conduct. The inference of impropriety that automatically arises where a minister is involved in a determination of administrative appeals not only is unfair on the incumbent, but means that the system itself is brought into disrepute.

Two factors unquestionably facilitated the actions and events leading to the royal commission's inquiry into the administrative system. The first was the state of the administrative system itself. It was notable for its complexity, fragmentation, gaps in effective lines of accountability, lack of standardisation and susceptibility to the corrosive effects of political influence and manipulation.

The second was the imposition upon that system of changes in the style and practice of administrative government, changes which were by no means unique to Western Australia, but which were not matched by safeguards which could protect the system itself from debilitation.

The royal commission made a number of recommendations as to the reform of the administrative system. With regard to the state of the administrative system itself, the royal commission recommended that a complete review of its structure and organisation was required. However, the commissioners reported that it was inappropriate for the commission to undertake this review—that was the responsibility of the government—but that they would recommend some of the principles and constraints which should inform that review.

The royal commission into WA Inc. reported in 1992, five years ago. The WA govern ment has yet to implement the recommendations and make changes to its administrative system. The manner in which the administrative system is presently structured, managed and regulated puts the public and at least parts of the system itself at risk. The commission's recommendations were aimed at minimising those risks, and the government's irresponsibility in continuing to maintain the status quo is unconscionable.

The Commission on Government, which made its findings on the review of administrative decisions in July 1996, made a number of recommendations which included removing the power from ministers to determine administrative appeals. The Commission on Government recommended that an administrative review tribunal, which I will refer to as ART, should be established to help ensure administrative justice and thus act to prevent corrupt, illegal and improper conduct.
