The commission reported that the practice of ministers reviewing administrative decisions suffered from the perceived lack of independence and concern that partisan considerations could intrude on or influence decisions. The commission also recommended that there should be only one tier of external review and the proposed administrative review tribunal should become a single point of contact for any person seeking a review of any administrative decision made in the Western Australian public sector.

Aside from consolidating the structure of the administrative system and removing referral to the minister for the determination of administrative appeals, the commission was concerned that the public should have confidence in the accountability of the proposed ART.

The commission recommended that the operations and effectiveness of the ART should be open to public scrutiny and that it must operate in an open, transparent and accountable manner, be subject to the jurisdiction of the Auditor‐General's department and produce full annual reports and proper performance indicators.

The Court government's failure to implement the recommendations of both these inquiries—a royal commission and its own appointed Commission on Government—demonstrates that the coalition in Western Australia is not concerned with preventing any appearance of or actual impropriety or corruption in government.

The government's disregard of the importance of its accountability to the people of Western Australia is epitomised in the recent activities of the former planning minister. During the period of caretaker government, Mr Lewis was busy overturning local council decisions on highly controversial matters at a time when he was accountable to no‐one. These decisions were not made by Mr Lewis, the managing director of a business—which is the unfortunate way coalitions throughout this country seem to view government—but were made by a minister of the government that ought to be accountable to the people.

Under no circumstances should the need for an extensive and comprehensive system of administrative decisions review be underestimated. Proper review of decisions which are disputed is an essential requirement for accountable government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in the adjournment debate I wish to very briefly address the government's response to the inquiry into the abolition of the development import finance facility—DIFF. The government's response to the inquiry into DIFF has identified what the government senators have asserted since the inception of the inquiry, namely, that it had been clear coalition election policy to abolish the DIFF scheme in its current form.

SPEECH.PARA: Given frequent criticisms of claimed merits and failings of DIFF as a means of efficiently delivering Australia's humanitarian aid obligations, it was high time that an independent review was carried out. The announcement of the Simons review well before the DIFF inquiry came to fruition clearly demonstrates the government's commitment to an independent review as to the place of a reformed mixed credit scheme to deliver aid.

The Simons aid review has broad and wide ranging terms of reference which certainly comprehend an examination of the efficiency of DIFF as an aid delivery mechanism. The majority's concerns regarding the time and nature of any replacement mixed credit scheme are premature given the review currently under way.

As to the majority recommendations regarding projects that were in the pipeline at the time, the minority report clearly spells out details about the legal obligations and procedural considerations and drop‐out rates which counter the likelihood of claims that companies in receipt of a mere letter of advice would ultimately proceed to fruition.

Of course, projects that had received an actual offer were allowed to proceed and certain other projects of high priority in receipt of a letter of advice were also funded. It must have been patently obvious, following the government's decision to abolish the program, that any attempt by the opposition to secure continued funding for projects just in the pipeline in 1996-97 through the committee process was to be of little avail.

Unfortunately, the terms of the Senate inquiry and the findings of the majority and witnesses invited to give oral evidence, who were almost invariably beneficiaries of the scheme, were heavily skewed to the conclusion that DIFF projects provided an ideal mechanism to deliver developmental objectives and commercial benefits.

In the absence of any definitive review, the developmental outcomes of some of the projects were simply subjective and anecdotal. While there was some evidence to support the notion that concessional finance schemes can and in fact have produced positive outcomes where the project has sufficiently targeted humanitarian outcomes, reliance on responses from financial beneficiaries without more was clearly flawed.

Scant attention was given to the fundamental question whether the clear commercial benefits to individual companies, in particular industry sectors, in fact provided net commercial benefits to Australia at an acceptable cost to taxpayers. Throughout the duration of the inquiry, committee members did not access all information necessary to form a concluded view as to DIFF's net economic benefits to the Australian economy. It is a question

BREAK.PARA: which requires resolution in the interests of the continuation or implementation of any concessional finance scheme. Taxpayers have a right to know where their money is going and the demands for securing value for money should not be dismissed.

It is possible that further refinement of the selection process, the feasibility study requirements and the framework for conducting needs analysis may have improved the effectiveness of aid delivered via the DIFF scheme. However, as the scheme operated to 1 July 1996, DIFF clearly did not provide for effective aid delivery in a consistent manner, despite the anti‐poverty benefits of some individual projects. So its abolition should not have caused such an outcry.

Not since the Fitzgerald review has a review been given the charter to rethink how foreign aid can be delivered in consideration of poverty reduction, the development of permanent humanitarian outcomes and commercial objectives. There is much scope for the Simons review to be imaginative in its findings. It is to be hoped that the Simons review will address the matters material to the
future of Australia's aid program and the place of a reformed mixed credit scheme. I welcome the government's response.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 18 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the exclusion of Royal Australian Navy members who were engaged in the Malaya Emergency 1955‐60 from eligibility for benefits under the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act 1956 (the Act):

(1) Are the members of the Royal Australian Navy contingent of the Far East Strategic Reserve in the Malaya Emergency considered to have been on `active service' at any time within the 1955‐60 period.
(2) Were the members of the Royal Australian Navy involved in the Malaya Emergency subjected to additional operational risks at any time within the 1955‐1960 period.
(3) How are the terms `active service' and `allotment for special service in an operational area' linked.
(4) Why was the Royal Australian Navy the only force serving in the Malaya Emergency specifically excluded in the Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. It should be noted that the term `active service' has no meaning in relation to repatriation legislation.

(3) They are not. These terms are defined for the purposes of two distinctly different pieces of legislation for distinctly different reasons. The term `active service' is used in relation to discipline under military law while `allotment for service in an operational area' relates to repatriation legislation.

(4) The Royal Australian Navy was excluded under the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act 1956 in relation to service during the Malayan Emergency. In response to a question from a Government member as to why this was the case, Dr Donald Cameron, Minister for Health at that time (1956), replying on behalf of the Minister for Repatriation, stated:

They are not regarded as being subjected to additional operational risks. They are subjected to the risks of the service for which they engage, and therefore their conditions are in accordance with the terms of their enlistment."

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the senator representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 28 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a 100 per cent interim increase in the maximum permitted concentration of cadmium in peanuts been recommended by the Australia and New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA).

(2) Is this doubling in the permissible level of this highly toxic heavy metal being recommended prior to a review of all cadmium standards using established procedures, and in contravention of the commitments of the Authority's own May 1995 workshop to minimise cadmium exposure of the community by maintaining current maximum permitted concentrations and examining reviewing these downwards.

(3) Is it a fact that peanuts imported from China consistently show cadmium contamination above the existing Australian food standards maximum permitted level of 501g/kg. (corrected: not 50mg/kg, as in original)
(4) Would the effect of the Authority's recommendation be to allow the importation of peanuts from China with levels of cadmium above the currently permitted maximum.

(5) Is the Minister or ANZFA aware of any advice from the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS) given to representatives of the Chinese Government that the maximum concentration of cadmium permitted in imported peanuts would be doubled.
(6) Is it a fact that a shipment of cadmium-contaminated peanuts from China has been sent to Australia and is being held in bond.

(7) Is the Minister or ANZFA aware that this shipment has been sent as a consequence of advice from AQIS about the proposed relaxation of standards, and that it is merely awaiting the implementation of the recommended new standard before being released onto the Australian market.

(8) Is the Minister or ANZFA aware of any threat by the Chinese Government to retaliate against Australian wheat exports to China unless Australia's food safety standards are relaxed to permit the import of peanuts contaminated with cadmium at levels up to twice that which is currently permitted.2.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The proposed interim maximum permitted concentration (MPC) for cadmium in peanuts of 0.1 mg/kg is consistent with the proposal published by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA) as part of the review of cadmium standards. There is no toxicity from cadmium below the internationally accepted safe level of intake of 70 1g/day/person and surveys show Australians are ingesting approximately 10—15 1g/day/person which indicates no concern for public health and safety. Peanuts contribute a minor fraction of this daily intake. Contrary to the statement in your question, there was no commitment at the 1995 workshop to maintain current MPCs for cadmium and it was recognised that several MPCs were established without adequate data and cannot be realistically applied.

(3) It is understood by ANZFA that the regular surveillance of imports of Chinese peanuts has detected a proportion of shipments of peanuts with cadmium levels above the current maximum permitted concentration.

(4) If accepted, the Authority's recommendation will increase the maximum permitted concentration of cadmium in peanuts. This will allow the entry of some Chinese peanuts which are currently excluded.

(6) I am advised that shipments of peanuts originating from China have been found to contain cadmium in excess of the maximum permitted concentration. Peanuts are being held by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. The importers have been informed of their options under the Imported Food Control Act 1992.

(8) ANZFA has received correspondence from a Chinese import and export company raising the maximum permitted concentration of cadmium in peanuts as a potential trade issue. Officials from the Chinese Embassy have met with the Chairperson of ANZFA to express their concerns in relation to the Australian MPCs for cadmium in peanuts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 5 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) fail to approve the new Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) antiretroviral drug, nevirapine, at a meeting on 3 and 4 October 1996.

(2) Was Nevirapine unanimously recommended for marketing approval by the United States Food and Drug Administration's (USFDA) Antiviral Drug Advisory Committee, and subsequently approved by the USFDA, in June 1996.
(3) Will ADEC's failure to approve Nevirapine delay for several months marketing approval and access through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
(4) Does the Minister agree that these kinds of delays in accessing new HIV antiviral drugs can hasten the onset of HIV‐related illnesses and death for people with HIV infection.
(5) Is the Minister proposing to take any action to remedy the delay in approving and funding Nevirapine that has resulted from ADEC's decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) deferred a decision to allow time for important efficacy and safety data from an additional clinical study to be presented. The company had presented a preliminary discussion of the results of the study at a late stage in the evaluation process. The Committee agreed that a decision should not be made until a final study report was submitted and evaluated in the usual manner. In doing so, it was only following normal and proper procedure.
(2) Yes. However, the implication of the question is that this should have relevance to Australia. I would make two points:
(i) I have no intention of slavishly following what another country does.

(ii) As of 13 January 1997, Nevirapine had been approved for use in only two countries worldwide—USA and Argentina. It is currently being evaluated in several other countries, including Canada and New Zealand. An application for approval has not yet been submitted in any European country, the United Kingdom or Japan.
Australia is therefore ahead of most of the rest of the world with regard to evaluating this drug.
(3) It is not possible to say as approval by the ADEC does not guarantee Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme subsidisation.
(4) No. However, even if it did, one needs to weigh up the risks of making a drug available without adequate safety and efficacy data.

I should say that Australia has an outstanding record in fast‐tracking the evaluation of drugs to treat HIV/AIDS. In 1995‐96, the Therapeutic Goods Administration evaluated and the ADEC recommended approval of five important new drugs to treat HIV/AIDS. In most of these cases, Australia's decisions were in advance of most of the rest of the world.
Further, there are procedures in place aimed at expediting evaluations of important new drugs whenever possible, whilst continuing to ensure that proper processes are followed.
(5) No. While I am particularly sympathetic to the needs and concerns of anybody facing a life‐threatening condition, I do not concede in this case that there is anything in need of remedy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 23 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the government's objective to maintain viable populations and genetic diversity of species in Australia's forests; if so, should reserves be large enough to sustain the viability of populations, in order to maintain species diversity.

(2) Has the government of Victoria set a target for protecting a minimum number of Tiger Quolls in the wild in Victoria: (a) is this target 3000; (b) is this the minimum number to maintain viable populations and genetic diversity of this species; and (c) on what scientific evidence is this judgement made.
(3) Is the stronghold of Tiger Quolls in Victoria in East Gippsland.
(4) Has the Federal Government set targets for protecting a minimum number of Tiger Quolls in the wild in Victoria and in East Gippsland; if so, what are the targets, and how were they derived.

(5) Has the Victorian government set a target for protecting a minimum number of Tiger Quolls in forests covered by the East Gippsland Forest Management Plan: (a) is this target 50 or, if not, how many; (b) on what basis was the number calculated; (c) if the target for Special Protection Zones in East Gippsland is 50, where in Victoria are reserves for the balance of the targeted 3000 located, specifically: (i) regions, (ii) areas of suitable habitat, and (iii) numbers.

(6) Is it the Federal Government's assessment that the Special Protection Zones in the East Gippsland Forest Management Plan would provide sufficient suitable habitat for only a fraction even of the Victorian government's targeted number of 50 Tiger Quolls; if not, why not, if so, why.

(7) Will the Minister guarantee to Senator Brown, to the Australian community and to future generations that he is completely satisfied, personally, that the proposed reserves in the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement will sustain viable populations of the Tiger Quoll, so that this, amongst other species, can persist and continue to evolve into the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It is the government's stated objective in the National Forest Policy Statement, to protect biological diversity of species by establishing dedicated reserves of forests on public land. The reserves should be large enough to sustain areas of high quality habitat for all known elements of biodiversity.
(2) Yes. The government of Victoria has established a minimum target for protecting Tiger Quolls in the wild.
(a) Yes. The target is 3000.

(b) Yes. The Action Statement prepared under the Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act 1988, by Victorian zoologists, considers 3000 to be a minimum number to maintain viable populations and genetic diversity.

(c) There is no scientific evidence available on the number of 3000 being necessary to maintain viable Tiger Quoll populations in Victoria. The number of 3000 is a reasonable theoretical population number derived at by Victorian zoologists, following identification of declining Tiger Quoll populations evidenced in records from survey work by the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (NRE) and others over the last 15—20 years. This has included forest block surveys, other surveys covering much of the state, and incidental reports by naturalists, researchers and NRE staff.
(3) One of the known strongholds of Tiger Quolls is the dry rain shadow areas of the Upper Snowy River in the Snowy River and Alpine National Parks, in East Gippsland.

(4) No, but as part of the Comprehensive Regional Assessment of East Gippsland, the Federal Government, jointly with the Victorian Government, has determined that following identification of 50 Tiger Quoll detection sites, the conservation guideline in the East Gippsland Forest Management Plan will be reviewed.

(5) No. The Victorian Government will firstly identify 50 Tiger Quoll detection sites and then review its conservation guideline in the East Gippsland Forest Management Plan, to ensure adequate protection of the species.

(a) No. There is a lack of adequate research to establish a target number of Tiger Quolls to be protected. As quolls are extremely difficult animals to detect, indirect methods for their protection are required.

(b) 50 Tiger Quoll detection sites have been set by NRE zoologists as an arbitrary target, to be followed by a review of the conservation guideline in the East Gippsland Forest Management Plan, in order to provide adequate protection of the species.

(c) A target number of 50 Special Protection Zones for Tiger Quolls has not been set in the East Gippsland Forest Area. The conservation of a minimum population of 3000 adults is the statewide target. (i) Suitable habitat and existing populations are found in the Otways, along the Great Dividing Range and eastern Victoria, and the Mt Eccles area of south-western Victoria. (ii) Habitat conservation in these regions and specifically, in East Gippsland, will focus on establishing a network of areas within the likely home range of the recorded animal which may include conservation reserves, larger patches of Special Protection Zone, stream buffers, steep slopes and areas unsuitable for timber harvesting. (iii) The aim for the Otway and south-western populations is to have at least 300 adults while the aims for populations in the other regions including East Gippsland, have yet to be determined.

(6) Yes. It is the Federal Government's assessment that the Special Protection Zones in the East Gippsland Forest Management Plan would provide suitable habitat for only a fraction of the Tiger Quolls with most of the known habitats located within the Alpine National Park, the Snowy River National Park and the Errinundra National Park. As stated in Question 5, a number of `50' Tiger Quolls has not been set.

(7) I am satisfied that the conservation objective outlined in the Victorian Government's Flora and Fauna Guarantee Action Statement No 15, provides for the protection of adequate populations of Tiger Quoll so that the species can persist and continue to evolve into the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who is the multi millionaire who has imported over 60 cars in his own name over the past five years, and who was referred to in the article by Brian Toohey which appeared in the West Australian on Monday 2 December 1996.

(2) Can the Minister confirm whether an investigation undertaken into one BMW imported last year by this individual showed that it was brand new, yet had been declared for entry into Australia as over 15 years old.

(3) Can the Minister confirm whether further checks into imports by this individual have shown a similar pattern, for example, new vehicles either being declared as too old to attract duty or of such little value as to minimise the amount owing.
(4) Have investigations been conducted into the imports and Customs duties paid on items imported in this person's own name.
(5) Has a formal audit on this person and his private companies and trusts been conducted; if not, why not.
(6) Has the Australian Tax Office (ATO) made any comments regarding the need for an audit; of so, what.
(7) Has the ATO demanded an explanation for why an audit has not taken place.
(8) Is it fair to say that Customs officers have been directed not to think of themselves as working in an enforcement culture, but to think of their job as facilitating trade?

(9) Is it a fact that one well‐known freight company keeps being given extensions of time to pay duties on a wide range of imports even though some of the money has been owing for four years; if so, why?
(10) What is the name of that company?
(11) Is it a fact that, according to an internal Customs report, under‐collection of fuel excises amounted to about $140 million?
(12)(a) Over what period of time did this amount accrue; and (b) has this money been recovered?
(13) Did the internal report make any suggestions about how under‐collection could be avoided; (a) what were they; and (b) have they been implemented; if not, why not.
(14) Is large scale avoidance also rife in the case of cigarettes?
(15) Has any investigation been conducted to determine whether avoidance is also rife in the case of cigarettes; if not, why not; if so, what was found.
(16) How many cuts in Customs staff took place since 1990 under the Australian Labor Party Government: (a) in absolute numbers; and (b) as a percentage of all staff?
(17) How many cuts to Customs staff have taken place since the Coalition has been elected: (a) in absolute numbers; and (b) as a percentage of total staff?
(18) How much have staff cuts since 1990 cost in terms of redundancy payments?
(19) To what extent will staff cuts weaken the ability of Customs to detect smuggling and other forms of fraud?
(20) Is it a fact that Customs staff are no longer on duty at night or weekend at major ports around Australia?
(21) Has a cost benefit analysis been undertaken of reducing Customs staff against revenue forgone as a result of increased duty and sales tax avoidance?

(22) Is there any evidence to suggest that providing extra staff to what is currently available would enable Customs to more adequately enforce the law and to recover revenue which would far exceed their labour cost?
(23) Can the ratios of Customs staff to revenue raised for each year since 1989 be provided?
(24) Can the ratios of Customs staff to successful anti‐smuggling, anti fraud and detection of Customs avoidance incidents and value for each year since 1989 be provided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Details of importations are provided to and held by the Australian Customs Service in confidence. I therefore regard it as inappropriate to reveal specific details of importers or their business transactions.
(2)‐(5) I have directed that the allegations made in the article be thoroughly investigated. Should there be any foundation to the allegations, appropriate action will be taken.
(6) and (7) I am not aware of any requests from the ATO on these matters.
(8) The Customs Corporate Statement identifies three principal roles:

PARA.TAB: to facilitate trade and the movement of people across the Australian border while protecting the community and maintaining appropriate compliance,
to assist Australian industry through the delivery of Government support measures, and
to collect customs and excise revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: Customs is a service‐oriented organisation with wide responsibilities covering industry, international commerce and travellers, and the Australian community. In striving to facilitate the legitimate movement of trade and people, Customs is conscious of the need to balance its role in the administration of laws and regulations designed to protect the community.
The Corporate Statement has been promulgated widely to all staff.
(9) and (10) Customs is not aware of any current case which fits the circumstances described in this question. If further details can be provided, I will have them investigated.

(11) An internal Customs paper estimated that if all fuels capable of being substituted for, or blended with, diesel fuel were in fact diverted to this use, the maximum revenue loss would be of the order of $140 million. The assumption underlying this worst case estimate is not valid as substitutable fuels have been and are used for legitimate purposes.
(12) There is no evidence that a loss of this scale did occur.

(14) The importation and local production of tobacco products is subject to ongoing compliance audit. While some cases have come to notice, there is no evidence of large scale avoidance of Customs and Excise duty in the case of cigarettes.
(15) Allegations of avoidance of Customs and Excise duties on cigarettes are made from time to time. These are investigated and where evidence is obtained appropriate action is taken.

(16)(a) At 30 June 1991 (comparable figures are not available for 30 June 1990) there were 5009 paid operative staff in Customs. At 30 March 1996 (following the Federal election) there were 4443 paid operative staff. This represents a reduction of 566. Of these, 439 staff left the agency through a voluntary redundancy program.
(b) This is a 11.3% reduction.

(17)(a) At 30 March 1996 (following the Federal election) there were 4443 paid operative staff in Customs and as at 30 December 1996 there were 4109 paid operative staff. This represents a reduction of 334 of which 302 left Customs through a voluntary redundancy program.
(b) This is a 7.5% reduction.

(19) Modern Customs techniques rely on advance targeting and risk assessment of vessels and aircraft entering the country. This is enhanced by the effective use of new technology. This combined means that Customs no longer has to rely on 24 hour physical coverage of every post and can target resources to meet risks as they are identified. The number of staff is therefore not related to the number of tasks or volume of cargo but to the identified risk.
It is interesting to note that over the last five years there was an upward trend in the quantities of drugs seized at airports and seaports as well as from the Post.
(20) Staff are on shift duty at major ports such as Sydney and Melbourne; at other ports, staff are available outside normal hours to meet identified needs.
(21) No there is no evidence that any revenue has been forgone.

(22) There is no evidence to suggest that a simple increase in staff numbers would improve Customs' ability to enforce the law and recover additional revenue. Effective compliance management requires application of risk management techniques by appropriately skilled staff with the support of effective technology. It is this formula which Customs is pursuing.
Total Revenues paid to Consolidated Revenue by Financial Year
(24) The answer is in two parts; prohibited goods and recoveries of avoided revenue.
Prohibited goods. The best available measures are for drug seizures, by number of seizures and by weight.

It is unwise to construe too much about the efficacy of Customs operations from these figures. They cannot distinguish between changes in Customs efficiency and changes in the supply and demand for illicit drugs. Also, yearly figures for the weight of seizures (particularly Cannabis) vary
widely depending on the occurrence or otherwise of one or two large quantity seizures in any given year.
However the figures seem to show an increase in weights of seizures in recent years, but with a decrease in the number of seizures.
Note: 1996/97 figures to date show an upward trend. Customs has in the last few weeks made 3 major seizures totalling an estimated 24 tonnes, more than 4 times the total for any previous full year.
